This week, the Summer Boat Show in London showcases many impressive yachts filled with new technology. Most of these boats are descendants of a major design change that happened 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat rests quietly in a tidal creek on the south coast. Although it was designed last year, it looks like it is 100 years old, which might make you think its owner is a romantic. Perhaps I am, but I’m not sure.

My boat combines the charm of classic design with the benefits of modern technology. However, while technology is essential in today’s boat design and building, it often separates sailors from the true challenges of life at sea. These challenges are often what they wanted to experience by going sailing in the first place. I’m not saying sailors should go back to facing every hardship. I believe it’s important for my boats to have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable sleeping areas. But why go sailing if every sail operates automatically? Dealing with a flapping sail is part of being a sailor.

Why should we give up common sense and move our steering positions from the safe back of the boat to a less secure spot near the front? Unfortunately, this change creates a cabin that resembles an ocean liner, with a bed larger than one at home. To me, a boat should always feel like a boat, not a house on the water.

When I bought my previous boat, Hirta, to sail around Britain for a TV race series, the previous owner noted that it had all the comforts but no luxuries. Over the years, I learned how true that was. Hirta had heavy sails, no running water, little electricity, no fridge, no central heating, no winches, and no electronics, especially for navigation. Yet, she was the easiest and most pleasant boat I ever sailed.

However, classic boats require a lot of maintenance, and when I injured my back, I realized I could no longer care for Hirta. I looked for a younger boat but found none that met my needs, so I decided to build a new one from scratch. The Westerman has never let me down. Although designer Nigel Irens and his assistant Ed Burnett use computer design programs, Irens first sketched this boat on a paper napkin before moving to the computer. After creating a model, just like boat builders did in the past, we refined the design together. The final version was perfect.

The completed boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of her first six races. She has a timeless look, sails beautifully, and her interior, made from reclaimed pitch pine, creates a peaceful atmosphere. This may be because she was designed solely as a sailing boat, without considering any furniture. This traditional approach works well. In her calm presence, she proves that you don’t need to follow trends to find happiness, and sometimes it’s wise to learn from history. Built with timber treated to resist water, she has all the advantages of a fiberglass boat while still looking, feeling, and sailing like a true classic.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are experiencing a surge in popularity. We asked five journalists to explore some of these places.

**A. HENLOW GRANGE**  
I was excited to spend six days at Henlow Grange because I was tired and needed to unwind. My room in the large 18th-century house was incredibly comfortable, and I felt relaxed right away. On the first day, I rested and slept a lot. Starting on the second day, I participated in various classes like body conditioning, yoga, and stretching. The instructors were very skilled, and I was amazed at how flexible I became throughout the week. They offer a wide range of treatments, including aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The facial treatment, which lasts an hour, truly makes you feel rejuvenated. The staff in the treatment rooms were exceptionally friendly and professional. The atmosphere was vibrant and enthusiastic. Henlow plans to renovate this year, adding a half-size Olympic swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. Bicycles are available for riding around the grounds. If you prefer a quieter activity and the weather is nice, you can read a magazine or take a peaceful walk in the garden. During my stay, my mood and appetite improved. I left feeling wonderful and energized, which lasted a long time. I definitely want to return. This is an ideal getaway for stressed working women. Save Room 5 for me!  
— Marcella D'Argy Smith

**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**  
The peaceful atmosphere of this stately home was clear as soon as I entered the reception area. The Hall features a beautifully decorated library, a lovely conservatory, and plenty of space, allowing you to avoid conversation if you wish. Upon arrival, everyone receives a medical check-up, including an examination of weight and blood pressure. We were all referred to as patients, which felt a bit strange since I am healthy. However, I appreciated that a shoulder issue found during the exam was quickly addressed by the fitness instructor, and we worked on it in group workshops and individual sessions. Each guest follows a specific diet. I lost weight without fasting, but I felt quite hungry and developed a headache on the second day. My daily menu included grapefruit and honey for breakfast, salads for lunch, and a mix of exotic fruit, yogurt, and hot broth for dinner. If you’re not on a light diet, you can eat in the main dining hall, where the food is delicious and well-presented. You receive a massage or water therapy every other day, and additional treatments are reasonably priced.  
— Liz Gregory

**C. CAREYS MANOR**  
Careys is not a health farm and does not claim to be one. It is a charming old manor with cozy log fires and a spacious lounge. If you are counting calories, you might want to skip the gourmet food, which features rich sauces and delightful desserts created by a French chef. Fortunately, the hotel has a fully-equipped gym and a soft-water pool, allowing me to work off some of the tempting dishes. (You can choose a 'health-conscious' diet if you want to lose weight.) The spa includes a bath, steam room, Swiss shower, sauna, and treatment rooms. A major attraction is the sports injury clinic, where I received expert advice on an old shoulder injury. The physiotherapist suggested good posture, exercises, and massage. Careys is both comfortable and luxurious, relaxed yet elegant. If you want to explore, the surrounding countryside is beautiful.  
— Beverly D'Silva

**D. CLIVEDEN**  
Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats guests like royalty. It offers health and beauty treatments, a well-equipped gym, saunas, a swimming pool, tennis, horse riding, and more. The estate features stunning woodland walks and gardens across 376 acres. Waldo's, a highly-acclaimed restaurant, serves dishes that are simply delightful. It took me half an hour to read the dinner menu because of the many choices. The meal was fantastic, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice cream. I went to bed feeling very happy! The next morning, I spent a few hours in the gym to burn off some calories before my next meal. In the Pavilion, I enjoyed a facial with gentle heat and essential oils, followed by an aromatherapy massage. I thought about the other journalists' reports on fitness assessments and beauty treatments. Cliveden offers all these options if you want to use them before indulging at Waldo's.  
— Kay Letch

**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**  
The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It’s the best because it’s the most delicious I’ve ever had, but the worst because it contains 360 calories, which can be a setback if you’re trying to lose weight. You have been warned! The second best thing is the amazing aromatherapy massage. I chose a relaxing oil blend and fell asleep twice during the treatment, which led to the best night’s sleep I’ve had in years. The facilities are modern and well-organized, with luxurious bedrooms. There are many therapists and beauty rooms, making it easy to schedule appointments. A variety of treatments are available, from manicures and pedicures to deep-cleansing facials and body treatments. The guests are a diverse group, including football teams, mothers and daughters, friends, and singles. Ideally, I would take a break here about once a month.  
— Eve Cameron

**NATURAL TALENTS**

In the seven million years since humans and chimpanzees split from a common ancestor, we have not developed significant differences; genetically, we are still over 98% similar to chimps. This suggests that the traits that make us human are a recent development in our evolutionary history. Our ability to create art and other unique human characteristics likely come from just a small number of our genes. This is a heavy responsibility for such a limited set of genes. 

Recent studies of animal behavior have shown that many traits once thought to be unique to humans are now seen as differences in degree rather than kind. For instance, both humans and wild chimpanzees use tools; chimpanzees use sticks to eat and as weapons, while sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys also have a basic form of language, using different sounds to warn of predators like leopards, eagles, and snakes. This means that aside from art, there are few clear differences between humans and animals.

If human art comes from a unique genetic trait, it is curious that our ancestors did not create art for almost 6.9 million years after separating from chimps. The earliest forms of art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but these materials do not last over time. We only have clear evidence of human art, such as cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments, starting around 35,000 years ago with the Cro-Magnons.

If we argue that our recent artistic achievements set us apart, we must consider how our art differs from that of animals. Three common claims are made: human art is non-utilitarian, it is created for aesthetic pleasure, and it is learned rather than instinctive. 

First, as Oscar Wilde noted, "All art is quite useless." A biologist might interpret this to mean that human art does not help us survive or reproduce, unlike many animal behaviors. While some human art serves a purpose in communication, it is not the same as passing on genes. In contrast, birdsong has clear functions, such as defending territory or attracting mates, which help transmit their genes. By this measure, human art does seem different.

The second claim is that human art is motivated by aesthetic pleasure. We cannot ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mainly sing during mating season, suggesting they do not sing just for beauty. Again, this makes human art seem unique.

The third claim is that human art is learned rather than instinctive. Different human cultures have distinct art styles that are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo and Paris are easily distinguishable, but these styles are not genetically inherited. In contrast, some bird species are born with the ability to sing their specific songs, even if they have never heard them before. 

The role of learning in human art is evident in how quickly our styles change. For instance, geese have made the same sounds for 2,000 years, but human art evolves rapidly. Even casual museum visitors can tell that a twentieth-century painting is more recent than the Mona Lisa. Art experts can often identify the time and artist of a painting they do not know. However, even experts might confuse two mid-twentieth-century artists named Congo and Betsy, who were actually chimpanzees. Congo created up to 33 paintings in one day for his own enjoyment and became upset when his pencil was taken away. Congo and Betsy had a show of their paintings in 1957 in London, and many of their works sold, which is something many human artists cannot claim.

These chimpanzee paintings challenge the distinctions between human art and animal behavior. Like human art, the paintings by these apes were not created for practical purposes; they were made for the satisfaction of the artist. One might argue that human art is different because it is often intended as a form of communication, while the apes did not care to share their work with others. However, this argument is not entirely convincing, as some famous human artworks were also created for personal satisfaction rather than communication.

**An Awfully Big Adventure**

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on Earth and also one of the most dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell his story. There are few big adventures left and even fewer heroes. In the past, children's stories featured brave explorers with sunburnt skin and squinting eyes, journeying into the unknown. Nowadays, such characters are rare in fiction and even more so in real life. That was my belief until I met Charles Blackmore.

Blackmore's adventure involved leading a team across the Taklamakan Desert, known locally as the Desert of Death. He shared the dangers and excitement of this incredible journey from the comfort of his home. His team included four Britons (one was a medical officer), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have endangered everyone’s lives and the success of the expedition.

This diverse group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of one of the harshest deserts in the world, and Blackmore has written a captivating account of their journey. At that time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 fulfilling years. He started the expedition for fun, to find purpose in his life, and to discover who he really was outside the Army. "I had always thought I would spend my whole life in the Army. I had been offered a promotion, but suddenly I wanted to see who Charles Blackmore really was. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried that I wouldn’t return since no one had ever completed that route; we were going in without any knowledge."

In the end, it took them 59 days to cross from west to east, and Blackmore described the desert as very kind to them. Anyone reading his remarkable story might question the use of the word "kind." The team faced unimaginable hardships: dysentery, extreme temperatures, severe thirst, and the loss of part of their water supply. "But," Blackmore explains, "when we were at our limits and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we found some. We didn’t encounter the desert's famous sandstorms, and we avoided the freezing cold that could have stopped us completely. However, we were constantly battling challenges. The fine sand got into everything, especially our blisters and wounds. Climbing the high dunes was torture for both us and the heavily loaded camels, which often rolled over onto us."

"What motivated me most was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time did not allow for one. No aircraft flew over us. Once we entered the sandhills, we were completely alone. I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very afraid of my physical ability. I remember the first day — we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that it was hard to breathe. I thought, 'We have to start now!' At that moment, I was very scared."

If it was tough at the beginning, how did they feel at the end? "After walking 1,000 kilometers, you’re not going to give up. You’ve endured so much; you have come so far. We were very thin but also very strong despite our exhaustion. My body was toned, and my legs felt powerful. I could walk over anything."

Midway through the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon and thinking of his family. How aware was he of the struggle it must have been for them? "Inside me, there’s someone trying to find peace. When I have doubts about myself now, I think back to the desert and remember that we managed to accomplish that. I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I’ve done. Yet, when I think of my life’s achievements, I think of my family and the happiness we share — by that measure, the desert doesn’t compare."

Has Charles Blackmore found peace? "I long for the challenge — for the open spaces — and the determination it brings. We were uplifted by our sense of purpose. Now, I find it hard to fit into the sameness of modern life."

**Text: 'Rediscovering Manual Work'**

Susan Harr decides to unplug her devices and enjoy the benefits of doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it provides us with amazing gadgets that simplify our lives and supposedly give us more free time. However, this belief is a form of brainwashing that makes us think technology is essential. Using our hands for tasks does not harm the environment, unlike many gadgets.

After a frustrating experience with a broken word processor, which cost a lot to fix, Susan realized that gadgets often cause more problems than they solve. She began to let her household technology fade away as it broke down. This made her question what "extra time" technology really gives us. Does it just lead us to buy more gadgets for new activities? She suspects that marketing tricks us into thinking we need these devices.

When her broken gadget started making strange noises, even after being unplugged, she left it outside, where it now sits quietly. Susan enjoys working without noisy machines, allowing her to focus on her sewing. She feels safer sewing by hand, rather than using an electric machine that moves quickly towards her fingers. Plus, she can easily take her sewing supplies anywhere.

While there are some gadgets she appreciates, like her washing machine, she has found joy in living without others. After feeling too reliant on television, she returned her rented color TV and switched to a small black-and-white one. This change has encouraged her family to spend more time walking their dog, reading, talking, and enjoying hobbies. For Susan, sewing has become a new passion, and her old sewing machine now serves as a plant table. 

People often think they cannot live without technology, but Susan believes that life was once filled with hard work and struggle. Computers now do many tasks for us, but she finds that sewing by hand is enjoyable and fulfilling. She can listen to the radio or talk with loved ones while sewing, and even watch her favorite shows without feeling guilty, as she is being productive.

Initially, Susan was intimidated by the idea of hand-sewing, thinking it would be tedious. However, she has discovered that it is calming and satisfying to see her work improve. She finds that tasks get done quickly, and she can enjoy a slower pace of life. She also appreciates the simple pleasure of washing dishes by hand, allowing her to daydream.

Now, Susan looks around her home and questions the need for many gadgets. She wonders if they really need a freezer, microwave, or electric lawnmower. In fact, she realizes they could save a lot of money by living without electric lights!

**Text: The Cabinet-Maker Charles Hurst**

Charles Hurst is a skilled cabinet-maker who creates beautifully crafted furniture. Joanna Watt meets him in his workshop, located under a railway arch in East London. When I arrive, he greets me quickly with a handshake and says, "Well, fire away then!" It’s hard to tell if he is truly in a hurry or just acting tough. However, looking around his workshop, it’s clear he is busy, with many unfinished pieces of furniture and colorful wooden planks everywhere.

Hurst has been a cabinet-maker for ten years and has built a strong reputation. His order book is always full for months ahead, even though he doesn’t actively promote himself. People know that if they want a quality cupboard, table, bookcase, or kitchen unit, Hurst is the right choice. While it’s not hard to find a furniture-maker, finding one who focuses on making well-crafted furniture with simple designs is more challenging. Hurst notes, "There are few real cabinet-makers now. Many call themselves furniture-makers."

As a craftsman with high standards, Hurst often feels disappointed by modern furniture. He expresses his frustration with poorly made, mass-produced items and craftsmen who create low-quality pieces. His pursuit of perfection is a key part of his success, along with his talent. Hurst is confident in his skills, stating, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things." Despite his confidence, he shows some humility towards the end of our conversation.

Hurst is self-taught. When asked how he learned his craft, he replies, "I asked the right questions and picked it all up." Most of his work comes from private clients, and some return for more projects. He enjoys completing entire houses for clients, but admits that not all client relationships are easy. He finds it frustrating when clients are unsure of what they want until it’s too late, but he appreciates clients who have clear expectations.

While Hurst is proud of his work, he also acknowledges the skills of others. He says, "There are people far better than me. I can admire other people." He criticizes craftsmen who take too long to create a single piece, and he is not fond of degree shows where students try to make fashion statements. He believes furniture should be practical and usable, not just a statement piece.

Hurst may be confident and direct, but he is not pretentious. As I leave, he reminds me, "After all, I am only making furniture," showing a grounded attitude towards his craft.

**Three Theories About Sleep**

People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping, which suggests that sleep is very important. However, scientists do not fully agree on why we need to sleep. There are three main theories.

The first and most popular theory suggests that sleep is mainly for our physical health. It argues that while we sleep, our bodies work to repair any damage from the day and restore our energy.

The second theory focuses on the benefits of sleep for learning. It claims that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day, and without sleep, we would struggle to learn effectively.

The third theory is about energy. It suggests that we need to sleep to recharge our energy, so we are ready for the next day.

**ECCENTRICS**

An eccentric is someone whose behavior is unusual and does not follow the accepted norms of society. This raises the question, "What is normal?" Most people have their own quirks and peculiarities. These might include a love for entering newspaper contests, a habit of collecting beer mats, or a tendency to write letters to the editor about various topics. Eccentricity is a way of expressing our individuality.

Inside us, there is often a struggle between two opposing forces. One force is called individualism, which encourages us to be unique, while the other is conformity, which pushes us to fit in. For many, the desire to be accepted and liked by others is stronger than the desire to stand out and be different. 

People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often come together. They form clubs, hold meetings, and organize events to discuss their shared interests or challenges. The key idea here is 'common.' They seek others who understand what their friends and family might see as odd. Being part of a group, even a small one, can be comforting.

Most of us feel a tension between individualism and conformity. While we may follow the crowd, we often resist the idea that we are doing so. We feel a need to express our individuality, like when a man at a bar declares, "I say what I think," or when a newcomer insists, "You must take me as you find me. I don’t follow social rules."

At any moment, we can choose to embrace our individuality. Many people succeed in their careers by doing just that. For instance, Bob Dylan, the American singer, has said, "When you feel strongly about what you are doing and pursue it passionately, you will surprise many people." However, this assertion of individuality is not the same as eccentricity, especially in the beginning. 

When a pop singer wears strange clothes for attention, or a socialite makes shocking comments to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. But if they continue these behaviors until they become a part of who they are, then they can be considered eccentric. The key aspect of eccentricity is its naturalness. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they simply are.

A true eccentric is not focused on what others think. They act according to their true selves. This sets eccentrics apart from enthusiasts, pranksters, clever criminals, attention-seekers, and recluses. These individuals are aware of society and often act in response to it. Some want to impress others, while others want to escape from society. In contrast, eccentrics live their lives freely, without concern for societal expectations.

**Natural Books**

We asked four prominent naturalists to share the wildlife book that has had the most impact on them.

**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I have had the privilege of meeting many influential figures in this field. Among them, Barbara Ward stands out. She has been central to environmental discussions in Europe after the war. She combined her experiences from various environmental movements into a powerful philosophy. As a young journalist, I found her insights made everything clearer. Choosing her book was more challenging. It could have been *Only One Earth* or *Progress for a Small Planet*, but I believe *The Home of Man* is her most significant work. It discusses the rapid growth of cities while addressing the larger themes she cared about. It is a passionate call for what we now refer to as "sustainable human development." I have not found another book that matches its depth.

**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read *Signals for Survival* by Niko Tinbergen, I can almost hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of guano in the sun. This book beautifully explains the intriguing world of animal communication through words and images. After reading it, watching a gull colony transforms from chaos into a well-organized social structure. You can identify partners and family groups. Niko Tinbergen was a remarkable behaviorist who aimed to make his research accessible to everyone. His collaboration with talented wildlife artist Eric Ennion resulted in a book that appeals to anyone who loves nature. Ennion's paintings, created from years of observing birds, vividly show their behaviors, such as aggression and submission. This is the work of a true naturalist.

**C. Lee Durrell**  
Without a doubt, *My Family and Other Animals* by Gerald Durrell has greatly influenced my life. It not only led me to a wonderful husband and a fulfilling career in conservation but also solidified my love for the natural world. I was studying animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read this book. After two years of challenges, opening *My Family and Other Animals* at the end of a long day brightened my spirits. It beautifully intertwines animals, people, joy, and beauty, creating a vision of a world worth protecting. While many criticize humanity for its negative impact on nature, I remember Gerald as a child in the book, viewing all living beings as a family, connected and inseparable. This is a vital perspective for us all.

**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I discovered *The Shell Bird Book* by James Fisher in my school library shortly after it was published in 1966. I was immediately attracted to it, especially the 48 colorful bird illustrations by Eric Ennion. These images captivated me. I already owned other bird books and had spent vacations learning to identify birds, which inspired me to start sketching them. However, *The Shell Bird Book* offered much more. Along with the beautiful illustrations, it included chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even a section on birds in music, literature, and art. The wide range of information and stunning images encouraged me to appreciate birds and nature more broadly. The book showed me that my emotional and creative connection to nature is just as important as a scientific understanding. Since art was my stronger subject, I began to see new possibilities for my future.

**Do Reviews Sell Books?**

We asked five prominent British publishers about how book reviews affect sales. Here’s what they shared.

**Publisher A**  
Reviews are crucial for publishers; they are the first thing we check in newspapers. A study by the Book Marketing Council showed that many people buy a book because of reviews, more than any other reason like ads or recommendations from friends. Authors feel differently about reviews. Both authors and publishers are upset when there are no reviews, but publishers often take bad reviews in stride, believing that any mention can help sales. They enjoy reviews that reflect their own opinions about a book since they are often the first to read it.

**Publisher B**  
While publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, their needs are different. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books reviewed positively. Book reviews today are more varied and accessible than they were 40 years ago, but there is still a tendency to overlook paperbacks, which most people read. Weekly summaries of books are often insufficient, and even original paperbacks rarely get serious attention. However, publishers need reviews to promote books and authors effectively. A lively review from a respected source can boost sales, especially if there are multiple reviews. Fame helps get books into readers' hands.

**Publisher C**  
Reviews are essential for literary publishing; without them, we would struggle. Our books are usually not by well-known authors, and we rarely advertise, so we rely on literary editors to review our books. Positive reviews are far more valuable than ads because they are seen as unbiased. Good reviews can significantly increase book sales, but they need to be combined with other factors like recommendations from readers, support from booksellers, and smart marketing.

**Publisher D**  
I wish I understood the relationship between publishing and reviewing in Britain! In the U.S., a single review in the New York Times can make or break a book. Here, booksellers often ignore reviews. Sometimes, it takes years of great reviews for a good writer to gain readers. Interestingly, some poorly received books or those without reviews can still sell very well. The impact of reviews is unpredictable, although non-fiction reviews often focus more on the subject than the book itself.

**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers hope for positive reviews, but do they actually lead to sales? I once published a biography that received excellent reviews, but it didn’t sell well because people felt they could just read the reviews instead of buying the book. Does the reviewer’s name matter? Thirty years ago, certain reviewers had a strong influence on public opinion. Nowadays, unexpected reviewers or particularly clever reviews can also motivate potential buyers to visit the bookstore.

**WEATHERVANE MAKER**

The craft of making weathervanes is very old, dating back to ancient Egypt. Today, this skill is still practiced in the workshop of Graham Smith, one of the few artisans in the country who creates hand-cut weathervanes. Graham designs each piece to meet the specific needs of his customers. He explains, "This way, I can create a unique, personalized item." Many of his customers are women looking for special gifts for their husbands, wanting something that reflects their interests in work or leisure.

Graham's work is quite different from the traditional cockerel design, which is the most common type of weathervane. The first weathervane he made featured a witch on a broomstick, which surprised his wife and impressed their friends. They began asking him to make weathervanes for them. "I realized that the subjects I could use were endless," he says. This realization led him to focus on his weathervane business.

Before starting this venture, Graham trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Five years ago, he and his wife, Liz, decided to switch roles: she became the main breadwinner while he took care of their children and developed his business. He has no regrets about this change. "My previous job lacked creativity, but this work is exciting and artistic," he shares. Graham has now created over 100 original designs, paying close attention to detail. He always seeks customer approval for the design before he begins the hand-cutting process.

Graham also keeps a variety of traditional designs available, as they remain popular alongside his unique creations. "People are drawn to handmade items," he notes. "They appreciate the chance to own something different." He has no plans to expand his business, as he prefers to maintain it as a rural craft. "I have found my niche in the market. People love the uniqueness, and I find great satisfaction in transforming a simple shape into something almost lifelike," he explains.

For centuries, weathervanes have helped communities understand changes in the weather by indicating shifts in wind direction. Nowadays, as more people move to rural areas, they want to add unique touches to their homes, which has benefited crafts like Graham's. He has become busier, supplying flat-packed weathervanes to customers around the world, especially in America and Denmark. "The price depends on how detailed the design is," he explains. His latest request was for a weathervane shaped like a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a special gift that stands out.

**Beginner Takes All**

Before it was even published, *The Horse Whisperer* was already the most talked-about book of the year. This first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans made him a lot of money. Here, he shares his inspiration and success.

The beginning of the year was tough for Nicholas Evans, who worked as a screenwriter, producer, and wanted to be a director. Things started badly when a film project he had been working on, called *Life and Limb*, fell apart suddenly. He felt disappointed and worried because he hadn’t made any money in two years, and this film was his only hope to calm his angry bank manager.

A sensible person in Evans' situation would have found a job. He could have returned to his previous role as a television executive or started a television project he had paused. Instead, he made a choice that many, including himself, thought was crazy. He bought a ticket to America and spent three months researching his first novel.

Although he acted on impulse, the idea for the story had been in his mind for a while. It was inspired by a farrier he met while visiting a friend in Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a gentle horse that suddenly became aggressive for no reason. Its owners were desperate until they heard about a gypsy who could calm the horse just by talking to it. These people were known as "horse whisperers." This story fascinated Evans, and he began to research it, initially planning to write a screenplay since he was a filmmaker. However, after losing interest in the film industry, he decided to write the story as a book.

Throughout the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. "It was a strange time," he recalls. "I was observing others, but I felt very alone and thought my life was falling apart. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was deeply in debt, worried about how to support my children, and questioning if it was all a mistake."

By the end of August, after returning home and writing the first half of the book, he felt the pressure from his bank manager. He needed to know if it was worth continuing. He bravely showed the manuscript to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent read it and said it was "fine." When asked for more details, he suggested that Evans might receive a $30,000 advance for the book. Evans thought about how much he needed to pay off some debts, and $30,000 was not enough. He had spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer* and still had at least two months of work left. He was also advised to write a 12-page summary of the rest of the book.

In October, he sent the first two hundred pages of the novel, along with the summary, to seven UK publishers just before they left for the famous Frankfurt Book Fair. Within days, his agent called to say he had turned down the first offer of $75,000. "What?" Evans replied. The agent explained, "It's okay; I feel something big is happening."

What happened next became a significant moment in publishing history. Within a week of intense bidding, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for £550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record amounts for a first novel. "We couldn't believe it; we were in shock. We had never sent the manuscript to New York, and we still don't know how it got there," Evans said. They also didn’t send it to Hollywood, but soon major studios were competing for the film rights. "My UK agent wisely involved an agent in the US, and when he called to say, 'I think we can get $3 million outright,' we laughed in disbelief." 

As they agreed on this amount, the studios each presented their case to Evans. One night in October, he sat in his study while four prominent filmmakers called one after another, eager to pay $3 million for an unfinished novel. Evans shared this story with me over coffee on his wooden porch overlooking his garden. He mentioned that he had turned down an offer to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. "It's been like a fairy tale so far. I don’t want to ruin it. Writing at that level is very challenging, and I don’t want to become just an employee of these people I like who have paid me so much. I would hate to write a draft and then hear, 'Thanks, Nick, but we’ll bring in someone else now.'"

He said he would stay involved but from a distance. The success of his novel led to new support for *Life and Limb*, but he was uncertain if he wanted to pursue it. "I think it would be unwise not to write another novel," he concluded.

**Young Masters**

Bobby Fischer faces challenges as he tries to return to the world of chess. Today, chess is increasingly a game for younger players. After being away for 20 years, Fischer is back and competing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. Fischer won the first game impressively, but he is not the same player he was in 1972. At 49 years old, he is out of practice and not in great shape. Spassky is even older. 

Chess has changed significantly in the last two decades. Fischer helped make chess popular, leading to a new era of professionalism. Now, winning is the main goal for modern players. In international chess, a player’s mental strength and endurance are just as important as their intelligence. The pressure in chess has always been high, with a chess clock ensuring players make their moves in a set time. If they fail to do so, they lose immediately. Nowadays, games can last longer, and many are played without breaks, increasing the pressure on players. 

In the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the last. Currently, eight of the ten highest-ranked players are under 30. The way chess is played has also evolved. Much preparation now happens off the board, not just in psychological battles. Players must prepare thoroughly before matches, especially since computers can store millions of chess games and provide quick access to information about opponents. In recent matches, players have used large teams to analyze each other’s strategies continuously. 

The opening moves of a chess game are now studied in great detail, and being well-prepared can be crucial. Today’s chess scene has more top players than ever before, with many grandmasters competing for modest prizes worldwide. Success requires both mental and physical effort, as a single game can last up to eight hours. For chess masters, this time is a constant challenge, and losing focus can lead to failure. The presence of the chess clock adds to the stress, often leading to frantic moments where players must make quick moves or risk losing. 

In these intense situations, players must rely on their nerves, determination, and strong will to win. At the highest level, the pain of losing is hard to bear, while winning brings great satisfaction and a chance to recover from the stress. However, one victory is not enough to win a tournament; players must be ready for the next challenge. Most chess tournaments last 9 to 11 days, with games every day, and there are competitions throughout the year. World championship matches can be even more demanding. For example, the 1984 match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow had to be stopped after several months due to exhaustion, with Karpov losing about 10 kg.

Can Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do, ever, is play chess." This makes his long absence from the game puzzling. However, it also adds to his legacy. If he has returned for financial reasons, he is in a good position, as both he and Spassky will earn millions from their match. But if Fischer genuinely believes he can prove he is still the best player in the world, the outcome could be very disappointing for him.

**Fame and Fortune**

Imogen Edwards-Jones interviews some of the new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are rising to fame.

**A** Nick Grosso, in his early 30s, has written three well-received plays. He is now turning his first play, *Peaches*, into a movie script. "It's a low-budget project, but we aren't sure how low," he says. "It definitely won't cost over £30 million, but it could be as little as £30." Remarkably, Nick had never seen or read a play before writing *Peaches*. "When I wrote it, I never thought it would actually be performed," he shares. "The play is set in a car, which I probably wouldn’t do now because I understand the challenges involved. Back then, I knew nothing." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After completing his A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I realized I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my work to be performed, not just read, because of its rhythm and rhyme," he explains. "Suddenly, I was with people who thought like me. It was the first time I enjoyed being in an educational setting. It was very inspiring."

**B** Comedian Simon Pegg, 28, has made significant progress in his career since studying drama at Bristol University. He is currently writing a TV comedy series and has just completed a demanding tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. He has always worked hard, even during his time at Bristol, where he practiced his craft in comedy clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon recalls. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a traditional actor; I was always more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it really isn't. If you have courage and good material, making people laugh is wonderful." He has performed with the comedy group Funny Business, but his collaboration with Steve Coogan has been the most rewarding. "He saw my show, and since I was a big fan of his, he probably noticed I was imitating him," Simon admits.

**C** Ciaran McMenamin, 24, gained public attention as the lead in the series *The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star*. The response was very positive, and his career has taken off quickly. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he smiles. "Now I can choose what I want to do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a rare and comfortable position, especially since he has just graduated. Looking back at his early career, it's clear that such recognition was likely. Encouraged by his mother, he moved from leading roles in school plays to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he spent four years. "I was basically using acting to avoid doing homework," Ciaran laughs. "But then I decided I wanted to pursue it seriously because I had a talent and passion for it." Now, he is waiting for the accolades to come in, but when asked about fame, he becomes thoughtful. "When you're 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you soon realize that's not why you act. It's about earning respect for doing good work."

**D** Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has just signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be successful when their single, *Chimera*, is released soon. "The record company's idea of good sales is different from mine," he says. "They expect a hit, but I just want two people to buy it to be happy." Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to enter the music industry ever since. "It's funny how things work out," he says. "I had been performing at student gigs for eight years and was starting to feel discouraged. Just when I was about to give up, I met Rick Brown, who had connections at Domino, and we formed Matrix. It couldn't have come at a better time. There were moments when I felt really down, and I had been in some terrible bands. But hopefully, it will all be worth it."

**E** Poet and author Stephen Richards is 27 years old and has received more awards and honors than many people twice his age. He is already well-known in the poetry community, where he has been touring and giving readings several times a week for the past six years. His first novel, *Hidden*, will be published in March. "It's a story about obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't express as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing in school but became disillusioned with education later. "I chose not to go to university, but I realized I needed to after getting bored stuffing envelopes at a theater." After university, he published his first work, a children's book, in 1992. "I don't think my parents expected me to be a writer; they thought I would just be a reader since that’s all I did as a child." With his poetry receiving much praise, moving into novels is a bold step. "My poetry has a structure, which limits the chance of making mistakes. A novel can be any length, so there are more opportunities for errors. My main goal is to avoid falling into a routine where I produce work without caring about its quality."

A. Isabel, the main character in this quirky novel, believes she looks good in jeans but rarely wears them because she wants to avoid the wrong crowd. At 31, she is an art student who loves historical romances and is searching for the right partner, worried that her knobbly knees might hinder her chances. Despite her concerns, she remains hopeful, which ultimately helps her and others in the story. The author writes with lively energy, using a style reminiscent of early silent films, with chapter titles like "Our Hero Feels Inspired."

B. This story celebrates the rise and near-fall of a local radio station in America. It offers a humorous perspective on radio, seen through the eyes of a clever but timid child named Francis With. Francis works at WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio, a station created by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station broadcasts a mix of singers, preachers, and soap-opera stars. Set in a small American town, the author skillfully uses dry humor and simple language to transport readers back to the more relaxed days of the 1940s and 1950s, filled with dime stores and old Ford cars.

C. In the author's world, it is normal for a second husband to chat with his wife's first husband. When professor Richard Vaisey falls for a beautiful Russian poetess, he shares his feelings with his wife's ex-husband. The poetess writes poor poetry, which bothers Richard, and she seeks his help for her wrongly imprisoned brother. However, the way the author unravels these issues is even more captivating. He moves the story forward with a strong sense of humor and carefully examines relationships, making it a delightful and clever read.

D. In 1960s London, two sets of best friends—two women and two men—become intertwined in each other's lives for 25 years. At the beginning of this lengthy novel, James Hudson, a mysterious American businessman, is starting a newspaper, which his friend Richard Blake is editing. The newspaper launch is important, but so is the fact that they both loved a woman who was killed years earlier. The story includes themes of murder, ambition, love, and jealousy, all written well. This book allows readers to deeply connect with the characters.

E. This touching and funny story, written by a top American author, follows Ian Bedloe, who, feeling guilty about a past mistake, takes on the role of 'father' to his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, he is gradually becoming an eccentric bachelor amid the chaos of family life. The story explores deep emotions and highlights the special bond Ian forms with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm book that perfectly balances sadness and humor.

**Volunteer Tourism**

Four academic writers discuss international voluntary work. 

A. It is difficult to say that volunteer tourists make a significant direct contribution to development. While they may help build homes or schools, they often pay a large fee to participate. This money, if given directly to a local community, could pay for more labor than the volunteer could provide. This is particularly true for gap year volunteers, who usually lack the necessary skills or experience. Therefore, many studies question whether gap year volunteering is mainly driven by a genuine desire to help or if young people are more interested in gaining experience that will benefit their careers. However, these projects can help develop individuals who may act ethically in support of those in need throughout their lives.

B. Volunteering can promote greater international understanding, improve conflict resolution skills, encourage participation in global issues through civic organizations, and create international social networks among everyday people. In this way, the overall benefits can exceed the individual contributions, helping both volunteers and host communities, and contributing to the global good. However, if volunteering is mostly done by wealthy individuals, it may provide them with a broader perspective and career advantages, but it will not significantly help those who lack access to such opportunities. Volunteers may continue to benefit personally while using host organizations and communities to advance their own goals.

C. At its worst, international volunteering can resemble imperialism or self-serving charity, where wealthy Westerners seek personal growth. At its best, it can provide valuable technical assistance for development. It can benefit both volunteers and the organizations they work with, allowing for the exchange of skills, knowledge, and cultural experiences in developing communities. Most importantly, volunteering can raise awareness and foster a lifelong commitment to addressing power imbalances, poverty, injustice, and unsustainable development.

D. Volunteer tourism aligns with the growing trend of personal strategies to help others. These limited strategies, focused on making a small difference, can seem positive in a climate that is skeptical of large governments and businesses. However, they also avoid the need for democratic governance and reduce development to individual acts of charity, often failing to address the root causes of poverty in rural communities. While skepticism about volunteering is often misplaced, the act of volunteer tourism can sometimes be seen as simple charity. However, when it is promoted as sustainable development and when gap-year companies market their programs as such, it reflects a decline in the understanding of development issues. The politics of volunteer tourism can distract from the social realities of global inequalities and the poverty faced by many in developing countries.

**Sound the Alarm**

Stuart Harris reports that many people listen to the radio in the morning and need something to help them get out of bed. This is why clock radios are popular. But how do you choose a good one? A panel, including myself, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five models currently available.

One model has a 'dual alarm function,' which I initially thought would let you wake up to a buzzer, snooze for a bit, and then get up. However, the instruction booklet suggests using this feature to set two different wake-up times: one for weekdays and another for weekends. But who really schedules their life like that? This model costs about the same as another we tested, but it includes a cassette player, allowing you to fall asleep to your favorite tapes and wake up without news. We all agreed the radio quality was excellent, but the size was an issue—it’s as big as a rugby ball. Paul Bridges mentioned that any clock radio he buys must leave enough space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also said he always books a wake-up call just in case the alarm fails.

This model was voted the best in terms of design and overall performance. Paul Bridges said he was 'in love with it,' even though the clock he tested kept getting stuck at 16:00. I found the digital display appealing, with its stylish grey numbers on a soft green background. The wide snooze button is easy to tap even with your eyes closed. However, the smooth buttons made me want to touch them like piano keys, which led to confusion when I finally looked at the instruction booklet. The clock has a backup power feature, so you don’t have to reset it if someone accidentally unplugs it. Everyone liked this feature, but we found it challenging to set up. Still, mastering it made us feel sophisticated.

Tom Granger criticized another model with a built-in lamp, calling it 'unbelievably tacky.' He had to read the instructions twice to get it to work because the clock kept jumping from 12:00 to 02:00. The lamp was difficult to position and not useful for reading, as it only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges found the lamp idea amusing but agreed that tuning the radio was difficult. The buzzer sounded like a submarine alarm, making me want to throw it across the room. Interestingly, this model is the third most popular on the market. Aimed at young people, its bright colors appealed to both Tom Granger and me. Tom said he would choose this one because it stands out, unlike the others. It was also the only model we could set up without reading the instructions, thanks to its traditional controls. Unfortunately, the alarm has a funny 20-minute error margin, meaning it might go off 10 minutes earlier or later than set. Paul Bridges laughed at this, calling the model 'terribly fiddly' and 'completely useless.'

The simplest and cheapest model scored points with Tom Granger because it was standard and took up little space, plus it had old-fashioned dial tuning. He said it was easier to set up. With modern push-button tuning, you can never be sure if you pressed the buttons correctly, which makes it hard to trust that it will work. I thought the tuning was a bit rough, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed the radio quality was good. The buzzer on this model worked well; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

Hedgehogs

A hedgehog is a small mammal known for its sharp spines that cover its body. They are found in many parts of the world, but none are native to America or Australia. All hedgehog species can roll into a tight ball when threatened, with their spines pointing outward for protection. The effectiveness of this defense depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some desert hedgehogs have adapted to their environment and have fewer spines, making them more likely to run away from danger instead of rolling up, using that ability only as a last option.

Hedgehogs are mainly active at night and sleep during the day, often hiding under bushes or in burrows. While all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all do; some may remain awake throughout the year if conditions are suitable.

**Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**

Excelling in any sport is challenging, even for men, but women often face even greater difficulties. Training and competing leave little time for a normal life, requiring many sacrifices. Despite these challenges, women are overcoming prejudice and setting new records. Here, we highlight some remarkable British sportswomen who are achieving their dreams.

**A. Jill, 27, Skier**  
"Flying through the air and landing smoothly feels amazing, but it can also be frightening. Sometimes, I don’t feel well or the weather is bad, making it hard to see, but I push through. Having a career outside of skiing is tough because we train for ten months each year. I have to give up a lot of my social life and friendships, but it was my choice. There are six men and three women on the British team, and we all compete on the same courses and receive equal treatment—it's a young sport."

**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**  
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike to join a charity race and surprisingly won because I cycled faster than everyone else, even though I had never cycled before! I earn a good salary as a professional cyclist, and there are many opportunities for endorsements. However, I worry that people might think I succeeded because of my looks rather than my skills. So, I focus on cycling instead of making money. I train for at least four hours daily on the bike, along with stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands the commitment required."

**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**  
"Rowing is difficult for girls to start because few schools offer it. Most girls begin at 19 or 20, making it harder to compete internationally. Additionally, coaches often change frequently, leading to a lack of stability in the women's team. Despite these challenges, I enjoy rowing and staying fit, and I appreciate the social aspect of the sport."

**D. Ffyona, 24, Long-Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I dreamed of walking around the world, not realizing how vast it is! I found Britain too confining and safe. I was very determined and disliked being controlled by others. Each walk has been unique. My walk across Australia was the most painful experience, covering 50 miles a day with little sleep and many blisters. But I set a record! I had to succeed because my sponsorship would end after 95 days. Some men believe women are more likely to fail, making them hesitant to sponsor us."

**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**  
"Some men have big egos when driving, which is evident on the roads. When I perform well, they often ignore me. Being a woman in racing has its challenges. Men tend to see me as competition, which has led to many tough moments. You need to be competitive and assertive. Earning money in this sport is difficult, and what I do earn goes back into racing. Women have been racing since the 1920s and have often been seen as unusual. It’s encouraging to see more women joining the sport each year. I love saloon car racing because I strive for perfection with every lap."

**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 AM three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evenings, I either cycle or run. Sometimes, I even fall asleep at my desk! There’s a lot of pressure before races, and I really push myself during competitions. I often wonder why I do this, and I realize it’s because a) I feel happier when I’m fit, b) I would be lazy if I didn’t push myself, and c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when events are covered in the media, 90% of the focus is on the men's events, with only 10% mentioning the women's results. The prize money is also less for women. However, we have established an International Triathlon Women's Commission to address these issues."

**The Day I Met Picasso**

Richard Cork remembers the day he met Picasso when he was 78 years old. Even from a distance, he recognized Picasso, who was having lunch at an outdoor restaurant in Cannes. At that time, I was an 18-year-old student traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van. I had run out of money and found a job painting boats by the waterfront. However, I spent a lot of time drawing and had my sketchbook with me when I saw Picasso.

Picasso was known to be a private person, usually working alone in the hills. So, I was surprised to see him sitting at a table with his wife, Jacqueline, and some friends. I would not have approached him if my friend hadn’t encouraged me. Nervously, I introduced myself and asked for his signature, which he kindly gave me. He wrote his name at the top of the page and then added a lively drawing below it. His art often reflected real things, so the lines he drew might have represented a cloud, the sea, or the shape of Cannes harbor.

I thanked him and started a hesitant conversation. Since Picasso's English was not very good and my French was even worse, an American woman at the table helped translate. She kept calling him "the Maestro," which made it hard for me to speak freely. Still, I managed to tell Picasso how much I loved art and admired his work. After a while, I went back to my boat and proudly showed my friend the signature. He noticed that Picasso was still having lunch and urged me to go back and take advantage of the opportunity. He suggested I ask if I could draw Picasso’s portrait.

With my sketchbook in hand, I returned to Picasso's table. I decided not to ask if I could draw him, fearing he might say no. Instead, I stood by the table, set up my pad, took out a crayon, and began to draw. When Picasso saw me, he smiled mischievously and made it hard for me to draw by acting out funny expressions. He rolled his eyes, stuck out his tongue, and made silly shapes with his hands. Although it was tempting to give up, his playful spirit felt like a challenge. I sensed he wanted to see how determined I was.

Eventually, Picasso settled down and allowed me to study him closely. He looked strong and alert, wearing a blue-and-white striped shirt. He seemed much younger than his 84 years, with bright, dark eyes that were full of life. I was captivated by his eyes and tried to capture their intensity in my drawing. Even though he was surrounded by friends, he seemed distant and absorbed in his own thoughts. 

When the American woman told me that Picasso wanted to see my portrait, I felt embarrassed and said it wasn’t good enough. However, Picasso insisted, and when I showed him my sketch, he nodded approvingly. Then, to my surprise, he said it was his turn to draw. I quickly handed him my crayon, and he made a few swift strokes on the paper. In seconds, he created a lively outline of a bearded face that looked very different from my careful drawing. He had moved one of my eyes onto my nose and captured my smile with a single, joyful line. I looked like a character from one of his playful artworks.

I thanked Picasso and asked if he would sign my drawing. The American woman explained that he said I already had his signature. So, there were limits to his generosity! Looking back, I feel incredibly lucky. Meeting Picasso and receiving his attention meant a great deal to me.

**Talking Shop**

Have you ever gone into a store and ended up buying more than you planned? This article explains the strategies that shops use to encourage you to spend more money.

**A. The Freshness Factor**  
Supermarkets understand that customers value fresh produce. To create this impression, they often place fruits and vegetables at the entrance or display house plants. They might also have an in-store bakery that fills the air with the smell of fresh bread. The colors used in the store, like green, are chosen to suggest freshness. However, most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen foods and cleaning products, does not match this fresh image.

**B. Strategic Product Placement**  
The placement of products in a store is crucial for sales. Supermarkets use computerized systems to identify which areas attract the most shoppers. They place high-profit items in these spots, while also using eye-level shelves to catch attention. Special offer bins attract bargain hunters, and complementary items, like desserts near ice cream, encourage additional purchases.

**C. Spreading Essentials**  
Supermarkets often place low-cost essentials like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This forces shoppers to walk past more tempting, higher-priced items. Chain stores may also position popular products away from the entrance, hoping that loyal customers will search for them, thus encountering other tempting products along the way.

**D. Less is More**  
Chain stores have changed how they display their products. For example, the Next chain has moved away from a crowded display style to a more boutique-like approach, showcasing limited fashion items. This creates an impression of exclusivity, even though their clothing is mass-produced. Their success is due to both effective store design and appealing clothing.

**E. The Impact of Total Costs**  
Food shoppers often focus more on the total cost of their shopping rather than the price of individual items. Supermarkets mix low-cost staples with higher-priced items to attract customers. They may even sell some staples at a loss to draw shoppers in, a strategy known as "loss leaders." They achieve low prices by buying in bulk and negotiating discounts with manufacturers.

**F. The Importance of Pricing**  
Shoppers in chain stores tend to buy fewer items and pay more attention to individual prices. For example, pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can influence buying decisions. This pricing strategy also helps reduce theft, as employees must ring up sales to give change.

**G. Effective Lighting**  
Both supermarkets and chain stores carefully consider lighting. Chain stores aim for lighting that resembles natural light, helping customers see the true colors of clothing. Supermarkets use special lighting and mirrors to highlight fresh produce.

**H. Guided Pathways**  
Many chain stores use different carpet patterns to guide shoppers through the store. These paths, known as the "Yellow Brick Road," encourage customers to explore. Some stores, like Marks and Spencer, use more inviting carpets in sales areas to encourage shoppers to venture off the main paths.

**I. In-Store Promotions**  
As you enter a supermarket, you are often greeted by large, colorful images of delicious food, which can be hard to resist if you’re hungry. In the U.S., some supermarkets are testing "video trolleys" that display advertisements as you shop. These trolleys aim to attract impulse buyers and reportedly increase sales by about 30%.

**Sea, Ice & Rock**

Chris Bonnington, aged 58, is famous for reaching the summit of Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written several books, such as *Quest for Adventure* and *Everest the Hard Way*. Robin Knox-Johnston, who is 53, started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-1969, he became the first person to sail solo around the world in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record for crossing the Atlantic Ocean, taking just 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard in England.

Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, documenting their journey in their new book, *Sea, Ice and Rock*. In 1979, while I was working on *Quest for Adventure*, I called Robin for an interview. He invited me to join him for a sailing trip, where I could teach him some climbing techniques, and he could teach me the basics of sailing. It was my first experience on a yacht. We sailed for a while and then anchored. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while we paddled to shore to practice climbing. The route was challenging, but I was impressed by how steady Robin was in difficult conditions. He moved carefully and quietly.

Eventually, we reached a steep drop. I asked Robin if he had ever climbed before, and he said he hadn’t, so I showed him how. After I finished, he politely asked if he could descend using the ropes from his boat. He was used to using his arms, while I wanted him to use his legs. I was a bit uneasy, but he managed to lower himself safely. During that trip to Skye, Robin and I formed a strong friendship. His suggestion that we combine our skills for a trip to Greenland was a natural progression from our Skye adventure.

I was impressed by Robin's leadership. Normally, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin consulted everyone first. Although most crew members hesitated to give advice, it felt good to be part of the decision-making. Honestly, I found sailing challenging and somewhat dull. The moments of crisis were easier to handle because they brought excitement. However, I struggled with the long days at sea. I prefer being on land and am not very handy. In contrast, Robin was a natural sailor who enjoyed fixing the engine and the toilet. I realized that Robin didn’t really need my help, which sometimes made me feel useless.

The crew was cramped, with six people on a 32-foot yacht meant for four. On a mountain expedition, you can get some space from each other. When we arrived in Greenland and it was my turn to lead the expedition, I found it hard to take responsibility for Robin’s safety. There were many times while climbing when if Robin fell, he could have pulled me down with him. I had to be very careful. I also underestimated how difficult the Cathedral, Greenland's highest mountain, would be. Robin is not a natural climber, which made his efforts even more remarkable. The first time we tried to reach the top, we were active for 24 hours. On the way down, we were so tired that we nearly fell asleep on steep slopes, 1,500 feet above the ground. Robin faced many challenges but completely trusted me and followed my lead. When it became too difficult and I realized we had to turn back, he accepted my decision. I knew he was worried about the boat and whether it would make it through the ice, but he still wanted to try climbing the mountain again.

The only time our relationship nearly faced a crisis was on the yacht on the way home. We were taking turns keeping watch. I was supposed to wake up at 4 am for my shift, but Robin decided not to wake me, thinking he could handle it alone. The night before, I had almost fallen asleep. I felt he didn’t trust me, which made me insecure, and I expressed my feelings. Robin quickly reassured me that I had misunderstood the situation. While we enjoyed our trip to Skye, we truly got to know each other by the end of the Greenland expedition. I discovered that beneath his tough exterior, Robin was a kind-hearted and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**

Apples have been part of human life for thousands of years, existing in many colors, shapes, and sizes. However, in the late twentieth century, we risk losing this rich heritage.

**Prehistoric Times (8,000 BC)**  
Humans have eaten apples since ancient times. In neolithic Britain, they discarded apple seeds. Around 10,000 years ago, they left apple remains near lakes in Switzerland and Italy. In these areas, early humans even stored dried apple halves for winter. These apples were wild crab apples, small and different from the apples we know today, which were called 'windings' in Ancient Britain.

**Norman Influence (1000 AD)**  
The French learned advanced fruit-growing techniques from the Romans, which were further developed in monasteries. This knowledge, including cider-making, was brought to Britain. One dessert apple, called Decio, was likely introduced by the Roman general, Etio. However, many Roman apple varieties did not thrive in Britain, and Norman varieties soon became more popular. British monks continued to experiment and create new apple types, leading to the apples we have today.

**Medieval Favorites (1200)**  
By the thirteenth century, several apple varieties were established in Britain. The Old English Pearmain, noted in 1204 for its pear-like shape, was the main dessert apple until the eighteenth century. The Costard was a popular cooking apple sold in Oxford markets from 1296 until the late seventeenth century, giving rise to the term 'costermonger,' which means a street seller of fruits and vegetables. However, the country faced challenges like droughts, the Black Death, and the Wars of the Roses, leading to fewer apples being produced and more being imported. This changed in the sixteenth century when King Henry VIII sent his chief fruit expert, Richard Harris, to France to learn about apple cultivation. Harris returned with many apple grafts, including the famous Pippins, and established the first modern orchard in Teynham, Kent.

**Settler Treasures (1750)**  
By the seventeenth century, apples were so popular in Britain that the first settlers to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand took apples and seeds with them, considering them precious. Captain Bligh of the Bounty brought the first apples to Australia, Jan van Riebeeck took them to South Africa, and the Pilgrim Fathers carried them to America. In North America, the well-known apple planter was John Chapman, known as 'Johnny Appleseed.' Born in 1774, he planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. Native Americans viewed him as a medicine man, and his love for apple trees and unique clothing inspired many folktales.

**Modern Delicious (1850)**  
Around this time, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt in Iowa discovered a new apple tree growing from the roots of a dead tree. He named this apple 'Hawkey.' After presenting it at a fruit show, a judge exclaimed it was 'Delicious!' In 1895, this apple was introduced to the market as 'Delicious' and became one of the most widely grown apples globally.

**Granny Smith (1850)**  
Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was found in Australia by Maria Anne Smith, the daughter of convicts. She was independent and worked as a midwife in Eastwood, New South Wales. Known as 'Granny Smith,' she managed the family farm and orchard. In 1868, she discovered a small tree growing from discarded fruit. She transplanted it and soon harvested the first major crop of green apples, which became famous worldwide. When asked about the tree's origin, she remarked that it was typical of God to create something valuable from what we consider waste, reflecting both the apple and her own background.

**Uniformity Issues (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown worldwide, from northern India to Africa. However, most commercial apples come from just a few varieties, often chosen for their appearance or durability rather than taste. This trend of uniformity is dulling our taste and reducing genetic diversity. While amateur gardeners in the UK have preserved many old apple varieties, the US has lost most of its apples from a century ago. Fortunately, consumers are beginning to seek more variety. We cannot rely solely on amateur gardeners to preserve diversity in apples or other foods. We must advocate for a world that values and protects natural diversity for everyone's benefit.

Richard Nerurkar, a top long-distance runner from Britain, visits a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. Located ten miles south of the equator, a beautiful mountain path leads from a quiet road in Nairobi to Mount Kenya, the highest peak in the country. This stunning but remote place, called Nanyuk, has been my training base during the winter for the past three years. However, I had never trained with Kenyan runners until my recent trip. 

On this fourth winter training trip, I decided to change my routine. I participated in my first race in Kenya, where the air is thin, and I stayed at the national team training camp, where the best Kenyan runners prepare for the World Cross-Country Team Championships. I received an invitation from the national team coach after finishing fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race, behind three Kenyans and a Moroccan. It was an opportunity I could not miss. 

Training at high altitudes increases the number of red blood cells in the body, which helps carry more oxygen. This has contributed to the success of many Kenyan runners. My first race in Africa, which took place in Nairobi, was also significant because it was the first international cross-country race held on the continent. It was a humbling experience for me, as 41 runners finished ahead of me, and only three were not Kenyan. Despite this, I felt I had performed well.

However, I believe that Kenyan runners' success is not solely due to the altitude. They have a straightforward and enjoyable approach to running. Their running style appears effortless, their diet is simple, and they seem to genuinely enjoy competing. One important aspect of their success is their training methods, which I learned about during my time at the training camp.

The national team camp is located at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up the southern slope of Mount Kenya, surrounded by beautiful fields and lush vegetation. The facilities are basic, with athletes living in shared dormitories with college students. Their daily routine includes three workouts: a relaxed morning run, interval training in the late morning, and a steady run in the afternoon. Each day starts at six in the morning, with a briefing from the coaches. We were reminded to take it easy during the morning run because a tough workout awaited us later. 

On average, we covered about 40 kilometers each day, which is just under a marathon distance. Sundays were easier, with only one scheduled run of 20 kilometers. Life at the camp was simple. Pre-breakfast routines involved just splashing water on our faces and brushing our teeth. Breakfast consisted of tea, bread, and boiled eggs in a small dining area. Lunch and dinner were similar, featuring ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After our runs, we would drive to a stream fed by the melting glaciers of Mount Kenya for a proper wash.

By the end of my stay, I gained a deeper understanding of why Kenyan runners are so successful. Their achievements cannot be explained by genetics, upbringing, or altitude alone. I began to think that the simplicity of their mountain lifestyle, their intense training, and their passion for running might be the true reasons behind Kenya's dominance in long-distance running.

**The Challenges of Mass Marketing**

As many people know, advertising is struggling. This issue is not just due to the recession; advertising began to decline in early 1989, before the recession really affected the economy. The problems with advertising are deeper and are happening globally. The sad reality is that advertising has not adapted to the fast changes in the economy. Advertisers often think about large audiences and mass media, but as brands and media options have increased, target audiences have become more diverse. Even campaigns for well-known brands should focus on smaller groups, but they usually do not. This is a major reason why advertising is not effective.
