Consider your own shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands, and you may buy several of the same brand. In total, you probably only purchase a few advertised brands from the thousands available in the store. Over a year, you are unlikely to buy more than a few hundred different brands. For durable goods, you might buy about a dozen each year, and for cars, you typically buy one every three years. You may not buy many clothes either, and most of them are not from advertised brands. Even when you consider all the different products and services, it is likely that you do not buy more than 400 different brands in a year. 

In contrast, there are about 32,500 branded goods and services that are advertised. If we focus on the 9,500 brands that are actively promoted, the average person only buys about 400 of them, which is roughly 4 percent. This challenges the common belief that half of advertising is wasted; in reality, it could be that 96 percent of advertising is wasted, but no one knows which part is effective. 

When you watch TV, try to count how many commercials are for brands you actually buy or might buy in the future. Most people find that only about 6 percent of the ads are relevant to them, meaning that 94 percent of the commercials are likely wasted. Many people believe they are not influenced by advertising, but the truth is that most people do not buy the brands they see advertised. 

Waste is a natural part of advertising through media. The idea that every person who sees an ad will rush to buy the product is unrealistic. People only remember a small number of ads and ignore the rest, so some waste is unavoidable. However, this does not mean that advertising is not effective. Many ads have shown that they can work. Advertisers need to reach a large audience to connect with the smaller group that will respond, as they cannot predict who will be interested in their products.

Even with careful targeting, advertisers cannot eliminate waste completely. For example, even the best direct mail campaigns do not get a 100 percent response rate. This is a key difference between advertising through media and personal selling. A salesperson might successfully sell to every potential customer they meet, but this is not possible with media advertising. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they would communicate with them directly instead of using mass media.

Any advertiser who can attract one million new customers, which is about 2 percent of the adult population, is considered successful. For popular products like soap powder, the top brands would be thrilled to gain a million new customers. Therefore, any advertising campaign that can reach more than 2 percent of the population is seen as very successful, and this represents a small portion of the overall audience. While mass media can be an effective way to reach these customers, for advertising to improve, it must focus on more specific target audiences than ever before.

**Solar Survivor: Charles Clover Explores Britain's Most Eco-Friendly Home**

Charles Clover visits a unique home in Southwell, Nottinghamshire, known for its environmental friendliness. This area is home to Southwell Minster, an ancient cathedral famous for its carvings of 'green' men made by medieval craftsmen. The second surprise is the 'autonomous house,' built by Robert and Brenda Vale, which is considered the greenest home in Britain.

The Vales have created a house that uses rainwater for drinking and washing, recycles sewage into compost, and heats the home using waste heat from appliances and their own body heat, along with that of their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house, which looks traditional with its clay tile roof, is located 300 yards from the Minster and blends in with the local architecture. It was approved by planners even though it is in a conservation area.

When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, you will notice complete silence. The house is extremely well-insulated, with special windows that keep out noise. Inside, it feels peaceful, especially on a sunny summer day when the windows are closed and the conservatory warms the air. Robert shows how the house has clever ventilation systems to create airflow, as it is designed to be airtight. Even the cats have their own small air-locked door.

The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have been committed to environmental issues since the 1970s when they wrote a book called *The Autonomous House*. They aimed to create a building that produced no carbon dioxide and eventually decided to eliminate the need for mains water. They installed composting toilets, rainwater tanks, and special gutters to keep drinking water clean, filtering it before use. They also let water from washing flow into the garden, as they do not use a dishwasher due to their beliefs about strong detergents.

Robert explains that they want to show that it is possible to design a house that is much less harmful to the environment without sacrificing comfort. The only medieval feature of the house is its design, with a hall that reaches the full height of the building. The Vales do not pay water bills, and last winter, their electricity usage was only nine units a day, costing about 70p, which is much less than typical four-bedroom homes.

Soon, they will install solar panels worth £20,000 in the garden, which will allow the house to generate more electricity than it uses. They will still draw some electricity from the mains for cooking and appliances, but they expect to have enough surplus to charge an electric car in the future. The only source of heating is a small wood-burning stove, which they rarely use except during the coldest days.

When Clover visited in February, Robert mentioned it was too warm to light the fire, with the first-floor temperature at 18°C, which is comfortable despite being lower than usual. He explains that comfort depends on factors like insulation and the absence of drafts. He compares this to an Edwardian woman who felt comfortable at 12.5°C due to her clothing. He suggests that people living in older homes should adapt to similar conditions, though this idea may not be popular.

The house's success lies in its simplicity and low-tech design, using materials from local builders and craftsmen, making it affordable to build. This approach has faced resistance from commercial building companies, who are not keen on this model.

**The Camera Never Lies**

Arthur Conan Doyle, the writer of the Sherlock Holmes stories, considered himself a rational person and even a scientist. However, in 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden and believed they were real evidence of these tiny creatures. He published these photos with an article, accepting fairies as supernatural beings. It was not until 1939 that the two women who took the photos confessed they were fake. They had simply cut out images of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos are undeniably beautiful, but the simplicity of the trick challenges a fundamental idea about photography: that the camera cannot lie. In reality, it can, and it always has. Nowadays, we often use computer software to edit our digital images, and it is a misconception that photography ever had a time when it was completely honest. From the very beginning, when cameras started capturing images, those images were being changed.

**Blacksmiths**

Throughout history, iron has captured human imagination, and blacksmiths, who work with it, have often been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths held a respected position, similar to doctors and astrologers, as they were the only ones who made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral, and the elegant metal designs in French and Belgian Art Nouveau architecture were crafted by talented blacksmiths.

However, by the late 1960s, the number of blacksmiths in Britain had greatly decreased because heavy industry no longer needed their skills, and modern architects rarely used the beautiful wrought iron features. In the last ten years, there has been a revival of interest in decorative architecture and a more open approach to interior design. Still, much of the new work seems repetitive, with manufacturers labeling their products as "classical" or "Victorian-style." You can find trendy design stores filled with rusty candlesticks and similar items.

Fortunately, there are new opportunities for blacksmiths, and several events in the coming weeks aim to promote their craft. The first event is an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA), which opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, believes we might be entering a new Iron Age, as both the public and blacksmiths are becoming more aware of the craft. Modern power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to shape metal without the hard labor of the past. Dawson explains that these artists now have the tools to express their creativity.

The exhibition features about 250 pieces, including bookends and a spiral staircase, with prices starting at £90 and going up to several thousand pounds. Most of the money will go to the individual artists, but a portion will be kept by the Association to promote quality ironwork. Dawson's own contributions include an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a hand-blown glass shade. He describes his style as allowing steel to bend and take shape when heated, comparing it to drawing with metal in space.

Many artists are drawn to iron because it is a challenging material. Unlike other metals that are easier to shape when cold, iron and steel require more skill. Susan May, a trained jeweler, finds it magical that iron is soft when hot but becomes hard and unyielding when it cools. Ann Catrin Evans creates mild steel door knockers and handles inspired by the dark castles often seen in horror films. One of her designs resembles a ball and chain, while another looks like a Celtic cross. She appreciates the cold, hard nature of steel and its permanence.

No other metal has provided as much visual enjoyment or a sense of security as iron. It is likely that iron will continue to be used decoratively for many years to come, as long as we can avoid more rusty candlesticks.

**The Day I Gave Up Smoking**

I thought everyone would be happy when I quit smoking, but one of my colleagues was very angry. She shouted, "What do you mean? If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I found it hard to explain how I went from being a heavy smoker to not smoking at all in just a few hours. It was a bit annoying, and I still find it strange. 

The session I attended to stop smoking was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy, and it happened two months and three weeks ago. I hadn’t planned to quit, and I didn’t really want to. I felt pressured by anti-smoking groups, which I still resent. Plus, I had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn’t cough or feel sick, and I seemed to recover from colds faster than my friends who lived healthier lifestyles.

On that ordinary Thursday afternoon, I went to a session in Birmingham called The Easy Way to Stop Smoking to write an article about others trying to quit. I clearly stated, "I won’t be trying to stop; I’m here to write, not to quit, so it wouldn’t be fair to expect your method to work on me." I felt very reasonable because I genuinely enjoyed smoking; it brought me real pleasure.

The counsellor seemed to understand me. We were encouraged to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn’t want to, and neither did the others. I think the messages about stopping smoking started to make sense to me. Just as smoking had become a challenge against opposition, the idea of quitting began to feel appealing. The thought of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a personal feeling, unrelated to anyone else. Could I also achieve other things?

In many ways, quitting was easy. The physical cravings for nicotine, similar to hunger, faded after a minute or two and lasted only four or five days. I thought my work would be the hardest part without cigarettes, but it turned out to be fine. I had believed I wouldn’t be able to meet deadlines without nicotine and that I would fail to write a story. Surprisingly, the hardest part was just relaxing at home on weekend mornings, and it still is. 

I’ve come to realize that smoking helped me deal with boredom; having a cigarette was an activity in itself. Yes, I do miss smoking, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is something I have to adjust to—eating out, waiting for a flight, checking into a hotel, or during a theatre intermission. These are all moments when I would have previously smoked.

**Dorothy Who?**

Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, yet many people in Britain do not know her name. For the past four years, I have been testing my friends to see if they recognize her. When I tell them I am writing her biography, if they respond with excitement, they pass the test. 

Why should people in Britain know about Dorothy Hodgkin? She deserves recognition simply because she is the only British woman to win a Nobel Prize in science. If someone had the same achievement in literature, they would be famous. Hodgkin, who passed away in 1994, was an extraordinary person, much like the complex crystals she studied. Her life reflects significant changes in the 20th century, including the progress of women's education and the globalization of science.

When I started my research, I wanted to read scientific biographies. A friend of Hodgkin suggested a biography of Linus Pauling, who was a close friend and worked in the same field. I went to a local bookstore, but I found that there were no biographies of Pauling available. I was surprised that Pauling, a highly influential chemist and Nobel Prize winner, was not considered interesting enough for British readers. 

Even scientists sometimes think that biographies of scientists are not engaging. Peter Medawar, a Nobel laureate, once said that the lives of scientists are often dull. If scientists believe this, it is not surprising that publishers and booksellers do too. This attitude reflects a common belief that there is a big gap between the arts and sciences, which still exists in literature. Only a few famous scientists make it into biography sections of bookstores. 

It is not true that scientists lead less interesting lives than artists, writers, or politicians. Some scientists are very careful about their public image. For example, a well-known geneticist said he would be happy to discuss his work but did not want to be quoted or photographed because he did not want to seem like he was promoting himself. This reluctance to share personal stories can create a false image of science and may discourage young people from pursuing scientific careers.

Fortunately, this is changing. Nowadays, scientists often appear in public in ways other than just scientific interviews. For instance, Professor Richard Dawkins presents awards on a TV quiz show, and geneticist Steve Jones appears in car commercials. These activities help make scientists more relatable to the public.

The publishing world is also changing. Scientific biographies used to be dry and overly respectful, often ignoring the personal lives of scientists. This changed with Richard Feynman's book, "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman?", which is both funny and touching. Recently, even famous scientists like Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Albert Einstein, and Marie Curie have been portrayed with their flaws on display. Readers find it interesting to see how creative geniuses deal with personal challenges, even if those challenges seem unrelated to their scientific work.

Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her research. She made significant discoveries, including the structures of penicillin and vitamin B12, which earned her the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1964, and insulin, which her team solved in 1969. She achieved these successes by pushing scientific techniques to new limits. However, she also balanced her career with her family life, raising three children and being married to a husband who was often away for work. While her personal life may not directly relate to her scientific achievements, it shows her ability to integrate different aspects of her life.

There is much in Hodgkin's life that is universally interesting, but it is important to recognize her scientific contributions as well. Scientific inquiry was her passion, as it must be for any successful scientist. The challenge for biographers is to convey this passion effectively. Many readers may not have the scientific background to understand complex ideas without extensive explanation. However, understanding science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just requires effort.

It is unfortunate that educated people who would feel embarrassed for not knowing a famous literary figure often remain unaware of the rich legacy of scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin.

**Margaret and Her Water-Finding Skills**

Margaret Wilkins is known for her unique ability to find water. She uses a forked hazel stick to detect underground water sources. Farmers whose wells have dried up often seek her help. Along with her husband, she runs a well-drilling business that uses modern equipment like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. However, when it comes to finding water, she relies solely on her hazel stick. The couple has a success rate of over 90%.

This skill, known as dowsing, involves locating water, minerals, and lost items underground. There are various theories about how dowsing works, ranging from physical explanations like magnetism to spiritual beliefs. One of the more believable theories suggests that everything on Earth vibrates, with water vibrating more than other substances. It is thought that dowsers can sense these vibrations while standing on the ground. Some dowsers claim they can "feel" water, while others say they can "smell" it, as smell is a very sensitive sense.

In recent years of drought, Margaret has been very busy, sometimes having a waiting list of nearly six weeks. Most of her clients are farmers with dry wells, as wells typically last a long time, meaning she only sees each customer once. Other clients include owners of remote cottages or barns, which are now used as holiday homes, where installing long water pipes is too costly. There are also golf course developers who need water for their clubhouses.

Margaret usually looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She emphasizes that wells cannot be drilled where there is a risk of contamination from waste. The water she finds is usually in cracks in solid rock, and if it is brought up correctly, it should be clean. However, in Cornwall, where they work, there are many minerals, so they must be cautious about iron in the water. Additionally, electricity is needed to run the pump, which can be expensive if the well is far from power sources.

To begin her search for water, Margaret first studies a map of the area and uses a pendulum. She holds the pendulum still and moves it over the map; it swings when she is above a water source. After identifying potential areas on the map, she walks over the land with her hazel stick, which is forked and equal in size on both sides. When she is above water, she feels a strange sensation and sways slightly. Once this feeling passes, she uses the stick to find the exact drilling spot.

Holding the two forks of the stick, she pulls them slightly apart to create tension. If water is directly below, the straight part of the stick will rise. It is crucial to drill exactly where the stick indicates; even a small mistake can mean missing the water entirely. Margaret and her husband often dowse the same area, and they usually agree on where to drill. If they disagree, they will continue searching until they reach a consensus.

Margaret's skills are not just a local tradition; they have intrigued anthropologists and writers for a long time. She describes her ability as an "intuitive perception of the environment," which is the best way to explain how she finds water so accurately. Without this "sixth sense," it would be difficult for her family to sustain their well-drilling business year after year.

**We Changed Lives for a Day!**

Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? It might be exciting to try something completely different. We arranged this for four people - here’s what happened.

**Amanda's Story**

Amanda, 23, is a young mother with two daughters. She swapped lives with her friend Cindy, 30, who works as a waitress in a fancy London restaurant. 

Amanda had never been in a place like that before. It was dark, loud, and crowded, which was very different from her hometown. She felt nervous and overwhelmed. Being a mother is busy, but waitressing was a whole new challenge! She had only fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks. The other waitresses made it look easy, but when she tried, the drinks slipped off the tray and spilled everywhere. She felt embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed and reassured her that everyone makes mistakes at first.

By 11:30 am, a line of customers was waiting outside, and Amanda felt anxious about remembering their orders. Luckily, the ordering system was automated, so that was one less worry. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and she struggled to hear customers over the loud music. She often had to ask them to repeat themselves, which was embarrassing. By the end of her shift at 5 pm, she was exhausted and just wanted to soak her feet in hot water. One waitress told her it had been a "quiet" day, which surprised Amanda. She realized waitressing was much harder than she thought. She used to think it was an easy job, but it actually requires a friendly personality and the ability to handle a busy environment. Amanda felt too shy to work on a Saturday night when it would be even busier. She was also disappointed with the tips she received, especially from wealthy customers. In the end, she was happy to return to her children, as being a mother felt much easier after her day as a waitress.

**Cindy's Story**

Cindy, who is 30, was nervous about being a mother for a day, but she was also excited. She had heard that Amanda's daughters could be mischievous, but she thought she could manage. 

After Amanda left for the restaurant, Cindy had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, she thought she would have three hours of peace. But she was wrong! A note from Amanda reminded her that she still had to make the beds, clean the house, and do the laundry. 

At 1 pm, Cindy picked up Katie, quickly shopped at the supermarket, and took her home for lunch. However, when she brought Sophie home from school, things got chaotic. The girls turned the couch into a trampoline and played a loud game. Cindy tried to stay calm, thinking they would tire out soon, but they had more energy than she expected! After much effort, she finally got them to bed by 8 pm, but then the real challenge began. The girls kept asking for glasses of water, which was just a trick to get them downstairs to watch TV. Cindy found it exhausting to negotiate with them all evening. She realized that taking care of two small children was much more tiring than she had imagined. There was no time to think about herself, and the responsibility felt overwhelming. Despite the challenges, she enjoyed the day.

**Rosemary's Story**

Rosemary, 42, runs a dairy farm. She swapped lives with Hilary, 30, a primary school teacher. 

On the farm, Rosemary wakes up at 5:30 am, so sleeping in until 7 am felt luxurious! She was unsure how to dress for school and hoped she wouldn’t stand out. At assembly, she faced about 400 students and hoped to blend in. 

In math class, the children worked in small groups, which was different from her own school experience. She helped with a nature project, identifying and feeding snails. By lunchtime, she was tired and looked forward to a break, but teachers only have about five minutes to eat. There was so much to do before classes resumed. She attended a staff meeting and ended up helping with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson, which she enjoyed, followed by a French lesson where the children practiced on her, revealing her rusty French skills. Finally, they had Physical Education, and by then, she was exhausted, while the children seemed full of energy. Speaking in front of the class was the hardest part for her. Although teachers have more holidays, she decided she preferred farming.

**Hilary's Story**

Hilary arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, only to find that Rosemary had been working for three hours already! Rosemary's farm is large, with 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves, and about 800 sheep. She also makes ice cream, yogurt, and cream for sale.

Hilary spent most of the morning in the ice cream shop, bottling milk and making ice cream. It was hard not to taste the treats! At lunchtime, she checked on the sheep and helped a ewe that had fallen over. If sheep are not helped within 12 hours, they can die, so daily checks are essential. 

After feeding the calves, Hilary started milking, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, every day of the year! Hilary found the day lonely and missed the children, as animals don’t talk back. The hardest part of farming is the constant work; cows must be milked twice daily, making it hard to take time off. Rosemary only gets about three days of vacation each year. Farming may seem romantic, but the reality is very different. The income is unstable, and she wouldn’t want to rely on the weather.

A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It is interesting how many successful musicians come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of non-musical parents in a rural area of southern Sweden, has become a remarkable trumpet player by the age of 30. His recordings introduce new music, including concertos by lesser-known composers from the baroque and classical periods, as well as new compositions. When you meet him, he appears youthful and energetic, reflecting the lively sound of the trumpet. Recently, he performed the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London's top concert halls, and a television feature was made about his career, filmed in both London and Sweden.

Hardenberger was born near Malmo and began his musical journey with a Christmas gift when he was eight years old. His father, who did not play music but enjoyed Louis Armstrong, decided to give his son a real trumpet instead of a toy. The gift was a success, and the boy played constantly. His mother arranged for him to take lessons from the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra, Bo Nilsson, who recognized Hardenberger's natural talent. Hardenberger is grateful to have had such a dedicated teacher from the beginning, someone who was passionate about the trumpet and always seeking new ways to improve.

Hardenberger explains that the trumpet is a simple instrument, and it is impossible to create a perfect one. There will always be some flaws, and no two mouthpieces are identical. He believes it is important to understand these imperfections and learn to work with them. From the start, he had a unique sound that was recognizable, which he considers his first achievement. Unlike John Wallace, a prominent British trumpet player who started in brass bands and orchestras, Hardenberger has always seen himself as a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre and collected his records. His parents supported his ambition to pursue a career in trumpet playing.

At 15, it was time to decide where he would study. Although Bo Nilsson suggested America, it was considered too far and risky, so at 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud reinforced Hardenberger's belief that playing in an orchestra was not for him, comparing it to gardening. Hardenberger knew he played better than many of his peers, but it was only after entering a competition at 17 that he realized he had a special ability to connect with the audience. Thibaud encouraged him to participate for experience. Hardenberger prepared for the first round and advanced to the second, where he was familiar with most pieces. However, in the final round, he faced a challenging concerto that had intimidated him before. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed the performance and realized that even when he felt he played poorly, people were still engaged.

Hardenberger's honest view of his talent might seem arrogant, but that is not the case. He thoughtfully avoids analyzing what makes his communication with the audience special, believing that trying to explain it could diminish its power. He feels that the true strength of music lies in its ability to move people.

**New In Paperback**

A. The story of Tristan Smith, a citizen in the made-up republic of Efica, is a remarkable tale about human power, history, and humor. The author skillfully creates a world with its own history, traditions, and customs. The book is also known for its humor and the author's unique perspective, combined with deep psychological insights, making it a challenging but rewarding read.

B. Harriet is a composed, middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not have met Sheila, a traditional working-class woman who cares for her elderly father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change dramatically when Leo violently attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to discuss what happened. Leo, who had always been a good student and never fought before, cannot explain his actions, while Joe, although physically recovering, becomes withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by her son's situation, and caring for him consumes her life. Sheila feels so guilty that she asks to meet Harriet, leading to an unexpected friendship. The author excels at showing how people respond to major changes in their lives and captures the mother's feeling that she can never do enough for her son.

C. This book, shortlisted for the Booker Prize, tells the story of one of the most isolated Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long, quiet history. The narrative is set against important moments in Scottish history, vividly imagined through the daydreams of the young protagonist, Throfinn Ragnarson. He suddenly disappears from the story but returns after World War II, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.

D. After his recent success, the author has written a sequel filled with the same gentle irony and sharp observations of family life that made the first book popular. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway approaches her seventies with her lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's outlook on life remains a mix of vanity, charm, and reluctant kindness, while Rosie supports her in her entertaining manipulation of friends and suitors. By the end of the book, Aurora must face the passage of time and the arrival of a new generation. The author skillfully reveals the underlying sadness in everyday life, focusing more on the shadows than the bright moments.

E. Six very different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful descriptive language to explore the personal journeys of self-discovery that each sailor experiences, returning home with renewed spirits after their time adrift on "the desert cities of waves." The author employs striking images to express themes of memory and awareness, which can be both isolating and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps meets five women who share their experiences in different professions, discussing the positives, negatives, and their daily routines.

**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  

**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7:00 am, and arrive at work by 8:00 am to start surgeries at 8:30 am. I perform surgeries all day on Mondays and Wednesdays, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most brain surgeries last about three hours, but some can take all day. There have been times when I’ve worked for ten hours straight without a break. Deciding when to operate can be stressful. While I don’t feel stressed during surgery, I sometimes worry about the next day’s tasks. Brain surgery is often a last option for patients, but when it succeeds, it is incredibly rewarding, making up for the times it doesn’t. From 10:00 am to 1:00 pm, I run an out-patients' clinic where I explain procedures to patients. I enjoy this and find it easy to communicate with them, although time constraints can make it challenging. I usually leave work between 6:00 pm and 8:00 pm. I am on call some nights and weekends, always carrying my bleeper. During holidays, I often worry about my patients for the first few days and dream about surgeries at night. I struggle to relax."

**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  

**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, and take the train to work, arriving at 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to discuss our projects and any issues. I work in a team of three senior designers, a partner, and a junior designer. My work is mostly about production, with only 10-15% being actual design. I receive a brief from the client, and if they have clear ideas, I spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After that, I present my ideas to the client. Once they approve, we create estimates and budgets, and I start hiring photographers and illustrators. I also coordinate with printers to ensure everything is done on time. Managing multiple projects can be very stressful, and deadlines are always tight. Lunch is at 1:00 pm for an hour, but I often work through it with sandwiches. It feels great when clients appreciate my designs, but it’s disappointing when they reject my hard work. I usually get home by 7:30 pm, but it can be much later. I find it hard to relax after a busy day."

**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  

**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I usually wake up around 7:00 am, but on days when I meet long-haul flights, I get up between 4:30 am and 5:00 am. I might go for a bike ride or swim around 10:30 or 11:00 am. Since chauffeuring is a sedentary job, I pay attention to my diet and exercise. I have a big breakfast and snack throughout the day. Clients often ask for recommendations for restaurants or shops, so I need to know the area well. Many jobs are pre-booked, allowing me to plan my routes. While most passengers are polite, some can be rude. I have built good relationships with my regular clients. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, so I must be careful not to get too tired. I try to go to bed by 11:00 pm."

**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  

**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up around 7:00 am, leave home by 7:30 am, and start my first job. My assistant and I mainly maintain gardens we designed. We do some commercial work, but most is in private gardens, spending about an hour and a half at each location. Around 11:00 am, we take a break for a big breakfast at a local café. In summer, I may work until 10:00 pm, and in winter until 4:30 pm. I run the business from home, so when I return, I check messages and return calls. If someone wants a new garden design, I usually schedule a consultation in the evening. We focus on using old materials to create gardens that look historic. Sometimes clients have specific ideas that aren’t appealing. However, it’s very rewarding to see a garden we designed bloom. I find it hard to relax in the evenings because I can hear the business phone. I sleep well because my job is physically demanding, leaving me exhausted at the end of the day."

**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  

**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the construction site by 8:30 am. As the assistant resident engineer, I oversee the building of bridges and a retaining wall. I ensure that contractors follow the schedule and safety guidelines while minimizing environmental impact. I coordinate with site professionals and solve problems as they arise. The contractors start work at 6:00 am, so my first task is to check in with the clerk of works about what happened overnight. The rest of my day involves responding to their updates, reviewing paperwork, and answering design questions. I usually take a half-hour lunch between 2:00 pm and 2:30 pm, but I often eat on the go. Since we monitor the contractors' work, it can lead to conflicts, so maintaining a good relationship is crucial. I see the duty resident engineer once a day, but I act immediately if something urgent arises. I typically leave the site around 6:00 pm and am always on call."

**Careers: Six People Discuss Their Typical Workday**

**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am to reach the office by 7:30 am. My job involves managing customer development programs for our credit card users. I launch and oversee the Membership Rewards scheme in major European markets. I maintain contact with current card users, attract new ones, and build partnerships with companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and then respond to emails. I handle advertising for the membership program across Europe, meeting with marketing staff and advertising agencies to create strategies and plan future projects. I have many meetings throughout the day, but I keep my door open for anyone who has questions. I travel to different markets in Europe once or twice a week to address any issues. When I’m in London, I usually leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**  
I arrive at work by 10:00 am and start by reviewing the mail, which includes ten to twenty demo tapes daily, letters from producers, concert information, and invoices from musicians and studios. The phone starts ringing around 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers, and I have meetings throughout the day to discuss campaigns or projects for artists. When I listen to demo tapes, I know that these represent people's hard work, so I aim to provide constructive feedback. I can tell if the sound fits our record label. Once I sign a band, we begin working on their first album, selecting songs, producers, and additional musicians. I also share my vision for the album with the marketing team. I manage budgets and expenses. I leave work by 7:00 pm at the earliest, and I often attend concerts in the evenings, sometimes seeing up to five new bands in one night. After a concert, I might visit an artist in the studio. Most of my social life revolves around my work, and I often don’t get home until 1:00 am, when I listen to a record to relax.

**C. Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I check the mail, look at my schedule for client meetings, and see who shows up. I enjoy showing customers around the showroom and love making sales, knowing the furniture will go to a good home. We sell antiques priced between £1,000 and £6,000, sourcing them from auctions, private clients, and overseas. Many items need restoration, so I work closely with our full-time restorer and other specialists. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette while drinking coffee to stay updated on the industry and often visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I handle the accounts once a month and do tax returns every three months. I leave work at 5:30 pm, and it usually takes me about an hour to unwind.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I work on a set shift schedule. On early shifts, I leave home at 6:00 am. I start my shift at 7:00 am, taking over one of the control positions in the tower. We have a rotating schedule, working about an hour and a half at one station, then taking a half-hour break before switching to another station. The air traffic controllers, a supervisor, and the watch manager work closely together to manage aircraft movements. In winter, we handle around 1,000 movements daily, and even more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, allowing me to read about new air traffic regulations between 12:00 am and 4:00 am. This job requires full attention, so if I feel unwell, I don’t hesitate to take a sick day. The work can be stressful, and it takes time to relax after a shift. I hope to become a watch manager and eventually the general manager of the airport.

**E. Shop Manager**  
If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8:00 am. My first task is to start the electronic point-of-sale system. I ensure someone is at the till and coordinate lunch breaks for staff. In the morning, I assist customers in finding and ordering books. I enjoy helping customers, although it can be frustrating when they come in with reviews and expect me to gather many books quickly. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm on weekdays, publishers’ representatives visit, and I discuss upcoming titles with them. I need to estimate how many copies of a new title we might sell. When we want to feature a new title, I ensure it arrives on time. My early shift ends at 5:45 pm. Two days a week, I work a late shift, during which I shut down the computer system, lock up, and go home.

**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work, arriving by 8:45 am. I contact freelance reporters to learn about events in my region. I assess financial risks for multinational companies operating abroad, warning clients about potential issues. I provide three services: an online executive preview, a security forecast, and a travel information security guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss the stories I will follow. My first executive preview must be online by 10:00 am, and my second by 11:00 am, so I work quickly to gather information. I write the stories, send them to my editor for approval, and make any necessary changes before they are published. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on specific events and stay updated. I usually leave work around 6:00 pm, and it can be hard to relax afterward; I often find myself awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: Take Charge of Your Work Life**

A. **What Makes a Good Leader?**  
A good leader inspires others, drives change, and guides people towards a common goal. Leadership is not about physical traits like height, nor is it just about being smart. According to Pat Dixon, author of *Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace*, leadership is about getting things done through enthusiastic and engaged people. A key part of being a good leader is being able to express your ideas clearly and confidently. Dixon emphasizes that a leader should say "I believe" instead of "I think."

B. John van Maurik, who directs a Leadership in Management course, believes that most people have more leadership potential than they realize. Becoming a leader involves recognizing and developing your hidden talents. In a way, we are all born with the ability to lead; we just need the right environment to grow. While it’s easy to see leadership in famous figures like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, it can be harder to see it in our own workplaces. However, leadership is now seen as essential for effective management.

C. Think about the best and worst boss you’ve had. They might have been equally good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve those goals? A good leader motivates and supports you, while a bad leader makes you feel unimportant and withholds information. The good leader leads effectively, while the bad leader simply manages poorly.

D. Leaders and managers are different. Managers prefer to work within established limits, while leaders create new possibilities. Micheal Shea, author of *Leadership Rules*, states that a good manager can keep a struggling company running, but a good leader can revitalize a discouraged organization, whether it’s a business, a sports team, or a country.

E. Whether you are the boss or a middle manager, improving your leadership skills can be beneficial. Here are some important lessons:  
- Leadership works best when you choose to lead. Discover your passions and values. When you feel inspired, use that energy to take action.  
- Start seeing yourself as a leader. Your ability to lead is a valuable part of who you are.  
- Collaboration is important, but sometimes strong leadership is necessary. Try different leadership styles. If you usually negotiate, take the lead instead. Notice how this changes the results.  
- Set goals and strive to exceed them. Identify areas in your job where being a leader can improve your effectiveness and career opportunities.

F. Leadership doesn’t just happen; it develops through taking initiative, taking risks, and learning from mistakes. Learn to delegate, motivate, organize, and provide feedback.  
- Don’t assume your leadership style will automatically win over your colleagues; it might even push them away. Keep improving your communication skills. You don’t need to be liked, but your ideas and achievements should be respected.  
- Be visible and approachable to those who matter. Remember, you don’t have to lead all the time. Understand when your leadership is crucial and how you can help others grow as leaders.

**Films on Video: Reviews by Film Critic Nick James**

**A. Abyss**  
Before "Titanic," director James Cameron created a tense Cold War thriller about oil workers and navy experts trying to save a nuclear submarine trapped deep underwater. The interactions and modest bravery of foreman Bud and his team remind us of similar heroes in Howard Hawks' films. The film's design and special effects are outstanding, but the dialogue and character development are lacking. Despite the skilled filmmaking, the story feels like a typical B-movie.

**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This video release of the James Jones novel about the Guadalcanal battle, directed by Andrew Marton, offers a different perspective compared to Terrence Malick's recent film. While Malick's version is mystical and poetic, Marton's is more traditional, focusing on a single soldier and his difficult relationship with his tough sergeant. Malick's film is richer and more complex, but Marton's version has its strong moments, especially a flashback where the soldier dreams of his wife, which is portrayed more harshly than Malick's softer imagery.

**C. On Guard**  
This entertaining swashbuckler, loosely based on Paul Feval's 1875 novel, stands out among musketeer adventures. Fabrice Luchini plays a cunning villain, while Vincent Perez is a lively hero, even if his role is brief. Daniel Auteuil, though perhaps too serious for a light-hearted film, also shines as an acrobat-turned-swordsman. The filmmakers use familiar costume-drama clichés with such charm and energy that it doesn't feel tiresome.

**D. Character**  
Set in early 20th-century Rotterdam, this film tells a somber story. The detailed production and costumes make it look like a historical exhibit. Jan Decleir portrays the harsh bailiff Dreverhaven, who is ruthless in evicting tenants. His troubled relationship with his son is central to the plot, but the filmmakers focus too much on period details, neglecting the dark and powerful story.

**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This newly remastered video release highlights director Leone's skill, especially in sound editing, where every sound is clear. The storytelling is harsh, and whenever there is a quiet moment, Morricone's powerful music brings excitement. Morally, there is little difference between the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Ell Wallach), as they all act unscrupulously in the post-Civil War West.

**F. The Longest Day**  
Promoted as featuring "forty-eight international stars," this three-hour war epic by Darryl Zanuck involves four directors and 23,000 extras, making it feel overly ambitious. The early scenes, where battle-hardened veterans wait for news of the invasion, drag on for both the audience and the soldiers. While it is an impressive logistical achievement, it is best experienced on the big screen. The video version loses much of its impact.

**BOOK A**: *Compelling Evidence* by Steve Martin is truly engaging. The story follows a lawyer who is trying to establish his own practice after leaving a prestigious law firm. He unexpectedly ends up defending his boss's wife, who is accused of murdering her husband. The trial scenes are gripping, with uncertainty about the outcome until the very end, and there is a surprising twist in the final pages. This is an impressive debut in a competitive genre.

**BOOK B**: *Curtains for the Cardinal* starts with excitement, introducing Sigismondo, a problem-solver for the Italian Renaissance aristocracy. He gets caught up in a mix of politics, church intrigue, and serious murder, but we are confident he will uncover the truth. The plot is complex, and the book is a bit lengthy, but it remains very enjoyable.

**BOOK C**: *File Under: Deceased* by Sarah Lacey features a unique new detective, Leah Hunter, who works as a tax inspector. She finds herself in a position to investigate when a strange man collapses at her feet. Despite facing criticism and the disapproval of a handsome local detective, Leah proves to be resourceful and impressive.

**BOOK D**: *Double Deuce* by Robert B. Parker follows Spenser, a clever private investigator, as he helps his friend Hawk remove drug dealers from a struggling neighborhood in Boston. The dialogue is sharp and quick, and while there are fewer deaths than usual, the story includes more philosophical elements. Parker consistently delivers high-quality entertainment.

**BOOK E**: *False Prophet* by Faye Kellermann features detectives Pete Decker and Marge Dunn as they investigate a burglary and attack at the home of a famous film star's daughter. The author's straightforward writing style and keen observation of unusual human behavior make this an enjoyable mystery.

**BOOK F**: *Blood Red, Snow White* is written by the husband-and-wife team Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It features another lawyer and a female client, but the action takes place outside the courtroom, leading the lawyer to become a victim as the story unfolds. The novel skillfully combines elements of romance, wealth, and violence to create a captivating suspense story.

**BOOK G**: *Dead for a Ducat* by Simon Shaw introduces actor Philip Fletcher as a potential victim. A humorous cast of characters comes together to film a Robin Hood story, but Philip feels uncertain about the direction of his career. While Shaw usually entertains, this shift from dark comedy to farce does not quite meet his usual high standards.

**BOOK H**: *Fall Down Easy* is Lawrence Gough's best work in a while. It follows Canadian police as they pursue a clever bank robber who targets female tellers. The story builds tension slowly and effectively, and the portrayal of the intelligent, troubled robber elevates it above the typical detective novel.

I might be too old for this adventure, but here I go! At 34, Tim Pozzi has left a good job to go backpacking. He thinks about why he and others his age are making this choice. This summer, I quit my job and decided to rent out my flat to travel in Southeast Asia for a year. You might think I'm lucky, but at 34, I feel nervous. I have traveled before; after university, I spent two years backpacking in North and South America. When I returned, I promised myself I would do it again someday. But then life happened: I fell in love, started a career, bought a flat, and got used to earning a salary. Gradually, I realized I was sacrificing my own happiness for my paycheck. When I handed in my resignation, it felt like I was taking control of my life again. 

Now, I have no ties. Many of my friends are married with children, and while they wouldn’t trade places with me, they envy my freedom. I’m not in a relationship and don’t have strong career ambitions, so I feel I should make the most of this freedom—if only for my friends! But why am I so nervous? First, I need to make all the arrangements. How can I let someone else live in my home? How do I organize the rental? And I still need to decide where to go. I tend to procrastinate and am already behind schedule. I thought, “I might as well enjoy the summer in England,” and then, “Why not wait for the football season to start?” 

Letting go of emotional ties makes it harder. I wonder if I can still handle backpacking. Will I adjust to a simpler way of life? Will I feel out of place among younger backpackers? Maybe not. I’ve noticed that more Britons in their late twenties and thirties want to break free from their established lives and travel abroad. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says there’s a growing realization that adventure is available: “People who always say, ‘I wish I had that opportunity’ are realizing they can have it anytime. They just need to be brave, organized, and confident enough to do it.”

For Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, this trip is a last chance to have fun before settling down. They bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. Danny says, “I’m willing to give up job security for this trip. There’s always a worry that I won’t move up in my career when I return, but I think it’s a risk worth taking. When I left the office, I threw my calculator into the river as a symbolic act of defiance!” 

For Matt, who just left the Army, his year of travel was transformative. “In the military, there’s a strict way of doing things. I needed to change that to live well as a civilian.” While there are many reasons for traveling at this age, some common factors exist. Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development says, “Today’s workforce is more flexible. Many people work on short-term contracts, so if your contract ends, you have nothing to lose.” Larger companies are even allowing career breaks, knowing that trained employees will return instead of going to competitors.

Dan Hiscocks, managing director of Travellerseye, a company that shares stories of ordinary travelers, notes that more thirty-somethings are reassessing their lives. “If you’re unhappy with your job—and many people are—it’s no longer just about sticking it out. People now know that opportunities exist and that a job isn’t for life. Travel allows you to step back and think about your life.” 

Is this desire to travel just another sign that my generation struggles with adulthood? Jennifer Cox disagrees. “It shows a better-educated, more stable society where we care less about paying bills and more about living a balanced life. We’re taking the time to ask, ‘Is this what I want?’” Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher going to Central America for a year, doesn’t think he’s running away. “It’s more about running towards something. I want to pursue my own interests.” However, he does feel some anxiety about leaving behind his comfortable routine of going to the office, greeting everyone, and enjoying a cup of coffee.

I share Ben’s concerns about leaving a structured life with few challenges, and I’m not sure I would be making this journey if I hadn’t found my boss so unbearable. As Jennifer Cox points out, “This is common. There’s often a trigger, like a breakup or job loss, that pushes people to travel.” It may have taken a nudge to get me moving, but I’m now looking forward to the next 12 months with growing excitement. No matter what happens, I’ll take pride in having embraced life fully. I believe many of us older backpackers feel the same way.

**Transforming Home into a Workplace**

Georgina McGuiness took a long break from journalism and felt disconnected from the technological changes in the field. In this piece, she shares how she turned her home into an effective workspace.

The Christmas before last, I turned 37 and realized I needed to revive my journalism career, which I thought was fading away due to technology. Looking at my resume, I saw that I was stuck in the past, using a typewriter, which felt outdated. I worried that no one would trust me with a computer in a newsroom. Many job ads required experience in desktop publishing, which I lacked. I felt more likely to host a seminar on nuclear physics than to design a page on a computer. I was known in my family as the technophobe; even basic calculators confused me, and I struggled with the video timer.

I knew I had to act quickly to fill the gap in my career. I thought leaving home before my children would be difficult, but then I entered a local newspaper competition and, surprisingly, my family won a computer package. We received a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family. We jumped into this new world, and terms like cyberspace, Internet, and surfing became part of our everyday language. We started chatting online with people from around the world. The children stopped watching TV, and I created a small office in the kitchen with a phone, fax machine, CD-ROM, and a modem to connect to the Internet. This setup allowed me to work from home while still taking the kids to school.

My children were already comfortable with computers from school, while I was more cautious, fearing I would lose my work by pressing the wrong button. I was wrong. Although I wasn't very skilled, I learned the basics, and it turned out to be logical and straightforward. With persistence, I improved a little each day. I recently began freelancing for a magazine, writing about two articles a month, and I feel proud to balance both work and family life.

How has the computer helped me? In school, my desk was always messy, and I often lost important notes. The computer has made me more organized, especially with office tasks. I use spreadsheets to track income and expenses, and ready-made invoices and letterheads save me a lot of time. As a journalist, being online allows me to research stories, seek information on forums, and discuss working from home with others globally.

However, working from home has its downsides. It can be isolating, and household distractions often take priority. When the children are home, we sometimes argue over who gets to use the computer. Yet, many people in my neighborhood are buying multimedia PCs, not just for education and entertainment, but also for the convenience of avoiding daily commutes.

As we move into the next century, a report called "PC Usage in UK Homes" describes the typical home computer user as 38 years old and well-educated. Most own a personal computer, and many have additional devices like CD-ROMs and laser printers. Considering this, I feel I am ahead of the curve. Who knows, one day I might be emailing a column to a newspaper in Melbourne or even publishing my own magazine from home. It seems that the possibilities in cyberspace are endless.

**The Tartan Museum**

The modern buildings of Scotland's national museum stand out in historic Edinburgh. But are the exhibits inside just as impressive? Sally Varlow visited the museum before it opened.

You can't miss the new Museum of Scotland, located at the corner of Chambers Street in Edinburgh. It features a large yellow sandstone tower and unique, wedge-shaped buildings topped with a hanging garden. Last winter, the building received mixed reactions: some called it a "masterpiece" or "stunning," while others were more cautious or even critical. Now, as the inside prepares for opening, the exhibitions may face similar opinions.

Forget debates about whether the museum tells a national story or follows a timeline. The answer is yes; it presents a rich tapestry of stories linked to valuable historic objects, with a timeline to help visitors navigate without restricting the displays. Importantly, it does not let national pride overshadow its treasures, like Mary Queen of Scots' jewels and the silver from Holyrood chapel.

The main concern is whether visitors will find the museum engaging enough to return. Dr. David Clarke, the head of exhibitions, believes a visit should be enjoyable and visually appealing, aimed at those with little prior knowledge. Despite this openness, Clarke insists on authenticity in the exhibits. He rejects overly imaginative recreations of the past, stating that they misrepresent history. The public deserves the truth.

At this museum, what you see reflects what experts know. The challenge for visitors is whether the stories of the objects can be communicated effectively through explanation panels, captions, and multimedia, with only about 30 computers available throughout the museum. With less than three days before the opening, it remains uncertain.

Some aspects are clear, though. The stunning views of Edinburgh Castle are breathtaking. Inside, the layout is striking, with galleries connecting in various sizes and shapes, featuring pale walls designed to resemble large stone blocks and deep display cases. Natural light pours in through narrow windows and roof lights, creating a space where visitors can reflect on each item.

Thanks to a 12-member Junior board of 9- to 12-year-olds from across Scotland, the museum includes a Discovery Centre. The group wanted a way to interact with the displays. While they didn't get that, they did secure a dedicated hands-on area for children in what was supposed to be a temporary exhibition gallery. Consequently, the Twentieth Century gallery on the top floor is the only temporary exhibition, set to change every three years. It features a mix of items chosen by Scottish people and notable figures that have significantly influenced life in Scotland during the twentieth century. Suggestions ranged from electric guitars to televisions and favorite toys. While this idea is entertaining, it feels somewhat superficial and does not fully address deeper issues. However, the computerized collection of personal stories and memories will launch next week, which may add depth.

Overall, Dr. Clarke is correct in saying that "objects open windows on the past more vividly than anything else." As for the modern architecture, it is impressive from the inside and top, but whether it fits well in its location is still up for debate.

**The Future of Print Media**

The term "transition" suggests a smooth change from one state to another. While change can be intimidating for some, it usually implies a gradual movement from the present to the future. However, the shift of newspapers to the online world is uncertain and often uncomfortable. Many believe this change is inevitable, as print newspaper sales are declining while online visits are increasing. For instance, major newspapers like The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have seen their print sales drop by 8% to 10% each year, while their website traffic continues to rise.

Yet, the situation is more complex than it seems. A recent survey by the World Association of Newspapers revealed that global newspaper circulation actually increased by 1.1% last year, reaching 512 million copies daily. While sales in Western countries have decreased, Asia has compensated for this decline. Interestingly, news and current affairs magazines, which many thought would struggle in the digital age, reported a 5.4% increase in sales.

The same trend is seen in the book industry. E-readers like Kindle are becoming very popular, with significant sales growth this year. However, when bookstores assessed the value of physical books sold in the past six months, they found only a slight decrease of 0.4%. This suggests that both digital and print formats can coexist.

The idea that young people are completely abandoning newspapers is exaggerated. According to the latest National Readership Survey, nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 still read major national newspapers. Different countries in Europe show varying trends: Britain has seen a 10.8% drop in newspaper sales, while Germany's decline is only 7%, and France has experienced a mere 3.1% fall.

These differences indicate that the situation is more complicated than the advocates of digital media suggest. In the past, analysts believed that rising online advertising revenues would support the transition to digital newspapers. However, with digital ad revenues now declining, this assumption seems outdated. Many US newspapers have introduced paywalls to charge for online access. Interestingly, offering a print subscription along with digital access appears to be an effective way to attract paying readers. Print remains an important tool for selling online subscriptions, as print ads generate significantly more revenue than online ads.

Maintaining both a print edition and an active website is challenging and costly for newspaper companies. However, print media still holds significant visibility, while gaining attention online can be much more difficult.

**Photographing People**

People are the most fascinating subjects for photography. A photo that includes a person is usually more interesting than one without. However, photographing people can be challenging. Besides technical skills, photographers must pay attention to actions, gestures, and expressions. The presence of a camera can sometimes change how people behave.

**A. Grouping People**  
When taking group photos, avoid straight lines. Have people stand at different angles and distances, and if possible, at different heights. You can also have some people sit or kneel in front so that all faces are visible, or raise your camera to get a better view.

**B. Posing for Pictures**  
People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax by suggesting comfortable positions, like folding their hands or putting them in their pockets.

**C. The Right Approach**  
Do not pretend you are not taking a picture when it is obvious you are. This can create tension. Most people will agree to have their photo taken, even if they hesitate at first. They may feel flattered but can also become self-conscious, so you might need to guide them. A photo can be less interesting if the subject looks away from the camera.

**D. Eye Contact**  
A photo is more powerful if the subject looks at the viewer. Ask them to look into the lens, and they don’t have to smile. They might not be able to maintain this for long, so remind them just before you take the picture. You can also say something funny to capture a genuine reaction.

**E. Candid Concentration**  
Instead of direct eye contact, you can have the subject focus on something in the picture. This can make them feel more comfortable, and it allows the viewer to see what the subject is interested in. Candid shots can be very engaging, and the subject's expression is crucial.

**F. Expressions and Gestures**  
Expressions and gestures reveal a lot about a person. For example, a laughing child can make viewers smile, while a sad face can evoke sympathy. Look for common expressions like shrugs, winks, or smiles; they communicate feelings instantly.

**G. Situation Interest**  
While close-up shots of a person can be striking, the background can add context and interest. When including a background, avoid irrelevant details or blur them to keep the focus on the subject. A wide-angle lens can help make the subject appear larger compared to the background.

**H. Interaction**  
Capturing moments where people are interacting—talking, laughing, or working together—can lead to great photos. Couples, mothers with babies, and teams in action make for appealing shots. Look for eye contact or physical connections, like a hand on an arm, to show relationships.

**I. People and Places**  
Many photos of people are taken during trips. To improve these pictures, use a standard or wide-angle lens and step back to include the entire background, like a building or landscape. Position your subjects close to the camera while ensuring the background is visible. An elevated camera position can help achieve this balance.

**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**  
Decide why you want to take the picture. If it’s to remember someone you met briefly, a clear posed photo against a nice background is good. However, family photos can become boring if they are all formal poses. Candid shots of events are often more lively and can capture genuine moments, creating lasting memories.

**Under Sarah's Spell**

Sarah Janson is a trompe-l'oeil artist, which means she creates paintings that trick the eye into seeing something that looks real. In this interview with Joanna Watt, we learn more about her unique perspective on art.

Unlike many artists, Sarah does not sign her work unless someone asks her to. She believes that the artwork itself is what matters, not the artist. She is very modest and almost makes it seem like her paintings create themselves. This attitude makes for an interesting interview, as she admits, "I just don't like to shout about myself." When asked about being photographed, she reacts with surprise.

After some time, Sarah becomes more comfortable, and the conversation turns lively and entertaining. She has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years, following two years of intense drawing at art school, where she learned valuable skills. Although she studied graphic illustration and worked in publishing, she found her true passion in trompe-l'oeil after working with a well-known decorator, Jim Smart. He encouraged her to try this style, and she quickly became dedicated to it.

Sarah emphasizes that trompe-l'oeil is about observation and life experiences, rather than formal teaching. She believes that one never truly masters an art form, as there is always more to learn. She is candid about her weaknesses, such as her struggle with painting bread, which she feels never looks right. She also admits to having difficulty with measurements, especially when working on a large project like the ceiling of a chapel.

Despite her self-doubt, Sarah's talent is undeniable. Her trompe-l'oeil works are exceptional and stand out from others in the field. She has completed many significant projects for both businesses and private clients. Much of her art is inspired by architecture, such as a dining room designed to resemble a Venetian palace or a painting that creates the illusion of additional rooms in a flat.

Sarah understands that trompe-l'oeil must do two things: first, it should draw people in and trick them, and second, it must engage their imagination. She believes that the artwork should also reflect the client's personality. She enjoys collaborating with clients, as their ideas often inspire her work. Many of her clients become friends, especially since she spends a lot of time with them during projects.

Sarah appreciates her clients, especially those who take risks by allowing her creative freedom. Despite her modesty, she is always busy with new projects. She reiterates her preference for being understated, saying, "I really don't like to shout about myself." However, her work is anything but quiet; it deserves more recognition, and I am happy to share her story.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**

Daniel Goleman explores the essential 'people skills' needed to succeed in any profession.

A. The workplace is changing. We are now evaluated by a new standard—not just our intelligence or qualifications, but also how we manage ourselves and interact with others. This new standard is increasingly important in hiring decisions and promotions. It helps identify who is likely to excel and who may not. Regardless of our current jobs, these skills are vital for our future employability. This new measure is different from what we learned in school, where exam performance was seen as crucial. Now, it assumes we all have the necessary knowledge and skills for our jobs. Instead, it emphasizes social skills and personal traits like initiative, empathy, adaptability, and persuasiveness—collectively known as emotional intelligence.

B. In a time when job security is uncertain, personal qualities are becoming more important in the workplace. For years, these qualities have been referred to by various names, such as 'character' and 'soft skills.' Now, we have a clearer understanding of these abilities, which we call 'emotional intelligence.' This term generally means the ability to understand and manage our own feelings and those of others, using emotions to guide our thoughts and actions. In the workplace, emotional intelligence includes self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and social skills. Some people mistakenly think it only means being nice. However, it can also require being direct and honest, even when it’s uncomfortable. Emotional intelligence is not about expressing feelings freely; it’s about managing them effectively to help people work together towards common goals.

C. More companies recognize that fostering emotional intelligence is vital for effective management. In complex jobs, emotional intelligence becomes even more important because a lack of these skills can limit the effectiveness of a person's technical knowledge. While some individuals have succeeded despite lacking emotional intelligence, as work becomes more collaborative, companies that promote teamwork gain a competitive advantage. In today’s work environment, which values teamwork and customer focus, emotional intelligence is essential for success in every job worldwide.

D. Unlike IQ, which remains relatively stable, emotional intelligence can grow throughout our lives as we learn from experiences. Research shows that most people become better at managing their emotions, motivating themselves, and developing empathy and social skills over time. This growth in emotional intelligence is often referred to as maturity. Not only can we learn emotional intelligence, but we can also add these skills to our toolkit for navigating the workplace. This is especially important in a time when job stability seems uncertain. While emotional intelligence is not a guaranteed solution for struggling organizations, ignoring the human element can hinder overall effectiveness.

Text: 'Should the media profit from content they do not own? Digital cameras and camera phones have made it easier to capture important news events, but social media has truly changed how citizen photography works. As news often breaks on social networks, some journalists are now using these platforms for images during fast-moving events. However, some reporters have shared user-generated content (UGC) without getting permission first. Although there is guidance stating that images on social media can be used without permission in special cases or when there is strong public interest, the question of whether this is ethical remains debated. Research shows that about one in ten people would film or photograph a news event, highlighting the significant role of UGC in the future of media. To maintain a good relationship with the public, the media must ensure that individuals are fairly compensated for their work and that permission is always obtained.'

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**

Acupuncture is a practice that has been around for two thousand years. It is part of traditional Chinese medicine, which also includes herbal remedies, massage, diet, physical manipulation, and exercise. While acupuncture can treat various health issues, it is particularly noted for its effectiveness in relieving pain. Many general practitioners, midwives, and physiotherapists in the West use it for this purpose.

**Understanding Traditional Chinese Medicine**

Traditional Chinese medicine views health as a balance of energy in the mind, body, and spirit. This energy, known as Qi (pronounced "chee"), flows through the body along pathways called meridians. There are twelve main meridians, each connected to a specific organ, and many smaller ones that distribute Qi to every cell. When the flow of Qi is disrupted, it can lead to weakness or illness. During a consultation, an acupuncturist will assess your Qi by checking your pulse, examining your tongue, and looking at your overall health. They will ask about your medical history, current health, mental state, and lifestyle habits, including diet and sleep.

**Acupuncture Points**

Acupuncture involves inserting fine needles into specific points on the body, which are linked to the meridians. These points may not be near the area of pain. Patients often report feeling a mild ache or tingling when the needle is adjusted, which indicates that the needle has reached the Qi. There are over three hundred acupuncture points on the main meridians, with many more used less frequently.

**Scientific Understanding of Acupuncture**

While Western doctors may not fully accept traditional Chinese medicine, many acknowledge that acupuncture can help relieve pain. Scientific studies suggest that acupuncture may work by blocking pain signals from reaching the brain or by releasing natural pain-relieving chemicals called endorphins.

**Types of Pain Treated**

Acupuncture is often sought by people with chronic pain when other treatments have failed. It is commonly used for back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, migraines, and post-surgery pain. Acupuncturists also claim it can help with menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in terminally ill patients.

**Modern Applications of Acupuncture**

Although acupuncture has been practiced in China for over two millennia, its use as an alternative to anesthesia in surgery began in the 1950s. This development helped some Western doctors recognize its potential. In China today, acupuncture is used in various surgeries, including tonsillectomies and heart surgeries. It can be used alone, with electrical stimulation, or alongside medications. While some patients report significant pain relief, experiences can vary. Acupuncturists argue that acupuncture has fewer side effects than traditional anesthetics and allows for quicker recovery.

**Effectiveness of Acupuncture**

Evaluating acupuncture through clinical trials can be challenging, but studies indicate that 50 to 80 percent of patients find it effective for chronic pain. Acupuncturists generally agree with this success rate, although they recognize that it may not work for everyone. They suggest that patients with long-term pain may need six to seven sessions to feel significant relief, though some improvement can often be noticed after just two or three visits.

**A Holistic Approach to Pain**

Western and Chinese medicine have different perspectives on pain. Acupuncturists take a holistic approach, considering not just the symptoms but also the overall health of the patient. They spend time diagnosing the underlying issues affecting the Qi and consider external factors that may worsen the pain, such as weather conditions.
