This comprehensive view is not typically taken by conventional medical doctors.

**Choosing an Acupuncturist**

Some medical professionals have training in traditional acupuncture, while others, including many general practitioners, prefer scientific explanations. Traditional acupuncturists believe that using the principles of traditional Chinese medicine can lead to deeper healing, which is hard to measure in studies. It is important to choose a qualified acupuncturist who can refer you to a medical doctor if further investigation is needed.

P.D. James is a well-known crime writer whose gentle appearance hides a deep and creative mind. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James, and she carries an air of quiet confidence. One can easily imagine her as a headmistress of a girls' school if she had not chosen to write detective stories filled with unexpected twists. However, it quickly becomes clear that her confident demeanor masks her shyness. She admits that her main character, Adam Dalgliesh, is somewhat based on herself, or how she might have been if she were a man. Dalgliesh prefers to solve crimes alone, just like James prefers to write in solitude. She needs complete privacy to write, no matter where she is.

Despite her success, she is too humble to agree that she is the most famous crime writer in Britain, even though millions enjoy her twelve major detective novels. She admires the work of her close friend Ruth Rendell, especially her psychological novels written under the name Barbara Vine. The books she enjoys most are often by female authors like Iris Murdoch, Anita Brookner, and Penelope Lively, but she also appreciates male writers like Graham Greene and Evelyn Waugh, whom she considers great novelists.

P.D. James found success later in life. She was 42 when her first crime novel, Cover Her Face, was published. Born in Oxford, she grew up in Cambridge after her family moved there when she was 11. She met her husband, a university student, in Cambridge, which is why she chose it as the setting for one of her novels, An Unsuitable Job For A Woman. She shares that her life has had its challenges, including the struggles she faced when her husband, Connor Bantry White, returned from World War II in poor health. To support him and their two daughters, Clare and Jane, she worked long hours, which left her little time to write, despite having many ideas. Fortunately, her husband's parents helped care for the children during those tough times.

While working full-time in administration for the National Health Service, she used her excellent organizational skills. At one point, she managed five psychiatric outpatient clinics. She then spent eleven years at the Home Office, first in the Police Department and later in the Criminal Law section, focusing on juvenile crime. During her time in forensic science, she became accustomed to seeing dead bodies, but her interest was not in death itself. Instead, she was drawn to the structure and craft of writing a crime novel. She has always loved reading detective stories and knew she wanted to be a writer.

James did not want to write about her own traumatic experiences. She saw writing detective stories as a valuable training ground for becoming a serious novelist, as it allowed her to explore human nature while keeping her own life experiences at a distance. She believes that writing detective stories helps bring order to chaos. Solving a crime affirms the value of life, even if that life is not admirable. Ultimately, she notes that no one truly enjoys violence.

**The Pen is Mightier than the Psychoanalyst**

The study of handwriting to understand a person's character is becoming more popular. In some countries, if you apply for a job, you will likely be asked to provide a sample of your handwriting. This handwriting sample can significantly influence whether you are considered suitable for the position. Handwriting analysis, known as graphology, is recognized as a legitimate science in many places. Researchers suggest it can help identify certain health issues, like heart disease and cancer, and can also reveal emotional and psychological states. 

Graphology is increasingly used for career guidance and as a supplement to job interviews. Many large companies now hire graphologists to evaluate the handwriting of job candidates. However, many doctors and psychiatrists are skeptical about the effectiveness of graphology. Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist with over 20 years of experience, believes it deserves more attention. She argues that handwriting can reflect psychological traits and some medical conditions. According to her, "Handwriting is a strong indicator of social class and intelligence. It can also help assess mental abilities, whether someone should focus on arts or sciences, and whether they have a deceitful or honest character."

Ms. Marne claims that graphology can be particularly useful in identifying potential criminal behavior. She notes that criminals often have disturbed handwriting, which is usually poorly formed and sometimes illiterate. Many criminals come from challenging backgrounds and show signs of emotional development issues, which can be reflected in childish handwriting and repetitive letter formations. 

She states, "I can determine if people are honest, manipulative, or trustworthy." For example, young male offenders often have tall ascenders in their writing, suggesting they live in a fantasy world and aspire to great success. Graphologists can also predict if someone is under extreme stress or has violent tendencies, and they can even identify potential suicidal thoughts. 

Ms. Marne explains that heart and lung issues can also be detected through handwriting. While one sample may not provide enough information for a diagnosis, changes in handwriting over time, such as a previously stable signature becoming shaky or disjointed, can indicate serious problems. A significant emotional disturbance may also temporarily alter a person's signature.

She describes various handwriting traits that reveal psychological characteristics. For instance, people whose letters connect like threads may be clever but deceitful. Those who write mostly in capital letters might be hiding their true selves. Light pressure in writing suggests sensitivity and low energy. Originality in handwriting shows confidence and creativity, while disconnected writing often indicates a solitary personality. Small signatures can reflect feelings of inferiority, while circles over the letter "i" may indicate a desire for attention. Heavy crossings of the letter "t" can suggest intolerance and a condescending attitude.

Ms. Marne believes that it takes six years of study and experience to accurately analyze handwriting, along with empathy and intuition. She feels more research is needed to establish graphology as a scientific discipline, and she is optimistic that this will happen soon. She claims, "It is actually more accurate than psychoanalysis because it reveals a person's entire history, including emotional crises, without needing to ask potentially misleading questions."

Despite these intriguing claims, there is little solid evidence to support them. Some psychiatrists criticize graphology, arguing that handwriting is influenced by education, artistic skills, and the writing style taught, and that it holds no deeper significance.

**Is Your Office Working Well?**

Fresh air and comfortable chairs are essential for a happy and healthy workplace, according to a recent survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they were as work environments. Our expert panel included a building health consultant, an ergonomist who studies work conditions, and an occupational psychologist. Here are their assessments.

**Office A: Advertising Agency**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is very basic; it has no central heating or mechanical ventilation, and the windows open directly onto the street. Surprisingly, the small team of seven people seems happy and has few complaints. They adapt to the weather by opening doors and roof panels or using electric heaters, similar to how they would at home. This may be the reason for their contentment: they have created a cozy work environment without unnecessary rules.

- **Ergonomist:** The furniture is mismatched and often leads to poor posture. Many chairs are old, not adjustable, and some are broken. However, the staff has a varied work schedule that includes office tasks, client meetings, and presentations, which helps prevent fatigue and boredom.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** Employees enjoy the variety of work and the flexible office space. They feel the office is "just the right size"—small enough to know what others are doing, yet large enough to focus on individual tasks. The office is attractive and promotes both efficiency and creativity.

**Office B: News Service**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office may not be very exciting, but it is comfortable and staff do not dislike it. The air quality and maintenance are good, partly due to a No Smoking policy.

- **Ergonomist:** The company has hired an ergonomist, and the chairs, lighting, and computer equipment are excellent. The layout could be better, but the environment feels impersonal with plain grey walls.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The walls are mostly bare, except for year planners and a poster about maternity rights. Most employees have been there for over five years, and relationships are satisfactory. The office could improve by rearranging desks to facilitate information sharing and displaying project updates on the walls.

**Office C: Bank**

- **Building Health Consultant:** Reactions to this office are mixed. It feels like being in a glass case, surrounded by many similar spaces. Despite a mix of smokers and non-smokers, the air quality is surprisingly good.

- **Ergonomist:** The office is standard and uninspiring. The desks are barely adequate, and not all chairs meet ergonomic standards. Many computer screens are on low desks, which is not suitable for modern equipment.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** Staff support each other well and have good technology. The office has many awards on display, but the wood paneling and brown carpet create a dull atmosphere. However, the office is lively and busy.

**Office D: Newspaper**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office has many issues. The air conditioning is poorly controlled, leading to uncomfortable temperature changes. The space is cluttered, and most desks are too small. Dust is a problem, as it collects in many areas.

- **Ergonomist:** The furniture is more suitable for a workshop than an office. Many chairs are old and do not support proper posture, especially for shorter users. 

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The office is filled with old brown chairs and dirty carpets. There is a lot of room for improvement—cleaning is needed, individual achievements should be recognized, and air conditioning must be fixed, especially with so many smokers. During our visit, there were few conversations, and everyone seemed stressed and focused on deadlines. The company should encourage teamwork.

**Chewing Gum Culture**

Chewing gum is popular, accessible to everyone, and Americans chew about 12 million sticks daily. This ancient practice has turned into a large industry. Each stick of gum has fewer than ten calories, but since it is considered food, it must meet the standards set by the American Food and Drug Administration.

Today’s gum is mostly made from synthetic materials, including pine resins and softeners that help maintain flavor and improve texture. However, this was not always the case. The ancient Greeks chewed a resin from the mastic tree, which grows mainly in Greece and Turkey. Greek women particularly liked mastic gum for cleaning their teeth and freshening their breath. American colonists learned from the Native Americans in New England and chewed resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, lumps of spruce for chewing were sold in the eastern United States, marking the beginning of commercial chewing gum in the country.

Modern chewing gum began in the late 1860s with the discovery of chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree found in Central America. Gum made from chicle was smoother, more enjoyable, and elastic, leading to the growth of a whole industry. However, efforts to grow sapodilla commercially have not succeeded. As the demand for chewing gum increased, synthetic alternatives were created.

Today, the few remaining chicle gatherers, known as chicleros, live a difficult and dangerous life. They trek for miles to collect sap from scattered sapodilla trees in very humid conditions. The environment is harsh, with poisonous snakes and many insects. One particularly troublesome insect, the chicle fly, lays its eggs in the ears and noses of the gatherers. Despite these dangers, experienced chicleros can quickly climb a mature tree to create a path for the sap to flow into a bag below. They then carry the sap back to a camp, where it is boiled until it becomes sticky and is formed into bricks.

Life at the camp is also tough, with a boring and often inadequate diet based mainly on maize, accompanied by a local alcohol made from sugar cane. Despite these challenges, chicleros worry about their jobs. Not long ago, the United States imported 7,000 tonnes of chicle each year from Central America, but last year only 200 tonnes were collected in Mexico's Yucatan peninsula.

As chewing gum sales have increased, manufacturers have shifted to synthetic ingredients to lower costs and meet demand. Meanwhile, gum producers are finding creative ways to market their products. They claim that gum helps with relaxation, boosts energy, and reduces stress (soldiers in both world wars were often given gum). The most significant claim is that it helps reduce tooth decay. Plaque acid, which forms when we eat, can harm teeth. Our saliva helps neutralize this acid and provides minerals like calcium, phosphate, and fluoride, acting as the body’s natural defense. Gum manufacturers suggest that chewing for 20 minutes can increase saliva production.

Research continues on new textures and flavors. Glycerine and other vegetable oils are now used to create the gum base. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still require natural ingredients. Additionally, 137 square kilometers of land in America is dedicated to growing mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**REMOTE HOTELS**

**A. INDIA - Ghanerao Hotel, Rajasthan**  
Ghanerao Hotel is located at the edge of the Aravalli Hills in a small village known for its craftsmen. It combines the peacefulness of an English country house with Indian culture. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years, and now Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests into their home. The amenities are basic, with hot water provided in buckets, but this simplicity adds to the hotel's charm.

**B. NEW ZEALAND - Hermitage Hotel, Mount Cook**  
One of my favorite hotels is the Hermitage Hotel on New Zealand's South Island. I discovered it by chance while climbing. After being flown close to the top of a glacier and climbing to the peak, we had to walk down. To my surprise, we found this hotel at the bottom, set in stunning, wild countryside. Arriving exhausted and finding luxury, with a pianist playing Cole Porter, was an unforgettable experience.

**C. MAURITIUS - Paradis Hotel**  
On the southwest coast of Mauritius, Paradis Hotel is located on a quiet peninsula. The road to the hotel winds along the coast, passing empty beaches where only fishermen are present. Although the hotel is large and offers many free water sports, you can easily find solitude on its nine kilometers of private beach. Swim a little way out into the Indian Ocean, and the hotel becomes hidden behind palm trees. In the evening, as the sun sets and everyone leaves, you can feel completely away from it all.

**D. ST LUCIA - Ladera Hotel**  
Ladera Hotel in St Lucia has one of the most stunning views in the Caribbean. It is quiet and remote, situated 1,000 feet high, with open rooms that look out between the twin peaks of the Pitons to the Caribbean Sea. The hotel features colonial-style decor, with mahogany and greenheart wood furniture, and four-poster beds with muslin netting.

**E. TURKEY - The Splendid Hotel, Istanbul**  
The Splendid Hotel, located on Buyukada in the Princes Islands, is an ideal escape from the noise of Istanbul. Just an hour by boat, the islands are peaceful, with no cars, only horse-drawn carriages and beautiful wooden buildings from the 1920s. The hotel, painted white with red domes, resembles a historic hotel from the French Riviera. Although it is a bit worn, it still retains its charm.

**F. FRANCE - Chateau d'Etoges, Epernay**  
In the small village of Etoges, in the Champagne region, there is a lovely seventeenth-century chateau surrounded by a moat with swans. This chateau, which was a family home until recently, has 20 unique rooms, some with four-poster beds, and one even has a billiard table. They offer special weekend rates for two nights, including breakfast and dinner, along with complimentary champagne.

**G. KENYA - The Fairview Hotel, Nairobi**  
The Fairview Hotel is a rare find in Africa, offering comfort without excessive luxury. It is a popular stop for travelers recovering from safaris and planning their next adventures. Guests often arrive, see the beautiful gardens and inviting rooms, and decide to stay longer. The hotel has apartments for those who want to settle in for a few months. Set on Nairobi Hill, it feels far removed from the busy city center, making it a perfect spot to enjoy the stunning African sunset while sipping beer and anticipating a hearty dinner.

**H. ITALY - Hotel Splendido, Portofino**  
The Hotel Splendido was first signed into by the Duke of Windsor, and since then, many famous people have visited, including Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart. Today, you might meet wealthy guests, but the hotel, which was once a monastery, remains splendid. It offers simple yet delicious food and features beautiful Persian rugs and homemade pasta.

The Hotel Inspector, Sue Brown, evaluates hotels as her job. Christopher Middleton observed her during an inspection. Just one minute into the annual check, problems arise at the Globe Hotel, although the staff are unaware. The receptionist is busy quoting room rates to a potential guest and ignores Sue and Christopher. "She hasn't even acknowledged us," Sue comments quietly. "Very poor." This is a common mistake during the arrival phase, one Sue has seen many times in her 11 years as an inspector. "But this isn't just any three-star hotel," she argues. "It has three red stars, so I expect better." Having red stars means the Globe is among the top 130 hotels out of 4,000 in the guide published by her organization.

Even before the cold welcome, the atmosphere feels off. Access from the parking lot is through an unmanned door with a buzzer, leading to a long, empty corridor to the hotel entrance. "Again, not what I expected," Sue remarks. Could it get worse? Yes, it can. The receptionist cheerfully informs them, "We have no record of your booking." It turns out that out of the 15 rooms, 12 are empty that night. One available room is on the top floor, but it does not meet Sue's standards: it feels stuffy, and there is a large hole in the wall behind the wardrobe.

When she started her career, she earned a reputation for being tough. "I was known as 'The Woman in Black,'" she recalls, "which is funny because I never wore black. And I’ve never been too tough." However, the next morning, after paying her bill, she reveals her identity to the hotel’s general manager, Robin Greaves. His face shows fear. Before she says anything, he apologizes for a bad smell in the main lounge. "We think there's a blocked drain," he sighs. "The whole floor might need to be replaced."

Sue kindly suggests that, in addition to fixing the plumbing, he should guide his staff to avoid directing guests to that lounge. "It might be better to lead them to the other lounge," she advises. Greaves nods sadly and takes notes. He has only been at the Globe for five months and struggles to believe Sue when she says her feedback is meant to help the hotel in the long run.

Not everything is negative. Sue praises Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the young waitress, who provided information about the hotel’s 400-year history. The dinner also meets the standards to keep the hotel’s two-rosette food rating, encouraging Greaves to ask, "What do we need to do to get three rosettes?" Sue's response is, "Don’t serve a collapsing pudding." Greaves’ brief excitement fades.

Sue's job is to express the complaints that many customers are too afraid to voice. "Sometimes, it can be very sensitive. I remember a woman complained that I got her son fired. All I could say was the truth: he served me apple pie with his fingers." She receives letters with false accusations, from being overly critical to demanding bribes. "You get used to it, but it still hurts," she says.

Sue must not only share her findings verbally with the hotel manager but also send a detailed written report. After all, the hotel pays for her insights (there is an annual fee for being included in the guide). However, being recognized with red stars makes it worthwhile. It is good news for Greaves that Sue will not recommend taking away the Globe's red stars. The bad news is that another inspector will return in the next two months to ensure improvements have been made. "Good," Greaves says with a forced smile. "We’ll look forward to that."

**Seven Summits: A Mountaineer's Journey**

Doug Scott, an experienced mountaineer, shares his incredible experiences of climbing the highest peaks on each continent, known as the Seven Summits. He began this journey later in life and will describe each mountain in the order he climbed them.

**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**  
While resting in a snow cave 91 meters below the summit, Doug and his climbing partner, Dougal Haston, discussed sleeping bags, which seemed odd since they were alone. Doug attributed this to a lack of oxygen and even found himself talking to his feet, which were getting cold. He remembered climbers who had lost fingers and toes to frostbite. Their main concern was not just survival, but how well they could survive. Over the next two days, Doug reflected on their time on the summit ridge and felt grateful to be climbing with Dougal, who inspired confidence in him. He focused on finding a better rhythm to reach the summit.

**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**  
Considered one of the most dangerous mountains, Doug and Dougal arrived at the Kahiltna Glacier in April 1976. They spent four days carrying equipment and food to the base. After the first day, they realized the challenge ahead. They followed a route established in 1967 but decided to take a new path to the summit. Climbing "alpine style," they carried everything on their backs. After facing tough conditions, including a wet sleeping bag and strong winds, they finally reached the summit, feeling victorious.

**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**  
In September 1976, Doug and his friend Paul Braithwaite flew to Nairobi to climb Mt. Kenya but ended up on Kilimanjaro due to a free ride. They got lost in the dense jungle, which was concerning because water was scarce. On the second day, they found a rock pool marked by rubbish, which was a relief. They attempted a challenging climb but decided to take a safer route to the summit.

**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**  
In January 1992, Doug and his wife, Sharu, arrived at Punta del Inca and met fellow climber Phil Erscheler. Phil suggested they join his group climbing via the Polish Glacier, a less crowded route. After waiting out bad weather, they set off. The glacier was icy and treacherous, so they chose to take the standard route instead. They faced strong winds but successfully reached the summit and met other climbers who encouraged Doug to pursue the Seven Summits goal.

**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**  
Doug learned that climbing Vinson Massif could be funded by guiding others. In November 1992, his team traveled to the South Pole. During this time, the sun never set, creating a unique atmosphere. On December 7, they set out for the summit. Despite harsh winds and freezing temperatures, they all reached the top within eight hours, although visibility was poor due to a storm.

**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**  
In the summer of 1994, Doug's team gathered in St. Petersburg and traveled to Terskol, near Elbrus. After acclimatizing, they took a cable car to 3,900m and walked to a refuge at 4,200m. Two days later, they faced strong winds while climbing. They thought they had reached the summit but discovered there was still more to climb. They returned to the refuge and descended the volcano the next day.

**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**  
On their expedition to Carstensz, Doug and his team aimed to establish a new route and connect with the local Dani people. Despite warnings of potential danger from bandits, they set out to climb. On May 12, the weather improved, and they reached the summit by 11 am. Doug received a standing ovation for completing his seventh summit, marking the end of his incredible journey.

**Style Merchants**

Style influences many aspects of our lives today, from clothing to home decor and accessories. Jo Foley shares the latest trends for fashion enthusiasts this year.

**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**  
Ned Ingham creates beautiful, romantic wedding dresses. He advises people to steer clear of traditional, stiff designs and overly frilly styles, opting instead for simpler looks. Ingham has been sketching and designing wedding dresses since he was a child. At 16, he attended fashion school, where he learned how to cut and sew clothes. However, you don’t need to be a bride to wear an Ingham dress; he also designs elegant evening gowns, updated with modern colors and fabrics. For those who prefer classic styles, Ingham offers a timeless navy-blue summer suit, a staple in women's wardrobes throughout the 20th century, but he gives it a fresh, contemporary twist.

**Sally Quail: Jeweller**  
Sally Quail, who previously worked for an art dealer, has no formal training in jewellery design. She began creating her own engagement ring when she couldn’t find one she liked, which led her to start her own design business in 1990. Now, her jewellery is popular among many celebrities. Her signature style features large semi-precious stones set in gold, creating stunning necklaces, bracelets, and rings inspired by 18th-century designs. Recently, she has started using diamonds, saying, "I reached that moment in every woman's life when she wants a diamond, and that is when I began working with them."

**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**  
Just four years after entering the competitive fashion industry, Lily Grimson has had two of her handbag designs chosen for a major exhibition, despite only having taken an introductory art and design course. Her bags, handmade in the UK, are not just functional; they exude glamour, whether made from luxurious calfskin or rich silk. The combination of style and quality makes a Grimson bag truly special.

**Peter Little: Hairdresser**  
For over 20 years, Peter Little has styled the hair of many famous individuals. He understands that most women want a natural look that they can manage at home. His unique approach ensures that clients don’t look like they just left a salon. However, this relaxed style comes at a price—£250 for the first appointment, with a three-month waiting list. Leveraging his celebrity status, Peter has launched his own line of hairdryers and styling tools, allowing those who can’t visit his salon to achieve their desired looks at home.

**Penny Pratt: Florist**  
Penny Pratt runs a small flower shop and serves as a floral consultant for a large supermarket chain, providing floral ideas for top restaurants. Remarkably, she has no formal qualifications in floristry and left her teaching job ten years ago to pursue a new path. Her modern and simple floral arrangements have won numerous design awards, helping her establish her own London Flower School. She has also enjoyed successful lecture tours in Japan and the USA. Penny believes that flower arrangements today should be simple yet striking, avoiding excessive leaves, which can be too large and architectural. For wedding bouquets, she emphasizes that all flowers should be of the same type.

**Five-Star Luxury with Modern Technology**

The new five-star Merrion Hotel in Dublin combines luxury with the latest technology. It was created by transforming four large 18th-century houses, a project that took nearly two years and involved extensive research into what customers want. This approach has allowed the hotel to install advanced technology that benefits both staff and guests.

General Manager Peter MacCann expects his staff to know guests by name, but he uses a computer system to keep track of their preferences. This system helps the hotel provide a special experience for returning guests. Although it cost £250,000 to set up, MacCann believes it will be worth it over time due to its efficiency. For instance, if a guest requests specific music CDs during their first stay, those same CDs will be ready for them on their next visit, thanks to the guest-history feature.

Room temperature is another common concern for hotel guests. The Merrion has a high-tech system that allows guests to adjust the temperature within three degrees of the normal 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can change the temperature in each room between 14°C and 25°C.

Business travelers will particularly appreciate the technology in their rooms. MacCann estimates that about 65% of the hotel’s business will come from this group. To cater to their needs, the hotel has equipped each room with three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and video-conferencing capabilities. The hotel has also prepared for future technological advancements by installing extra cables and renting televisions and DVD recorders, allowing for easy upgrades.

Despite all this technology, MacCann emphasizes that they want guests to feel comfortable, not overwhelmed. The hotel features 145 spacious and well-furnished bedrooms that are inviting and cozy. Guests can also enjoy a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a lovely garden.

The dining experience is also exceptional. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who previously earned two Michelin stars for his restaurant in Dublin, has moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This change allows him to create a modern kitchen and offers better parking than his previous location. For the hotel, having a renowned restaurant adds value without financial risk. With its combination of technology and skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is poised for success.

**An Eye for Detail**

Artist Susan Shepherd is well-known for her flower paintings, which are inspired by the large garden around her house. This garden is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The two long flower borders along the paved path that runs from east to west are beautifully arranged in terms of color, shape, and structure. This beauty is partly thanks to the previous owners, who were passionate gardeners and left behind plants that Susan loves. She also inherited the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' about some of the things I wanted to add, but when I told him I wanted to paint them, he understood my vision."

Susan prefers to create detailed studies of individual plants rather than painting the entire garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants in their natural setting, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which can take a few days, and then I bring in another one to continue the painting. Sometimes, it can take a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is in spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all bloom together, and it's a hectic time," she says. However, she finds the gradual decay of flowers fascinating. For instance, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, and after a day, they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, they seem dull, but they keep changing with twists and turns."

Susan has always had an interest in plants. "I studied botany in school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside," she recalls. "I wasn't really into gardening back then; I didn't like garden flowers because they reminded me of fake ones sold in some flower shops. To me, only wildflowers were real. I was fascinated by how they could grow in tough places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."

Today, her garden features many plants from distant lands, yet they thrive just as well as they did in places like China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed approach to her garden, similar to a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious trouble. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of inspiration right outside her door, finding time to work in the garden has been challenging. She now hires an extra gardener, but she understands that to stay connected to her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**No Title**

In March, strong storms caused many trees in the Brackham area to fall. The town lost two large lime trees from the old market square. This change upset many residents who preferred the town's traditional look. Normally, Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police, would have been among those upset. However, during the storm, he was too ill to notice because he was suffering from bronchitis for the first time in his life. 

When he first felt pain in his head and tightness in his chest, his wife, Molly, urged him to see a doctor. But Pelham, believing the police needed him, ignored her advice and tried to keep working. This decision made him forgetful and irritable. Eventually, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor, and he had no energy left to argue. Soon after, he was at the pharmacy getting antibiotics and then back home, where Molly sent him straight to bed.

On Thursday morning, when Molly told him that the walnut tree in their garden had fallen during the night, Pelham was too weak to fully understand. Later that evening, he asked if the house was damaged and felt relieved to hear it was not. He then covered himself with the sheets. It was not until Saturday, when the antibiotics started working and he felt better, that he noticed how much the loss of the walnut tree had changed the living room.

The Pelhams lived in a large house with a big garden, which they had bought without regrets. The garden had given them a sense of privacy. Before the storm, the walnut tree had provided a nice view from the living room, creating interesting patterns of light and shadow that hid the worn furniture they had brought from their old home. Now, without the tree, the room felt too bright, exposing the shabby furniture. The view from the window was also unpleasant; the tall house next door, which had been hidden by the tree, was now visible, with its unattractive purple bricks and many windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams.

"Doesn't it look terrible?" Pelham asked his wife weakly. But Molly, standing in the doorway, sounded more happy than upset. "I've been saying this since we moved in. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost."

**Living in the Valley**

We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first noticed the dangers in the surrounding hills that could threaten our survival. That year, storms arrived early, even before November ended. Until then, we felt safe in our valley, protected by the hills. Soon, snow began to fall, and within a day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. This snow almost blocked our lane and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. However, in the hills, the snow was much deeper and lasted longer. The wind blew fiercely up there, while in our valley, we only felt sudden gusts that made the trees sway, but their branches remained strong.

Despite the inconvenience of the snow and wind, we were more worried about the river, the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently. It reminded us of what could happen if the water from the hills was not controlled by the dams built many years ago. Soon, the snow began to melt, and we watched dark clouds gather over the hills to the west. These ominous grey clouds spread over the valleys, twisting and rising, warning us of what was coming. We had seen enough of the sky; now we focused on the river, which was becoming fuller and more turbulent each day. The melting snow was washed away by heavy rain, but the reservoir in the hills was filling up and nearing a dangerous level.

Then, it happened—after many years, the reservoir overflowed. It was like a mini Niagara Falls as water surged over the dam and rushed into the stream below. The river became wild, with water pouring down towards its lower stretches. Just a few meters from our cottage, the stream looked furious beneath the bridge. It was deeper than we had ever seen it, threatening to overflow its banks. For three days, we hoped it would stay within its limits. Thankfully, our hopes were fulfilled as the dam held, and the water levels began to drop.

In the past, before the dam was built, the river had flooded nearby villages in such a rage. Now, the dam controls the river's flow, and usually, everything is fine. The large amounts of water from the hills, caused by snow and heavy rain, stay behind the dam, with only occasional overflow. Because of this protection, we can enjoy the impressive clouds above the valley and appreciate the river's power without fear. Thanks to the dam, we feel our home in the valley is secure and safe.

Film critic Mark Adams reflects on his ten years of work for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing film articles for The Front Page was my first real job. Before that, I had done some reviews of novels for other newspapers, films for a magazine, and various tasks for the radio. This is how I met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who also worked in radio and television. He hired me, but since Tom was not mainly a journalist, he was not very careful in choosing his team. 

Initially, he wanted a group of critics to cover art forms that didn’t need special knowledge, like books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. We would have a weekly lunch to discuss which artistic works we should review, and there would be guests to keep the atmosphere friendly. At that time, it felt like a dream: a new newspaper, and I was part of the team. It seemed unlikely that a new paper could succeed in a crowded market. I even thought a millionaire was helping me personally and pretending to hire me, reflecting my low self-confidence. The first time I saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground and turning to a page with my review, I felt embarrassed.

Tom's idea of a team of critics for the arts did not work out as planned. Although it was a good idea, we didn’t meet as intended, and everything was done over the phone. It turned out that the public preferred to have a reviewer focus on one subject area, so I chose to specialize in film. Without Tom's initial support, we might not have developed the current system, where I write a detailed weekly piece, usually about one film. This way of working suits me well. I wouldn’t have enjoyed the typical film critic role, which requires reviewing every new film. That routine would quickly make me feel bored, and I would dread sitting through films I didn’t like.

The freedom I have allows me to expand my arguments or, during a dull week, to create something interesting from little material. But what is my role in the public eye? I believe people choose films based on stars, marketing, or the director. There is also loyalty to certain genres. It is rare for someone who dislikes westerns to buy a ticket for one after reading a review, or for a romantic film lover to skip a love story because of a critic's opinion. So, if a film review isn’t really a guide for consumers, what is it? I don’t feel I need to be “right” about a movie, nor do I think there should be a set number of “great” or “bad” films each year. My job is simply to present an argument. I am not a judge, and I don’t want to be one.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers? Because "it's fun." 

A teenager who loves endurance sports is looking for a training partner for triathlons, preferably female. This is a chance to work with someone who could be an Olympic champion. The partner should be very enthusiastic about distance running (regularly running 15 kilometers), distance swimming (enjoying winter training in cold rivers is a plus), and distance cycling (a love for cycling 100 kilometers is helpful). It is essential to be able to do all three activities without taking a break.

Triathlons are becoming one of the most popular Olympic sports. They attract large crowds who are both fascinated and shocked by athletes who swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers without stopping. While it may be exciting for spectators, what drives triathletes to push their bodies so hard? What makes a talented 17-year-old, who does well in school, give up so much for this challenging sport?

Melanie Sears, a young triathlete, has not yet learned the common phrases about personal satisfaction and mental challenges that many athletes use when asked similar questions. She explains, "You swim 1500 meters, then run out of the water and jump on your bike while still wet. Of course, you get cold. After the 40-kilometer bike ride, you have to run 10 kilometers, which feels long when you are tired. But it's really fun, and it's all worth it in the end."

Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14 years old. "I won the junior section, but I was the only junior competing. It felt so easy that I waved at my teammates as I went around." Feeling confident, she entered the National Championships. Although she had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, she did not place well. "I was following a man, and suddenly we found ourselves at the sea. We realized we had gone the wrong way. I ended up cycling 20 kilometers too far. I cried the whole time I was running."

Despite this setback, she is determined to keep going. "Sometimes I wish I could stop because then the pain would end, but I fear that if I stop just once, I would want to do it again." Her determination impresses Steve Trew, the sport's coaching director. "I tested her fitness, and she worked so hard on the running machine that it finally threw her off into a wall. She gave it her all, while most people would stop when they realize they can't go any further."

Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but much slower in cycling. That's why I'm working hard to improve." She is trying to convince her supportive parents, who will pay £1,300 for her trip to New Zealand for the World Championships, to buy a £2,000 bike (which is on sale for £1,000 off) so she can compete in national 25 km and 100 km races later this year.

However, there is a cost to her dedication. Her intense training has made her somewhat of a recluse. "I don't have a social life," she admits. "I'm not really into parties. After two hours of hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I do keep in touch with the other girls on the team." What do they talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, we discuss our times and achievements."

Where will this strong focus lead Melanie? She has tried other events, like the triathlon "sprint," which involves swimming 750 meters, cycling 20 kilometers, and running 5 kilometers. She wants to enter even tougher competitions than the triathlon. "The big problem is, I have no one my age to train with," she says. It's interesting, isn't it?

**The Collectors**

Amanda Roy discusses her passion for collecting and why many people share this hobby. Collecting is a popular activity, with one in three adults participating. It is a world filled with passion, envy, enthusiasm, and joy. However, if you decide to collect, remember: only collect items you truly love.

Since ancient times, people have felt the need to collect. Early humans collected pebbles, which they wore as necklaces. These pebbles, admired for their shapes and colors, were among the first objects gathered for intellectual and spiritual reasons. Over the years, this desire to collect has not changed. Children today still collect stones and seashells simply for their beauty.

I have been a collector all my life, gathering everything from flowers like tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. When I was six, I attended a school in a remote, cold part of England. When my parents visited, they took me to a local museum filled with objects collected by others. I was captivated by these items. Interestingly, I am not alone in my interest; many adults share this passion. 

People collect for various reasons, and one idea is that for some, collecting is the only part of their lives where they feel in control. For me, it is simply a joyful activity. One notable collector was the Duc de Berry in France, who had a "room of wonders" filled with natural and man-made curiosities, like coconut shell cups and carved ivory beads. Another famous collector, Catherine the Great of Russia, owned over 4,000 paintings. 

You don’t need to be wealthy to start a collection. I have collected diverse items, from tulip bulbs to china cups, always searching for unique examples. I remember convincing another tulip collector to sell me a special bulb. I planted it and cared for it, but one year it disappeared—stolen by another collector. 

I once collected 350 American rag dolls, exploring the USA to find different designs. Unfortunately, this collection was lost in a house fire. The next morning, I stood in my front hall, looking at the ruins of my furniture and collection, unsure which loss hurt more.

I find it fascinating how collections change hands. A silver spoon that belonged to a king or a poet adds value to items traded in markets. As certain small objects become popular among collectors, their prices rise. For example, toys from the 1950s are now considered valuable, especially if kept in their original boxes. Sadly, I discarded both the boxes and their contents!

**My Line of Work**

Four people discuss their jobs.

**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**  
I organize temporary exhibitions. This involves planning, designing, and promoting the exhibition. I research the exhibition topic and talk to key people to identify the main themes and goals. I decide which objects and images to display and ensure the public understands the exhibition's purpose. This includes planning interactive displays, workshops, and performances. I also coordinate with engineers and electricians to ensure the exhibition is safe for visitors. Before the exhibition opens, I help create brochures and leaflets to inform the public.

**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**  
When I arrive at 7:30 a.m., I first check the accounts. Then, I prepare new maps and documents to help students learn the routes needed to pass the London taxi-driver test. By midday, around 50 students are in class, figuring out the best routes, including one-way streets and turns. I step in when there are disagreements, like whether a right turn is allowed at a certain junction. As they approach the test, I give them a simple route but challenge them to find alternatives due to road closures. This encourages them to think critically.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**  
I live by the coast and work from home. My job involves answering phone inquiries, creating educational materials, and organizing training courses. I occasionally visit our main office, but I mostly work along the coast. I collaborate with schools and study centers, running courses for coastal managers and decision-makers about marine life. I take them out to sea to help them understand the underwater environment, which often changes their perspectives. I feel fortunate because conservation is my passion, but working for a charity means I constantly seek funding, which limits what I can achieve.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**  
My job is diverse. I ensure our publishing program meets market needs and maintain a stock of about 300 books. We have high standards for information and content. We receive many letters from readers about issues like international boundaries, which require careful responses. I discuss future projects and sales with co-publishers. I work with a dedicated team, which makes the job enjoyable. However, like many jobs, there is too much administration, leaving less time for more interesting tasks like product development and design.

**No Title**

Every June, we traveled to Ireland. Since the four of us started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a large house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. The English couple who own the house, the Malseeds, have made some additions to it, but they did so very tastefully. Strafe discovered Glencorn for us. He found an advertisement when the Malseeds were still promoting their place. One evening, he suggested it to us and read the details. The previous summer, we had gone to a hotel recommended by friends, but it was a disappointment because the food was terrible. 

The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. My real name is Dorothy Milson, but they call me Milly. Dekko got his nickname at school; Dekko Deacon sounds nice, I guess. He and Strafe were schoolmates, which is why we call Strafe by his last name, as the teachers did. We are all about the same age and live close to where the Malseeds used to live in England. We often think it’s a funny coincidence.

“Welcome back!” Mrs. Malseed said, smiling as she greeted us again this year. She seems to know when guests are arriving because she is usually waiting in the large hall, which always smells of flowers. “Arthur, take the luggage up,” she instructed the old porter. She named our rooms after flowers: Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium. Instead of numbers, Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors. In winter, when few guests come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of little details like that, while her husband handles repairs and redecorating.

“Welcome, welcome!” Mr. Malseed said as he entered the hall from the kitchen. He greeted us warmly in the Irish way, smiling with his twinkling brown eyes, making us feel special, not just another group of guests. Everyone smiled, and I could sense that our holiday had truly begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was perfect. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. “You look younger every year!” she said, making everyone laugh again. 

Arthur led us to our rooms, carrying as much luggage as he could and returning for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while, but we didn’t play too long because we were still tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other guests at dinner, of course, because Glencorn Lodge is always full in June. From our table by the window, we could see some guests walking on the lawns and others taking the path down to the beach. 

In the morning, we planned to walk along the beach to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, returning in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. I knew this routine well because over the years, we had developed this pattern. Since we first came here, we had all fallen in love with the beautiful landscape in every season.

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, shares her experiences as a chalet girl in Val d'Isere, France. This is her second year in this role, where she cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in traditional wooden houses called chalets. Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University with a degree in French and History of Art. She views her job as a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent career. "It's a great way to meet successful people," she says.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. After having her own breakfast, she prepares a hearty meal for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. Once breakfast is finished around 9:30 a.m., she cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she finds the least enjoyable part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski, enjoying the slopes until about 4:30 p.m. 

After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner, taking a shower first. Dinner, which is a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m., followed by coffee at 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen, as she dislikes starting the next day with a messy space. Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer privacy. "Good guests can make the week enjoyable," she notes, while acknowledging that some weeks are less pleasant.

Sarah lives in a chalet with friends, and they usually go out around 11 p.m. They often start their night at a place called Bananas, then move to G Jay's, and finish at Dick's T-Bar. However, she avoids staying out too late on Saturdays because Sundays are her busiest days. "It's a tough day," she admits, especially when she has to cook breakfast with a headache.

On Sundays, breakfast for departing guests is served by 7 a.m. After they leave, Sarah quickly cleans the chalet, stripping beds and preparing for new guests. If she hasn't done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. By around 3 p.m., after finishing the cleaning, she prepares tea for the new arrivals, who usually come around 4:30 p.m. They often seem confused and full of questions, which Sarah finds amusing.

Between tea and dinner, she helps guests who need ski equipment by taking them to the ski shop and getting a ride back. As dinner time approaches, she prepares for her next shift, sometimes enjoying a drink afterward, but often she is too tired and goes to bed early.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small, pale girl who looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but she claimed to be six years older. One day, she visited his factory wearing overalls and large shoes, with her curly hair framing her pretty face. Seymour found it hard to believe that she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania and researching the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. 

Several times a year, someone would contact Seymour to ask if they could visit his factory. Sometimes, he would help students by answering their questions over the phone or giving them a short tour if they seemed particularly serious. Rita was almost as small as the children from Marie's third-grade class, who had visited the factory years ago to learn how gloves were made. Seymour remembered how fascinated Marie had been by the steam-heated brass hands used to shape the gloves, which she called "pancake hands."

Rita asked, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" Seymour replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She took notes and asked, "Do they come directly to your shipping department?" He explained, "They go to the tannery first. We buy the material, and they prepare it for us. My grandfather, father, and I all worked in the tannery here in town. Have you ever been inside a tannery?" 

"Not yet," she said. 

"You should visit one if you want to write about leather. I can arrange that for you. They are basic places. The technology has improved, but it’s not much different from what it was hundreds of years ago. It's tough work. Tanning is one of the oldest industries; there are artifacts from 6,000 years ago found in Turkey. The first clothing was just animal skins that were tanned by smoking them. It’s a fascinating subject. My father is an expert on leather; you should talk to him. He can talk for two days about gloves. Glovemakers are passionate about their work. Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?"

"I can't say I have," she replied.

"Never seen anything manufactured?" he asked.

"I saw my mother bake a cake when I was a child."

He laughed at her answer. She was innocent and eager to learn, reminding him of Marie, who was much taller than Rita but shared her good-natured intelligence. 

"I have an idea," he said. "We will take you through the entire glove-making process. Come on! We’re going to make you a pair of gloves, and you will watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?"

**Is It a Tough Job?** Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as great as they seem.

**A. Raquel Graham**  
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She cannot meet tomorrow because her boss needs her in Los Angeles. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she must travel around the world at a moment's notice. Raquel loves her job and has a good relationship with her boss, but there is one small issue: she dislikes flying. "On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help me relax," she confesses. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde, which felt too cramped with its small windows. When she is not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London, handling routine tasks like organizing schedules, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, and planning travel. She did not apply for this job; a chance meeting with a pop group manager led to her working behind the scenes, and she took a secretarial course in the evenings. Five years later, she was in the right place when her boss needed a personal assistant.

**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, which is someone who carries a golfer's bags. Overall, he prefers caddying because golf is his passion. However, there are downsides. He earns a small flat fee plus a percentage of the winnings, which averages between £25,000 and £35,000, but much of that goes to travel and hotels. He started caddying for golfer Greg Norman when he was 31. "You're not just carrying bags; you're giving advice, using your knowledge, and trying to understand the course," he explains. Recently, his accounting skills were recognized by European Tour Productions, which made him a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes statistics from the caddies, which are valuable to TV commentators, golf magazines, and the players.

**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' section of a daily newspaper, and one of his easier tasks is to taste food at top restaurants. What does he think about expensive restaurants? "For those who can afford it, it's their choice," he says. "I would rather spend £120 on a memorable meal than buy a microwave." His cooking talent led to a friend offering him a food column in a Saturday Review. At that time, he was the creative director of an advertising agency, and it provided him with extra income. When he was 42, another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant a 50% cut in guaranteed income," he says, "but it was a chance to turn my passion into a career." He still cooks at home and tries to stay fit by cycling a couple of miles to the nearest tube station.

**D. Dick Prince**  
"I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most beloved children's authors. "Before that, I loved words and enjoyed writing, but I mostly wrote poetry. Then I had an idea for a story. Having been a farmer, I understood the problem of chickens being killed by a fox. So, I wrote a story called *The Fox Busters*, which became my first published children's book." Where do his ideas come from? "It's not easy; I have to work for them," he explains. "I usually write in the mornings, but I don't wake up at dawn. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing what I wrote in the morning—all with one finger on an old typewriter instead of a laptop, which I dislike. I receive between 50 and 100 letters a week, and that is the part of being a writer I enjoy the most. I try to respond to all of them, but I now have some secretarial help."

In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were processed into boards for building, there stood an old two-story brick building. Surrounding it were large piles of soft sawdust, creating golden mounds that extended to the blue lake. That afternoon, feeling bored, a group of boys followed Michael up a ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs dangling over the edge, gazing at the lake. Suddenly, Michael challenged them, saying, "I dare you to jump down." Without thinking, he leaped off the roof and landed in the sawdust, rolling around and laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted, calling them cowards to encourage them to jump too.

Still laughing, he watched as they hesitated on the roof, looking nervous. One by one, they jumped down, relieved to land safely. In the warm afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust, sharing jokes until one of them suggested they go back up and jump again. Although they were not very excited, they climbed back to the roof and began jumping off in a determined manner. Soon, only Michael remained, while the others called up to him, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong?"

Michael wanted to join them but stayed at the edge of the roof, nervously licking his lips and grinning foolishly, wondering why the drop seemed so much longer this time. For a moment, they thought he was just joking, but then they noticed him clenching his fists. He tried to count to ten before jumping, but when that didn't work, he took a deep breath and closed his eyes. As time passed, the boys grew impatient and started to laugh at him, tired of waiting and aware that dinner time was approaching. "Come on, you're a coward! Do you think we're going to sit here all night?" they shouted. When he still didn't move, they began to leave, still teasing him.

"Who started this?" he called after them, but he remained on the roof, staring unhappily at the ground. He stayed there alone for nearly an hour as the sun set, growing larger and more orange as it sank beyond the lake. His clothes were damp from nervous sweat. Finally, he closed his eyes, jumped off the roof, and landed heavily in the sawdust, lying there for a long time. The yard was silent; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he had been unable to jump earlier. Eventually, he got up slowly and walked home, feeling ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone.

He arrived so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You should be able to get home on time by now. If you won't come home, maybe you should stay out tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a hint of gray in her hair, and a patient smile. Although she spoke firmly, Michael, with his dark, gloomy face, barely heard her; he was still imagining the grinning faces of his friends and hearing their laughter.

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy in your job and unsure how to change it? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people looking to change their careers seek help from a careers adviser. You will need to write a brief personal history and take several tests called 'psychometrics'. Afterward, you will receive a summary of the results, along with career suggestions and any retraining you might need.

I decided to try Career Analysts, a large organization that provides career advice. Taking the career test felt like being back in a science exam. I was in a group of about ten people, answering questions under time pressure. I reminded myself that it wasn't about passing or failing. It was difficult to see how the psychometric tests could accurately represent me. The tests included tasks like finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes.

After the tests, I had a long discussion with an adviser. Based on our conversation and the test results, he created a report with his observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of his conclusions, although I was a bit disappointed to learn that I had performed poorly in the scientific, technical, and practical tests. I’m glad I never became a nurse! However, it was comforting to hear that I had made the right choices regarding journalism.

Changing your career doesn’t always mean a complete shift. Last March, after losing her job as a marketing manager at a large insurance company, 25-year-old Donna Laney sought help from Career Analysts. She said, "Losing my job was a great chance for me to reflect on my career. I wanted to reassess my skills and interests." Some of the results surprised her. "I didn’t realize I had a talent for design. But I had to weigh the cost of retraining in design against my financial situation," she explained. Other suggestions included taking a year off to work in the Far East. Ultimately, she decided to use her existing skills and transition to a role that suited her better. She is now a Public Relations officer. While she believes she could have reached this point without Career Analysts, they helped her clarify what she truly wanted to do. She has recommended the service to several friends, all of whom are satisfied.

Not everyone finds success with career advice. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, said, "I was at a point in my career where I felt lost. I hoped a careers adviser would suggest something new. Although I received many ideas, I rejected them because they either meant a significant pay cut or required a lot of retraining. I didn’t learn anything new about myself." She felt that if she had shared the same information with a friend, they would have given her similar advice.

**Fun at the Dentist's?**

If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental clinic in Glasgow, you will notice bright, modern paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch where patients sit while he examines their teeth. Jerome points out that "Fifty percent of people only go to the dentist when they are in pain, instead of for regular check-ups. This is often because they are scared." To change this, he has worked to create a space where people feel comfortable. For instance, he decided not to wear a white coat, as many associate it with pain. He believes dental treatment should happen in a relaxed, interesting, and enjoyable atmosphere.

This approach may surprise many, as most people think of dental visits as painful or very formal. Jerome explains, "If patients are relaxed, entertained, and treated well, they will forget their past negative experiences." One of his innovative relaxation methods is using virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first dental practice in Britain to use them, and they are very popular. During the initial check-up, patients sit comfortably on the blue couch and watch a film about underwater wildlife while I check their teeth. Then, the headset switches to a special camera that gives them a visual tour of their mouth."

Interestingly, most patients seem to enjoy this part of their dental visit. Another important aspect is that the clinic smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's office. Today, it has a pleasant orange scent. Jerome explains, "When people enter, I want them to realize through all their senses that this is not a typical dentist's visit. Smell is very important. The usual dental smell can make people anxious if they are afraid of dentists." I found the gentle scent in the clinic very nice.

Although Jerome is known as Glasgow's most stylish dentist, he emphasizes that he takes his work seriously. While relaxation techniques are important, the quality of treatment is the top priority. For example, he uses a special tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth instead of scraping them. It may feel a bit unusual at first, but as long as patients are relaxed, it is not painful.

Five years ago, Jerome traveled to the United States to study dental techniques. "One thing I learned is that when you make it easier for the patient, it also makes it easier for you," he says. He believes his patient-focused approach is part of a gradual shift towards a less formal style in British dentistry.

At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes over, offers him a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks what video he would like to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this luxurious treatment, and it’s easy to see why. The clinic feels more like an elegant beauty salon than a typical dental practice.

**Bitter Water Hits the Big Time**

Chocolate, which originated in South America, is now a major global industry worth millions. In the UK, people spend over £230 million on chocolate during Easter, accounting for eight percent of all chocolate sales. Only Christmas sees more chocolate consumption. 

Although large-scale chocolate production started in the last century, the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over three thousand years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical evergreen found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and Southeast Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and contains 20 to 40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often mistakenly called cocoa beans, a misspelling from the 17th century when they were also referred to as cacoa and cocao beans.

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as currency and made a drink called xocoatl, which means "bitter water" in their language, Nahuatl. This drink was flavored with spices and used in ceremonies and to welcome guests. The Spanish found it more enjoyable when mixed with cinnamon and sugar, but this recipe did not reach the rest of Europe for another hundred years.

In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in major European cities where people gathered to drink chocolate. Until the last century, the drink was made by melting solid chocolate blocks in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from crushed beans. The modern chocolate bar began in 1847 when a company in Bristol, Fry and Sons, mixed cocoa butter with chocolate liquor and sugar to create a solid bar. A Swiss company later added milk solids, leading to the creation of milk chocolate.

At the turn of the century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their Birmingham factory Bournville, hoping to attract some French elegance. However, Cadbury's Dairy Milk bar, originally called Dairymaid in 1905, became popular due to clever advertising that linked it to the health benefits of milk from the English countryside, making it a competitor to luxurious French brands.

Currently, chocolate consumption in Britain seems to have stabilized at about four bars per week. This has prompted manufacturers to find new ways to attract customers. One recent strategy is the "extended line," where chocolate bars are transformed into ice cream, soft drinks, or desserts to appeal to chocolate lovers who are bored with traditional snacks.

On the other hand, cacao farmers are still struggling due to a drop in cocoa bean prices in the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers went out of business. So, as you enjoy your next chocolate bar, consider the challenges faced by those who grow cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

At 83 years old, Peter Cooke has become a skilled artist. He still has many interests, such as paper-making and feather-work, but for now, he focuses on creating beautiful objects from shells, a skill he has enjoyed developing over the last ten years. As he shows me his work in his apartment, he asks, "Tell me if I am boring you." There is a fine line between being boring and being passionate, but Cooke is clearly the latter, thanks to his charm and the beauty of his creations.

He points to some shell-covered decorations above his fireplace. "I won’t mind if people don’t buy them because I love them," he says. "I never intended to sell my work. About five years ago, some friends suggested I have an exhibition so others could see my art. They even spoke to a gallery owner." This led to a successful exhibition in London, where 70% of his pieces sold. His second exhibition opened yesterday, featuring 86 pieces, with prices starting at £225 for a shell flower in a crystal vase. Cooke claims he has no control over the prices and is open about them. He believes his work is unique, and the gallery owner told him, "One day you will stop, and everyone will want your pieces because there won’t be any more."

Cooke wishes he had started this art earlier in life, as he feels he could have created even more amazing things. Although he still has many ideas, he feels physically limited compared to when he began. However, his work is far from the typical shell crafts found in seaside shops. "I have a miniature mind," he says, which has led him to create boxes covered in thousands of tiny shells, shaded pictures made from shells, and baskets of incredibly realistic flowers.

He has developed his own techniques and uses materials he finds. For example, he uses cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, a special glue bought in bulk from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just happens," he explains, yet the detail, color variations, and symmetry in his work seem very intentional.

Cooke's search for beautiful, tiny shells has taken him beyond his local beaches in Norfolk to places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He insists that he only collects dead shells and defends himself against accusations of damaging the environment. "When I collect shells, I hear people stepping on them much faster than I can gather them. The sea also breaks them up. I would never take shells with living creatures in them or dive for them. Once the creatures have left, why shouldn’t I collect them?" His argument is convincing, especially considering the beauty he creates from the shells he collects.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

Kira Langer is a 15-year-old girl who models and appears on magazine covers. When she is not working, she studies for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw shares more about her.

The receptionist at Kira's agency told me she would be late. I thought about all the negative things I had read about models, like being difficult or vain. I worried she might not show up at all. But when Kira arrived, she was smiling and relaxed, accompanied by her mother. She wore a simple black dress and trainers, showing no signs of being spoiled. Kira seemed friendly and approachable.

Since models under 16 must have an adult with them, her mother was there, looking proud of her daughter. Kira seemed a bit surprised by her sudden fame, which was unexpected. It was her older sister who encouraged her to enter a modeling competition. Kira initially said no, but her sister sent in some photos anyway. When Kira learned she was a finalist, she was at school. This achievement boosted her confidence, and she performed well, winning the competition. The Select model agency in London quickly offered her work.

Kira now faces the challenge of balancing her modeling career with school life. Her friends and teachers are proud of her, but some classmates make rude comments about her success, saying she thinks too highly of herself. Kira finds this unfair, as she remains humble despite her achievements. She explains, "People think I’ve changed just because I’m a model, but I’m still the same person, just more confident."

Being a busy model affects her social life. The agency can call her at any time for a job the next day, making it hard for her to make plans with friends. However, her friends understand and don’t complain about her busy schedule.

Kira has the talent and support to have a successful career ahead of her, even before finishing her school exams. As I wrapped up the interview, I asked her what she would do if she didn’t have her looks. She paused and said, "I’d like to do what you’re doing."

**Father and Son Start Gold Rush**

Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from the cold north of Canada to the warm lands of Africa in search of valuable metals. This father and son team—one an explorer and the other a mineral expert—believe their mine on a Welsh mountain could hold up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they are sure they are very close to a gold vein worth five million dollars. Terence, 68, from Liverpool, said, "As we dig, we are finding high levels of gold; now we just need to dig a few more metres to where it is concentrated."

They have dedicated their lives to finding gold. Their journey began when Terence read about gold deposits worth millions in the "Dolgellau gold belt," an area near the town of Dolgellau in Wales. While studying 19th-century mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth, they chose the most promising land to explore. After clearing away plants and discovering gold pieces in the rocks, they spent the last ten years getting permission from landowners, taking soil samples, and removing old cars and trash. They dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to create a tunnel and a 10-metre shaft.

Now, they are running low on money. Having spent their savings on this dream, they need to convince an investor to contribute £50,000 to dig a bit deeper to reach the gold. Chris Madden mentioned, "At the moment, this looks doubtful, although we have several people we can contact."

As news of their dig spread through the valleys last week, the allure of gold began to attract the attention of local residents as well as other gold seekers. Dolgellau depends on tourism, and locals are cautiously optimistic. Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "If they are right, it would encourage more visitors here, but if they find gold, I hope millions of people don’t come and disturb the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has significantly declined since its peak in the late 1880s when thousands worked in many mines across the countryside. One of the last remaining mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, individual gold diggers are returning.
