George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel deep into the hill on the opposite side of the ridge from the Maddens. Hall, 70, said, "Searching for gold is very emotional. It’s adventurous and exciting, the thrill of uncovering hidden treasure. Maybe I’ll be lucky this time."

**IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which involves studying the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she descends into a small steel vehicle designed for underwater exploration, diving three kilometers down to study underwater volcanoes. 

Inside the vehicle, space is very limited, and she can touch the two pilots. They are accustomed to these cramped conditions, where they cannot stand or move freely, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last up to 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there is an emergency and they need to ascend quickly, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that rises quickly to the surface, similar to a ping-pong ball in water. Rachel notes, "No one has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a pleasant journey."

Rachel recalls her first experience in the vehicle. She climbed in on a ship's deck with an instructor, who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were assessing how she would handle being in such a confined space. Now, Rachel has completed six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew to a site five days west of the Canary Islands, where there is a large area of underwater volcanoes emitting black smoke. The Russian team was there to drop off scientific equipment for a project that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I enjoy, but I do it to support my research on the 'black smokers,'" another term for underwater volcanoes. These volcanoes release water that looks like black smoke at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees Celsius.

Rachel describes a frightening moment during her first dive with an American team. They were towing equipment when there was a sudden explosion, creating a loud bang that shook their vehicle. She thought, "I'm going to die." They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were overwhelmed with relief— they were still alive!

"Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is such an adventure. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, I feel a sense of wonder. Here I am at the bottom of the sea, witnessing something no one else on this planet has ever seen. I studied the black smokers for three years for my PhD, and seeing them in person was an incredible experience."

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a bit sunburned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was exhausted, and my mind was tired of dealing with foreign schedules, currencies, and languages. "Never again," I told myself as I returned home. I repeated this every year after. All I needed to do was buy one train ticket, and since I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. 

Once you learn to sleep in a train corridor, regular beds feel different. Carrying all your belongings in a rucksack makes you travel simply and can lead to wasteful habits, like burning socks that smell bad or throwing away finished books. However, this carefree attitude is part of the Inter-Rail spirit, where common sense can be set aside along with your paperback and socks. All it takes is one of those tickets in your hand. 

A system that allows young people to travel through multiple countries in a day is quite special. On my first trip, my friends and I didn’t realize the full potential of this train ticket; we thought it was just a cheap way to reach our campsite in southern France. But the idea of continuous travel was too appealing, as there was always another country just beyond the border. And the extra miles? They cost us nothing. 

We were not completely uninterested in culture, but this was our first holiday without parents, like many other Inter-Railers. In planning our own schedule, we focused only on the most accessible sights. It was a chance to avoid guided tours and do something different. I took pride in the fact that sometimes all I wanted to see was the view from the train station. We were just trying to get by and enjoy ourselves, just like most other Inter-Railers with whom we shared train corridors, food, water, money, and music. 

The thrill of travel comes from experiencing a place that was once just a name. It feels like the city you arrive in didn’t exist until the train pulls into the station, and you see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by witnessing Europe firsthand, observing the changing landscapes and different lifestyles, can you truly understand the continent. Everyone knows what is there, but it means little until you see it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos can be dull. While the train journey may not reveal new discoveries in the world, it offers a valuable personal experience. Europe is vast, and Inter-Rail provides the best chance to appreciate this, even if it didn’t happen for us right away.

Text: 'Arriving at an airport in another country only to find that your luggage is missing can be very disappointing. You might have to wear the same clothes for hours or even days until the airline returns your bags. If you are in a different climate, you may have to wear clothes that are not suitable for the weather. While airlines do not often share how many bags they lose, it is common for travelers to experience this issue at some point. Even the best airlines can make mistakes, and it is not always possible for them to ensure that your checked luggage travels on the same flight as you, especially if you have to change planes.

Airlines require passengers to check in early to give enough time for luggage to be processed and loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest times needed to switch between flights, and these are often extended to allow for baggage transfers. Usually, this system works well, but extra security checks and air traffic issues can lead to flight delays, which may disrupt the baggage system. Human errors, such as losing a destination label, can also happen. These problems are more likely at large airports, known as 'hubs', where many bags are handled. For instance, last year, Heathrow airport in London served over 41 million passengers, with nine million transferring to other flights. British Airways alone managed two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, most of whom had to walk a mile between terminals.

Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich can have issues. The risk of losing luggage during plane changes is higher at certain airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing bags when passengers make quick connections to Latin America. To reduce the chance of losing your luggage, choose direct flights when you can and check in early. If you must change planes, try to use the same airline for all your flights. Allow extra time for connections by taking an earlier flight, and make sure to label your luggage with your home and holiday addresses, including flight numbers.

If your luggage does go missing, contact the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

**The Kingfisher**

Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher, a stunning blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and feeds on fish. Old trees hang over the stream, providing shade to the shallow water. The main colors in this scene are soft greens, browns, and various shades of yellow from the sunlight, creating a peaceful atmosphere, much like the gentle sounds of water in the breeze. The kingfisher moves quickly and gracefully, like a flash of light, leaving a strong impression despite its small size. 

Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. His deep affection for this bird is evident in his struggle to explain what attracts him to it. The kingfisher is part of many legends. In Greek mythology, it is a moon goddess transformed into a bird. Another story suggests that the kingfisher flew so high that its upper body became the blue of the sky, while its underside was burned by the sun. There is some truth to this tale. Although kingfishers display various shades of blue, they do not have blue pigment in their feathers. Instead, the structure of their feathers scatters light, making them appear blue. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or rich emerald green depending on the light.

It is no surprise that many wildlife photographers are passionate about kingfishers. Their vibrant colors, combined with the fact that these birds are shy but can be observed from a distance, create a perfect opportunity for photographers. Charlie's first hideout was an old blanket he draped over himself while waiting near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird returned within minutes and sat just a meter away. However, it took him four more years to capture his first good photograph. During this time, the European kingfisher became a central part of his life. He spent as much time as possible by a stream filled with kingfishers, but school limited his time with them. He missed classes and considered himself an "academic failure." Nevertheless, his passion for this widespread kingfisher, the only one of its family that breeds in Europe, did not go unnoticed. At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine, later becoming an assistant editor, and eventually a freelance wildlife cameraman.

Now, Charlie dreams of creating the ultimate kingfisher film—one without narration, just beautiful images that convey everything. He prefers a simple approach and enjoys photographing parts of the kingfisher's wings. His thoughts drift as he reflects on the colors of the bird he has spent over half his life observing, which still captivate him. His photographs express some of his feelings, but Charlie knows that his work can never fully capture the depth of his connection with the kingfisher.

**Conducting an Orchestra: Insights from New Conductors**

Giving directions to an orchestra is challenging. Anne Inglis interviews five new conductors about their experiences.

**A. Anne Manson**  
Anne Manson, 30, asked to attend conductor Claudio Abbado's practice sessions in Vienna and unexpectedly ended up filling in for an absent assistant. This led to her conducting an orchestral rehearsal for Abbado. "I wasn't nervous," she said. "I have always felt confident in front of an orchestra." Manson, originally from America, works with a well-known opera company in London that focuses on modern music. She is also gaining recognition in other European countries, thanks to support from the British Arts Council. Since her first experience, she has assisted Abbado on several projects.

**B. Andrew Constantine**  
Andrew Constantine, 31, believes the hardest part of being a conductor is finding the right opportunities. He won a major competition in 1991 after two unsuccessful attempts. Reflecting on this, he feels fortunate about the timing: "If it had happened earlier, I might have been forgotten." The competition opened doors for performances and an assistant role with a famous conductor. However, he struggles with being labeled as a competition winner. "If in three years my name is still linked to the competition, I will be concerned," he said. Fortunately, orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra have invited him back, which is crucial for his career.

**C. Wasfi Kani**  
Wasfi Kani, who founded Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long rehearsal periods that come with opera productions. "The music deserves four weeks of focus," she said. Kani began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's commercial sector until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. A turning point for her was starting lessons with Sian Edwards. "I realized she was my size, unlike the larger conductors I had learned from before, which made a big difference." Kani appreciates the complexity of opera, noting the various personalities of singers and the many challenges involved.

**D. Roger Vignoles**  
Roger Vignoles, 48, describes his journey into conducting as surprising but fascinating. He began as a resident musician at an opera house and learned from skilled conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's *Agrippina* from the piano at a festival, an experience he had never tried before. "It was easier than I expected. I knew the music well and what I wanted it to sound like," he explained. Vignoles values every experience he has had in music and is open to trying new things to discover what he enjoys.

**E. Wayne Marshall**  
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed Wayne Marshall, then a young assistant conductor, and recommended him to his agent. Now 32, Marshall found himself conducting a musical in London on short notice, which was a tough start. He faced challenges, including professional musicians who were too relaxed during the performance. "I was firm with them. I always kept a clear beat and aimed for the best outcome," he said. Marshall believes many musicians do not need much guidance from a conductor, but he is not afraid to express his needs. "I've never formally studied conducting, and no book teaches you how to do it, but people have been supportive. I am determined and know what I like."

**Variations on a Theme**

If you are considering taking children to a theme park, there are many options in Britain. We asked five families to review some of the best parks.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**  
Last year, we visited a large theme park in the US and thought Fun Island might not be as exciting. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is designed for younger children, so our three-year-old felt included. The kids enjoyed the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young children, which was a big hit. For older kids, there are thrilling rides like Splash Out, where you end up in a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the children wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could use more atmosphere and better scenery. However, the staff were very helpful, and we found the park to be clean, well-organized, and focused on safety.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**  
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we were unsure what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and especially liked Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings. The older kids liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to relax. The landscaping was beautiful, and the staff were friendly and helpful. There was something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**  
After seven hours, we still felt there was more to explore. The children loved the Big Top Circus, which had an amazing trapeze act that kept us excited. We tried the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and kept their eyes closed, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, which looked like it would get you wet, but it didn’t. Toy Land was also a lot of fun for younger children. The kids wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved they were too small for it! The park is so well designed that even waiting in line for rides is not boring. It was very clean, and the staff were excellent. When I couldn’t sit with both girls on one ride, a staff member kindly went with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**  
We arrived at one o'clock and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This park is great for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I am quite timid, but I still had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slowly and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over too quickly! I wouldn’t try the Big Leap, but it looked thrilling if you are brave. If the children were a bit older, they might have found it less exciting, but they were the right age and enjoyed it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**  
According to the park's advertising, there is "No Limit to the Fun," and we definitely felt that was true. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, stands out, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride, while Jennie found the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older children went on multiple times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. We noticed that the staff's attitudes varied. Some were great with younger children, but the welcome was not always warm. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World, and we wouldn’t have dared tell the kids we were leaving early.

**Running a Business in the Countryside**

Five women share their experiences of starting businesses in rural areas.

A. **Christine Hogan** runs a computer-aided design business that earns over £200,000 a year and employs four full-time staff. She moved from London to the countryside with her husband when their children were young. Christine wanted a job she could do from home, so her husband suggested she start a design business. Although it required a lot of money and was challenging at first, she managed her finances carefully and communicated with her bank manager about spending. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings if needed. Her business remains small, and most customers pick up their orders directly.

B. **Maggy Sasanow** is a greetings card designer who works from home. She studied art at university and initially wanted to work in a museum, but after moving to the countryside, she decided to start her own business. She creates a collection of 50 cards that she sells to museums. Although working from home means there are always chores to do, like mowing the lawn, she enjoys her independence. She relies on word-of-mouth for customers and does not advertise. While she misses exchanging ideas with others, she finds more benefits than drawbacks in her situation.

C. **Delia Turner** runs a curtain-making business that has faced ups and downs. She started her business eight years ago when it was growing, and her income increased significantly in the first two years. However, due to an economic downturn, she had to let go of her six employees, which was difficult because jobs are scarce in her area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband’s help and collaborates with women who work from home. She must be flexible with her prices and explore new opportunities.

D. **Tessa Strickland** manages her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago to save money and because she loves rural life. She enjoys the freedom to work at her own pace, although 80% of her income comes from international deals, requiring her to take calls at unusual hours. The challenge is maintaining discipline to separate work from home life. Tessa publishes children's books from various cultures and initially felt isolated after moving from London.

E. **Meg Rivers** operates a cakes-by-post business and a shop that generates £250,000 a year, employing six people, some part-time. She started her business ten years ago at home, focusing on health by making fruit cakes with high-quality ingredients. After receiving requests from friends and family, she began shipping cakes nationwide. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where all baking is done, and she now manages the business side rather than cooking. Her main challenge has been financial, as she started with limited funds.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is special because they are all involved in music. The sons are talented composers and musicians, while their father, John, makes musical instruments. 

John and his wife, Hetty, are schoolteachers in South Wales. When they needed a cello for their son Paul, who was ten at the time, they found that buying one was very expensive. John thought about making a cello himself. He discovered the Welsh School of Instrument Making nearby and took evening classes for about three years. 

After trying to make violins and violas, John successfully created his first cello. Paul, now 28, remembers that it turned out great. John made another cello for Paul later, which he used until recently. John has now retired from teaching to focus on making instruments full-time, creating up to twelve violins each year. One of his violins was even sold to the famous American musician Jaime Laredo, which he considers a great achievement.

Both Paul and his younger brother, Huw, were encouraged to play music from a young age. Paul started with the piano: "As soon as I could reach the keys, I played," he recalls. However, he soon became interested in the cello. His parents wanted him to play the violin because John played the viola and needed another violinist for his music group. Paul tried the violin for a short time but preferred the cello after being inspired by a cellist in his father's group.

Huw, now 22, also found his own path in music. He appreciates that his parents were supportive without being pushy. Instead of feeling overshadowed by Paul's achievements, he saw them as motivation for his own success. Huw is now making a name for himself as a pianist and composer.

Paul has achieved great things with the cello his father made. He won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition and became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra at just 20 years old. He played his father's cello until last year, but now he has a new cello, a Francesco Rugeri, which is on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. 

Paul jokes that his father's cello might need 50 to 100 years to develop the same power as his new one, which is already 304 years old. Soon, he will perform on television with the Rugeri cello in Elgar's Cello Concerto. He believes that his performance style will remain unique, regardless of the cello's history.

However, Paul won't be able to watch his performance on TV because he will be playing at the Cheltenham Festival that same night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will premiere in London at the Wigmore Hall. John and Hetty will have to be very organized to keep up with all their sons' musical events in the coming weeks.

**Looking After the Countryside: The National Trust**

The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and speaks with Gareth Roberts, a warden who works for the Trust to care for its beautiful areas.

According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense and good people skills because they interact with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and construction companies regularly. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the warden position, but Gareth's local knowledge and farming experience helped him get the job, even though he did not have formal training. He says, "It helps that I still farm with my parents, so I understand farmers' issues and they can't fool me!"

His farming background also prepares him for the physical aspects of the job, such as building fences, planting trees, and constructing walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers collecting flowers, butterfly larvae, and birds' nests as a child and now realizes how farming has changed the countryside. He believes it is not the farmers' fault; they were just following government instructions.

When Gareth started, farmers and conservationists often disagreed. Both groups wanted things done in their own way. Now, they are communicating and understanding each other better. Gareth says, "We are at a turning point, and it only takes a small step to bring them together."

Gareth's work focuses on conservation, allowing public access to Trust land, planting and caring for trees, and working with tenant farmers. He aims to complete tasks efficiently and enjoys seeing projects finished, although he spends about half his time on paperwork and bills.

Gareth is passionate about his job and enjoys every moment, especially interacting with the public. However, he finds some visitors frustrating. "Some people come in, demand everything, and leave as if they have a right to it. Being polite to them can be annoying!" he admits. But, as Gareth says, it all comes down to common sense.

If you have plenty of common sense and enjoy outdoor work, you might consider applying to be a warden like Gareth. Just be aware that there may not be a position available on the Lleyn Peninsula for quite some time!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met Kendra Slowinski, the captain of England's netball team. When I spoke with her, she was busy preparing for the World Championships next month. Her day included teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I asked her if people stared at her while she trained. She replied, "I’m so focused on my movements and my feet that I don’t notice much else. I might see cars slowing down out of the corner of my eye, but that’s it."

Kendra explained, "My life right now is all about being at my best for the Championships. I follow a strict schedule to get as fit as possible." This will be her fourth World Championships, which will be the largest yet, with 27 countries participating. "Having home support is very special," she said. "It’s important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and will support us more. People want us to start the tournament with a strong performance."

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we have always won against them, but they will be exciting to play. They have a lot of talent." Currently, the England team is ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra noted that the World Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day; there’s no break between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different. You only get one chance, and you must be ready to take it."

In the fifteen years she has played at a high level, the sport has become more intense and faster. Players are now more aggressive on the court. Kendra said, "You don’t train hard just to lose. But once the game is over, we become friends again." 

Netball is also using more scientific methods for fitness testing. Kendra stated, "It’s crucial that we think and train like world-class players. As captain, I believe it’s important to have a strong mindset and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging my teammates."

Kendra mentioned, "From the start of my netball career, everything has been carefully planned. I decided a while ago that this competition would be my last as a player." She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she will probably have tears in her eyes.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How can parents support a child with exceptional musical talent? It can be challenging to know how to nurture their abilities. Some parents might not recognize their child's needs until frustration leads to difficult behavior. While most schools can help academically gifted children, musically talented kids often need special attention that regular schools may not provide, especially if music is seen as less important.

Children who are musically gifted, or whose talents are encouraged by their parents or teachers, may benefit from attending a specialist music school. In Britain, there are five such schools, which have been established recently. These schools create a supportive environment for children aged seven to eighteen to fully develop their musical skills under the guidance of professional musicians.

At specialist music schools, students spend about one third to one half of their day on music-related activities. This includes individual lessons (up to three hours a week for their main instruments), playing in orchestras and chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and music theory. They also practice in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their day is filled with a limited academic curriculum focusing on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages, although students can study more subjects if they wish.

All five British specialist music schools are independent, with small class sizes and a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students live at the school, which allows them to spend their formative years with peers who share similar goals and interests.

However, there are some drawbacks. One major issue is the cost, with fees ranging from £12,000 to £17,000 a year for boarders. Each school tries to help families with scholarships and financial aid for exceptionally talented children. Additionally, not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many school directors question whether it is wise to admit children as young as seven into such a demanding environment. They emphasize that their goal is to develop well-rounded individuals.

It is important to note that separating musically gifted children from their peers at an early age can create stress. Some children may lose their musical abilities during their teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to feelings of failure. However, specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and provide support when needed.

While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some have concerns about the limited academic focus, which often takes a back seat to music. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, so they may feel frustrated if their intellectual needs are not met.

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until a child is older and can make their own choices before pursuing a specialist education. Children who are also academically gifted can thrive in a regular school with a strong music program or by combining a standard school routine with music training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with excellent teachers, along with orchestral and chamber music experiences. However, this option may not be feasible for families living far from London or other major cities.

**An Eye for Detail**

Artist Susan Shepherd is well-known for her flower paintings, which are inspired by the large garden around her house. This garden is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The two long flower borders along the paved path that runs from east to west are beautifully arranged in terms of color, shape, and structure. This beauty is partly due to the previous owners, who were passionate gardeners and left behind plants that Susan loves. She also inherited the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' about some of the things I wanted to add, but when I told him I wanted to paint them, he understood my vision."

Susan prefers to create detailed studies of individual plants rather than painting the entire garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants in their natural setting, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which can take a few days, and then I bring in another one to add to the painting. Sometimes, it takes a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is in spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all bloom together, and it's a hectic time," she says. However, she finds beauty in the gradual decay of the flowers. For instance, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, and after a day, they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, they seem dull, but they transform with twists and turns."

Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside," she recalls. "I wasn't really interested in gardening back then; I didn't like garden flowers because they reminded me of fake ones sold in florists. To me, only wildflowers were real. I was fascinated by how they could grow in tough places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."

Today, her garden features many plants from distant lands, which thrive just as well in her garden as they do in their native environments, like China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed approach to gardening, similar to a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious trouble. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of inspiration right outside her door, finding time to work in the garden has been challenging. She now hires an extra gardener, but she understands that to stay connected to her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, shares her experiences as a chalet girl in Val d'Isère, France. This is her second year in this role, where she cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in traditional wooden houses called chalets. Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University with a degree in French and History of Art. She views her job as a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent career. "It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week," she explains.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. After having her own breakfast, she prepares a hearty meal for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. By 9:30 a.m., after the guests have finished breakfast, she cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea or cleans the rooms, which she finds the least enjoyable part of her job. By around 11 a.m., she is ready to ski herself, enjoying the slopes until about 4:30 p.m.

After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but avoids napping, as she believes it would make her feel worse. Dinner, which consists of three courses, is served at 8 p.m., and coffee follows by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen, as she dislikes starting the next day with a messy space. Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer privacy. "Good guests can make a week fantastic," she says, noting that some weeks are not as enjoyable.

Sarah lives in a chalet with friends, and they often go out around 11 p.m. They usually start their night at a place called Bananas, then might visit G Jay's and finish at Dick's T-Bar. However, she avoids staying out too late on Saturdays because Sundays are her busiest days. "It's a tough day," she admits, "when you definitely don’t want to be cooking breakfast while feeling tired."

On Sundays, Sarah starts work earlier, needing to have breakfast ready for guests by 7 a.m. Once the guests leave, she cleans quickly, clearing breakfast, stripping beds, and preparing for the next group. If she hasn’t done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. By around 3 p.m., after finishing the cleaning, she prepares tea for the new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they seem confused and have many questions, which she finds amusing.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski equipment by taking them to the ski shop and getting a ride back. Soon, it’s time for dinner again, and she may chat with friends, but sometimes she is too tired and goes to bed early.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie, a zookeeper, spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing my outfit for Marie Claire was difficult because I usually wear a uniform at the zoo. I first went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is a calm place, and I felt rushed here when I could be quietly spending time with an animal. Some fashion team members seemed stressed, but my job is not very stressful. During a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I found it funny to think that I would normally be cleaning cages or handling rats. I am interested in how magazines operate, but I really enjoy my job at the zoo, so I will stay there."

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived at the zoo in my leather boots and dark blue trousers. They gave me a green polo shirt to wear, which was good because I got very dirty. While petting an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably organizing clothes in a cupboard. By five o'clock, I was dirty but had a fantastic day. When I retire from fashion, I could see myself working with elephants, maybe in Africa."

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, worked with the television gardening show Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was very nice. I enjoyed being outside because I sometimes don’t see daylight due to my shifts. Even though it was hard work, it was a lot of fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. My idea of gardening didn’t include hard physical work or careful planning. I am more enthusiastic than effective at gardening, so I don’t plan to leave my nursing job."

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener on Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and distributed medicine. I thought I might faint during some tasks, but I surprised myself by handling it well. The camaraderie among the nurses was great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is less meaningful compared to nursing. My day at the hospital wasn’t pleasant, but it gave me a strong sense of satisfaction."

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and as soon as I wore it, I felt different—people looked up to me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my fitness training. When passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I handed out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt very self-conscious. On the return flight, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn’t sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult to manage them."

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was nervous about this swap because I don’t exercise. I was surprised by how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. At lunch, I noticed that some trainers didn’t eat very healthily, but they all drank a lot of water. I wouldn’t change my job for this, but it has motivated me to join a gym and try to be healthier."

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories**

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as possible. There is a local train from Cannes that travels along the coast and crosses into Italy. It offers stunning views of the sea, and no matter the weather or season, the journey is always magical. Out of the other window, you can see beautiful gardens and homes, making you feel like you are peeking into the lives of the wealthy. The passengers are always lively, a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the breathtaking scenery.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have had many wonderful train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels through the northern Sudan desert. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. When I moved to England as a teenager, I had never been on a train. London Waterloo was the first station I saw, and its large glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am grateful to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On that train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone said that pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since. The journey was lovely, traveling through France and then by boat up the Nile. It was the perfect way to relax after all the wedding planning.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on articles about a round-the-world trip and needed to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express. The schedule was unpredictable; we were just told to be ready on a certain day. The driver often waited for passengers, even if it took days. When the train arrived, many people rushed to get on, and some even traveled on the roof for free. At night, the train passed through some of the most beautiful landscapes I have ever seen, like a dream.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite memories of trains as children, but that’s not my story. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn’t until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film that featured a railway in Yorkshire, mostly filming on an old, well-kept section of the line maintained by volunteers. That’s where my love for steam trains began. When we weren’t filming, we took every chance to ride the train, and when I returned last year, everything felt the same, even the gas lights on the station platform!

Are you trying to get your work published? If you’re unsure where to send your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs has some helpful advice. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I have written a story or book. Who should I send it to?" One important thing to remember is that you need to research your target market and learn about publishers while also improving your writing skills. Turning your writing into something that can be sold requires a good understanding of the publishing world.

No matter what type of writing you do, it’s essential to know the markets you want to reach. You can do this in several ways, but the best method is to read as much relevant material as you can. Visit your local library and explore nearby bookstores and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what types of writing publishers are currently accepting. 

As time passes, you should keep updating your knowledge because new publications are always emerging—editors change jobs, and magazines shift their focus. Publishers are always looking for fresh talent, so as a writer, you need to provide what they want. 

If you’re unsure about what to write, for example, if you think you might want to write short love stories, the first step is to find out which magazines publish love stories, a rather limited market today. Get recent copies of those magazines and learn about the types of stories they buy, paying attention to their readers' expectations. The editor’s goal is to meet the needs of their audience.

Writers often ask me, "This has been rejected three times—am I wasting my time? Do I have a chance?" As a former teacher, I would never discourage anyone, but it’s likely that the work isn’t ready for publication. I try to give honest feedback while remaining positive. Many new writers are too eager to submit their work before they are truly prepared. If you’ve only written one story or article, it’s very unlikely to be published. This is rare. When you hear about someone’s success, they often have years of experience in publishing or journalism behind them.

When you finally send out your work for the first time, start writing more while you wait for a response. Write ten more stories, or even twenty. Each one will improve your skills, and you will start to see yourself as a writer, which will boost your confidence. Instead of discarding any of your work, focus on improving it. I also recommend not sharing your work with others in the early stages. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before achieving success.

Do everything you can to advance your writing career. Look for creative writing courses in your area. If you can’t find one, consider joining a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence by connecting with other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if possible.

**No Title**

On the last day of a difficult year, I was leaning against a pillar in the Baltimore train station, waiting for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people than I expected. The usual clean and bright atmosphere of the station was gone. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and groups of college students had left their bags all over the floor. A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to different strangers. He looked well-off: he had tanned skin, a nice sweater, and a soft beige coat. 

He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. Then he came over to a girl near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought I might like to talk to her. The man asked, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" The girl replied, "I’m going north, but to New York." "Thanks anyway," he said and moved on. Now I was really paying attention. 

He asked an old lady, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" When she said she was going to Wilmington, he just walked on to a couple with matching luggage. I straightened up and moved closer, pretending to look at the platform. I was going to Philadelphia, and I wondered why he didn’t ask me. I guessed he thought I looked unreliable. He glanced at me quickly and then went to the other end of the waiting area. He seemed stressed now. 

"Please!" he said to a woman reading a book. "Tell me you’re going to Philadelphia!" She looked up from her book. She was in her thirties, maybe thirty-five, and looked like a school teacher. "Philadelphia?" she said. "Yes, I am." 

"Could I ask you a favor?" I stood a few feet away, pretending to check my wrist, even though I didn’t have a watch. I could tell she was becoming cautious. The man must have noticed too, because he said, "Nothing too difficult, I promise!" 

They announced my train, and people started moving toward Gate E, older couples pulling their wheeled bags like pets on leashes. I heard the man talking. "My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, stopped for groceries, and came home to find my wife upset. She hardly said 'hello' to me. My daughter forgot her passport and called from the station in Philadelphia, not knowing what to do." 

The woman nodded sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet to see where this was going. "So I told her to stay put in the station, and I would get someone to bring her passport." 

I thought this story sounded suspicious. Why didn’t he go himself if it was such an emergency? The woman asked, "Why don’t you go yourself?" 

"I can’t leave my wife alone for that long. She’s in a wheelchair." I thought this was a weak excuse. It seemed like too much bad luck for one family. I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a simple envelope, but a padded one, the size of a paperback book. Aha! Padded! You couldn’t feel what was inside! From where I stood, it looked stapled shut too. I silently warned the woman to be careful.

**Gary and Me**

John Moore, the owner of a restaurant, shares his thoughts about his son Gary, who is a well-known TV chef. John believes that everyone has opportunities in life. For him, it was running a restaurant, and for Gary, it was cooking. When John found out about a restaurant for sale, he quickly went to see it, even though it was in poor condition. He thought it was just right for his plans.

Running the restaurant reminded John of his childhood. He remembered feeling sad when his mother went to work in a factory and left him alone. This made him want to ensure his family had time together. While John managed the restaurant, his wife took care of their children and handled the finances. They lived above the restaurant and always made it a point to have meals together, which helped their sons, Gary and Joe, grow up confident. From a young age, they would interact with regular customers, giving them a strong start in life.

Gary was an energetic child. When he was about seven, he tried to jump into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and accidentally knocked himself out. As he grew older, he earned pocket money by doing small jobs. By the age of ten, he was working in the kitchen every weekend, which meant he always had money at school. He was disciplined and often woke up before his father. In a family business, everyone contributes, and John appreciated Gary's help.

Although Gary did not excel academically, he was very talented in the kitchen. By 15, he was as skilled as the adult chefs and sometimes even managed the kitchen. He could prepare over a hundred meals, and John realized that Gary had a future in catering. When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant.

Recently, Gary started playing the drums and formed his own band. John wonders what will happen to Gary's cooking if his music career takes off. He advised Gary to focus on one goal at a time, saying, "If you chase two hares, you catch neither." John also told him that if he wanted to achieve something significant, he needed to do it by the age of 30.

At 17, Gary attended catering college. On his first day, while other students struggled, Gary quickly chopped vegetables and sliced meats, finishing his tasks in just an hour. He even helped his classmates. John is amazed by how successful Gary's TV cooking show has become and feels very proud of him. He has always encouraged Gary to work hard for what he wants because nothing is given for free. Gary recognized the opportunity he had and took full advantage of it.

As parents, we hope our children listen to our advice. Even if they only remember a small part of what we say, we should be grateful. John feels that Gary has listened and learned from him.

Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very difficult, almost like finding gold during a gold rush. The best way to find a place is through personal connections. If you know someone who knows someone leaving a flat, that can help. But if, like Jo, you have just arrived in Dublin, you don’t have those connections. You have to stay in a hostel and search for a place. For Jo, Dublin felt completely new and unfamiliar. She felt like she was entering a new world when she took the train to work there. She didn’t question why she was going; everyone she knew from school expected her to leave. Who would want to stay in a small, remote town? That’s what she had heard for years. Her friends wanted to escape, experience life, and have a real existence. Some of her classmates had moved to nearby towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family members helped them settle in. But Jo was going to Dublin alone.

Jo’s mother thought it would be great if she stayed permanently in the hostel run by nuns, believing it was safe. Her father hoped the hostel would be warm, as they are often cold. Jo’s sisters, who worked as waitresses in a hotel, thought she was crazy for staying a whole week in a hostel. However, Jo was unaware that they were still thinking about her as she responded to an advertisement for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was very close to her workplace and seemed too good to be true. She hoped it would be nice, that they would like her, and that it wouldn’t be too expensive. There wasn’t a line for this flat because it was more about finding a "Third Girl Wanted" than just a flat to rent. The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked ordinary—a red-brick terraced house with a basement. The flat was upstairs, and as Jo climbed the stairs, a cheerful girl with a college scarf came down. 

"Desperate place," she told Jo. "They’re both awful. Common as dirt." 

"Oh," Jo replied and continued up. 

"Hello," said the girl wearing a T-shirt with "Nessa" on it. "Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can’t stand her kind." 

"What did she do?" Jo asked. 

"She didn’t do anything. She just looked around, made a face, giggled, and said, 'Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear,' in a posh accent. We wouldn’t want her here, would we, Pauline?" 

Pauline, wearing a very colorful shirt, looked like a punk, which surprised Jo. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but had never talked to one before. 

"I’m Jo, I work at the post office and called about the flat," she said. 

Nessa mentioned they were about to have tea and brought out three mugs—one with "Nessa," one with "Pauline," and one labeled "Other." 

"We’ll put your name on a mug if you come to stay," she said kindly.

**Behind the Dolphin's Smile**

People have a strong affection for dolphins. We enjoy watching them in seaside areas, movies, and TV shows. However, the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society reports that dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds discusses the decline of dolphin populations.

Dolphins are special to us. They are among the smartest animals, sensitive to human feelings, and they inspire us with thoughts of freedom in the ocean. Our love for dolphins has been fueled by television shows like "Flipper" and "Seaquest," featuring a dolphin named Darwin. Yet, these cheerful images hide the harsh reality of dolphins living in polluted and overfished waters.

For example, the population of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has decreased by up to 89,000. You might think that such beloved animals would be protected by laws and cared for in marine reserves, but this is not happening. The lack of protection for dolphins could lead to one of the biggest wildlife disasters of our time.

There are forty different species of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common types are striped dolphins, common dolphins, bottlenose dolphins, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The first two types usually live far out at sea and are rarely seen, so we know little about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises were once frequently seen near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and used to be found along the Channel coast and in rivers like the Thames. Now, they can only be found in small numbers in places like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few remaining dolphins show signs of stress, such as skin injuries.

Understanding why dolphin numbers are declining is complicated. Overfishing is drastically reducing fish populations, which threatens both local fishing industries and dolphins. Porpoises need to find food quickly, and if fish are removed from one area, they may not have enough time to find food elsewhere. They also risk getting caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. Modern fishing methods often use large nets that can trap dolphins. In recent years, many dead dolphins have washed up on beaches in France and Cornwall, with injuries indicating they were caught in these nets.

Dolphins can also accumulate harmful substances from the sea in their bodies. For instance, pesticides can dissolve in fat, allowing dolphins to absorb them. This can lead to female dolphins producing milk that contains high levels of these toxins, which can poison their young. There has already been a case of a young dolphin dying from its mother’s contaminated milk.

Another significant threat to dolphins comes from human activities. Dolphins live in groups and rely on sound to understand their environment. Noise pollution from ships and oil drilling travels more effectively underwater than in the air, which may disturb dolphins in ways we do not fully understand.

**GETTING FIT**

Exercise is important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced, especially when life feels chaotic. You might be tired of hearing about fitness, but there are many good reasons to exercise, and very few reasons not to.

Exercise improves your muscle tone and can quickly change your body shape. It makes your muscles stronger and helps you maintain good posture, which is how you hold your body when sitting or standing. It also prevents muscle imbalances that can lead to injuries and improves specific areas like your thighs, stomach, and upper arms. Additionally, exercise benefits your heart, lungs, and blood circulation.

You may have heard these benefits before, but here’s something that might catch your attention: exercise can help reduce feelings of depression and tiredness, and it helps regulate your sleep. It is also effective in managing stress and can relieve certain medical conditions. 

If you’re still not convinced, just think about it—common sense tells us that exercise is good for us. There are many types of exercise you can try, such as aerobics, calisthenics, jogging, and weight training. However, be careful not to overdo it; training too hard can lead to injuries. It’s wise to start slowly and consult your doctor if you’re unsure about what’s best for you.

Good posture is crucial for improving your body shape. Poor posture can make you look unattractive and can drain your energy, making you more prone to minor health issues. If you tend to slouch, picture a helium balloon pulling the top of your head upward. This can help you lift your chest for better breathing and make your body appear slimmer.

Stretching is also important. It increases flexibility and helps you move easily, while preventing injuries from overuse. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will become more flexible and fit. Stretching should be a key part of your exercise routine, done slowly and carefully.

The best exercise routine includes a good warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**

What makes filmmakers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their comfortable homes for months? They are searching for the perfect shot. Among all the animals in the jungles and plains of East Africa, Amanda and Owen are some of the hardest to find. Currently, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has experienced six months of almost constant rain, leading to unexpected challenges. Newman mentioned that they had to buy an expensive piece of equipment so that if one of their vehicles gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him back to safety. Their collaboration has produced some of the best wildlife films on television, including a well-received documentary about leopards. While this film was being shown, they were already back in the field, this time tracking the shy jackal.

This kind of travel is common for filmmakers, who have been exploring the world to capture exotic wildlife since television began. I spoke with Newman during one of his rare meetings with other people at a safari lodge. He said, "We do have occasional arguments, but we usually resolve them quickly." Neither sees themselves as the leader, and he believes their strong partnership comes from their shared perspective on animals. "When we travel, we set up our tents each night. But this time, we are more stationary, so we prepare tea the night before and keep it warm in a vacuum flask." Their daily meals consist of pre-packaged food that is heated and served by whoever is available. "It's not unusual for us to be out for up to eight weeks, so meal preparation can be stressful," Newman explained. 

Although their lifestyle can be tough, the chance to be in remote areas allows them to get close to the animals. He recalled a time when they were filming a lion family, and one lioness would often wander off. When she returned, she would greet all the pride members, and eventually, she included their vehicle in her greetings.

Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift," and two years later, they teamed up to film Arctic foxes. Since then, they have learned to spend four months in the field to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they can start, they must submit a script for approval. "Amanda and I developed a strong working relationship from the beginning," Newman said, "because we share the same ideas and vision. We aim to create films that are rich in atmosphere, capturing the true spirit of the place and its animals, and that resonate emotionally with viewers. I believe evoking an emotional response is more impactful than simply appealing to logic."

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met Kendra Slawinski, the captain of England's netball team. When I spoke with her, she had just finished a typical day of teaching at a local school, followed by a training session in a supermarket parking lot. I was surprised by her choice of training location. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I'm so focused on my movements and my feet that I don't notice much else. I might see cars slowing down out of the corner of my eye, but that's it."

Kendra explained, "My entire life right now is about being at my best for the Championships." She follows a strict schedule to achieve maximum fitness. This will be her fourth World Championships, and it is expected to be the largest yet, with 27 countries participating. "Having home support is very special," she said. "It's important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and will support us more. People want us to start the tournament with a strong performance."

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra noted, "We have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play against because they have a lot of talent." Currently, the England team is ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra emphasized that the World Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day; there’s no break between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different. You only get one chance, and you must be ready to take it."

In the fifteen years since she started playing at a high level, the sport has become more intense and fast-paced. "You don’t train hard just to lose," Kendra said. "But once the game is over, we become friends again." 

Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. Kendra stated, "It’s crucial that we all think and train like world-class players. As captain, I believe it’s important to have a strong mindset and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging my teammates."

Kendra mentioned, "From the start of my netball career, everything has been carefully planned." She decided some time ago that this competition would mark the end of her playing career. She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her last major event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she will probably have tears of joy, knowing her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

**In Hot Water**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of her time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which involves studying the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she descends into a small steel vehicle designed for underwater exploration, diving three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.

Inside the vehicle, Rachel explains, "The space is so limited that I can reach out and touch the two pilots. We cannot stand up or move around, and we must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface."

If there is an emergency and she needs to ascend quickly, Rachel can press a panic button. This action releases a small escape vessel that rises to the surface quickly, similar to a ping-pong ball in water. Although no one has tested this escape method yet, Rachel doubts it would be a pleasant experience.

Rachel recalls her first time in the vehicle, which was on a ship's deck. An instructor guided her through emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were assessing how she would react in such a confined space. Now, Rachel has completed six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew to a site five days west of the Canary Islands, where there is a large area of underwater volcanoes emitting black smoke. The Russian team was there to drop off scientific equipment for a project that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I enjoy, but I do it to support my research on 'black smokers,' another term for underwater volcanoes. These volcanoes release water that looks like black smoke at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees."

The only time Rachel felt scared was during her first dive with an American team. They were towing equipment when suddenly there was an explosion, creating a massive bang that shook their vehicle. She thought, "I'm going to die." They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, the relief was overwhelming—they were still alive!

Diving to the ocean's deepest parts is an adventure for Rachel. Each time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. "Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before." After studying black smokers for three years for her Ph.D., seeing them in person was an incredible experience.

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Research shows that people form opinions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body language, and how we speak, including our speed, volume, and tone, as well as the words we use.

Mary Pearce studied to become a teacher. She worked hard to earn her degree and felt confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. On the day of the interview, she noticed a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing but decided it would make her late, and she believed being on time was very important. Unfortunately, Mary did not get the job. A friend who worked at the school told her that the Head Teacher commented, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher will she be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, explains that candidates who take care of their appearance are more likely to care about their jobs. While many believe that what matters is inside, it is essential to present yourself well in an interview.

Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but did not even get an interview. She thought it was a mistake and asked the Director of Personnel what happened. He told her she did not fit the image of an office manager and suggested she improve her wardrobe before applying again. Janet was shocked because she believed her work performance should matter more than her appearance.

Movement and gestures also affect how an interviewer perceives a candidate. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that only 7% of our message about feelings comes from the words we use, 38% from our voice, and a surprising 55% from our facial expressions. When our words and facial expressions send different messages, the listener will pay more attention to the non-verbal signals. Therefore, it is important that your words match your body language. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.

It is also crucial not to seem too desperate for the job or overly eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, had a great interview for a promotion and was offered the job immediately. She was very excited, but her enthusiasm led the boss to offer her a lower salary than she expected. She believes she could have negotiated a better salary if she had controlled her excitement.

Finally, what you say and how you say it can greatly affect your interview success. David Artesio, a manager at an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. For example, reading the annual report can provide insights into the company's activities. Mentioning an area of interest during the interview can show your enthusiasm for the company.

Business consultant Marian Woodall advises preparing a few questions and avoiding long, confusing sentences. She states, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators use short sentences and highlight key points."

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He says, "After 14 years in the City, it became boring and no one was enjoying their work anymore. I didn’t plan to leave for another five or ten years, but then I lost my job unexpectedly. I didn’t receive a great severance package, but it was enough to start my farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a well-known hotel restaurant. By supplying them with meat, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat online. I’m happy to be out of the office, but surprisingly, my life hasn’t changed much: I still work 80 to 90 hours a week and sell a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Able White was a manager in advertising, but now he makes a living as an artist. He explains, "I started painting as a hobby and found it much more exciting than my job. Choosing to leave my job and become an artist felt like the right choice. A career counselor I spoke to was very supportive. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their forties need to find work quickly for financial reasons. My wife and I married young, and our children are now independent, so we took a risk and moved to northern England, where we didn’t know anyone. We left our friends behind, but luckily, our friendships have lasted, and many visit us now."

**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business from her flat in London. She shares, "Being a lawyer was enjoyable and well-paid, but the hours were awful. I realized I didn’t want to become a senior partner and work even longer hours, so I decided to leave. Many people thought I would get bored, but that has never happened. The key is to set deadlines. In the fashion business, there are always collections and new designs to work on, so I keep a strict schedule. I feel happier and less stressed now, but I do miss the social interaction with colleagues. What I love about this job is that I am fully responsible for my work. If I do a poor job, I am the one to blame. When you work for a company, you care, but when your name is on the product, you care even more."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He says, "I was in finance from the age of 22, making deals. I enjoyed the excitement, but I never found it fulfilling. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I chose to resign and travel for a year. During that time, I figured out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited top gyms and spoke to their owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took various massage courses. Eventually, I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my life, which is the best part."

**Dedicated to Their Sports**

Four young athletes share their experiences.

**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I have always been active in sports. I tried many, but I excelled in football and athletics. At 14, I had a chance to join a professional football team, but I chose to focus on athletics instead. My proudest moment was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it didn’t attract much media attention, which was disappointing. I hoped to gain sponsorship, as training can be expensive. I train at home during the winter and then spend three weeks in Florida before the season starts. It’s enjoyable because the facilities are excellent and the nightlife is fun. However, I must be disciplined. If friends invite me out the night before training, I have to decline. I wish I didn’t have to, but dedication is essential in this sport. My main goal is to qualify for the next Olympics—that would be amazing.

**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I often see the same people at competitions. Professional surfers take their sport seriously, and the best waves are usually at dawn, so I avoid late-night parties. I don’t mind this too much, but I do miss sleeping in. However, it’s worth it because my dedication helped me win the National Championships last year. After a win, I always celebrate with a big night out, and if I win money, I treat myself to a nice getaway. The sacrifices pay off in the long run, as winning the championship led to me hosting a surfing series on TV. I suppose I’ve become somewhat of a celebrity now.

**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
Being on a boat with my teammates is always fun. We have a traditional way of celebrating our victories. Some say we act a bit immature when we celebrate, but we don’t seek media attention. Often, reporters seem more interested in our celebrations than our race results. I spend eight months a year away, so it’s nice to return home and hang out with friends from different backgrounds. It’s important to have a balance; you can’t be focused on sailing all the time. I’m recognized in the sailing world, but thankfully, I’m not often recognized in public. I wouldn’t want to be a celebrity. I do receive many nice letters from fans asking for autographs, and I make sure to reply to each one, even if it takes time.

**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It’s always exciting to step onto the court and feel the support of the crowd. However, at my last tournament, things got a bit overwhelming with fans crowding around. I enjoy being recognized by fans when I’m out shopping, but it has its challenges. My last girlfriend didn’t like it when I received too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that contributed to our breakup. It was tough, but sacrifices are necessary in any sport; you must be serious and professional. I’m focused on my game now and plan to enjoy other aspects of life after I retire, which comes relatively early in this sport.

**Young Shoppers**

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother describes it as "absolute murder." Her children want everything they see, whether it's the newest sugary cereal, a Disney video, or a comic book—often all three. She feels guilty for buying unhealthy items but also hates saying no all the time. This makes her feel frustrated before they even leave the house. She tries to avoid taking them shopping, but worries that she is not letting them learn how to make their own choices. 

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they are in a supermarket. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on television. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often do not understand why their parents say they cannot afford certain things, and arguments about the dangers of sugar are not convincing when faced with appealing advertisements.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance states that most parents care about their children's diet and have ideas about healthy food, although these ideas may not always be correct. It is important for parents and children to talk about food, as children who only hear about products from advertisements get a very limited view. Parents feel frustrated because they are competing with the advertising industry and often have to disappoint their children.

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV advertising, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy products. However, as Dibb notes, the goal of advertising is to persuade viewers to make purchases, even if they do not directly say, "Tell your mom to buy this."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they must decide which requests to accept and which to deny. One mother mentions that she tries to be patient when discussing food with her children, but still feels uneasy about how she handles their requests. She has talked to her son about advertisements so much that he now thinks they are not trustworthy. As a result, they have fewer conflicts in the supermarket because he does not ask for things she does not want to buy.

Parents also recognize that they can be inconsistent in their responses to their children's requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, explains that they refuse to buy sweets for their son because they believe they are unhealthy, while they themselves buy rich foods like double cream and chocolate. He finds it enjoyable to buy nice things and understands why children want to share in that. However, he admits that his mood affects how he responds to their requests, making it hard to be consistent.

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas.
