While parents might spend less if their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without constant demands from a six-year-old could attract more customers, making up for any loss in sales.

**Five-Star Luxury with Modern Technology**

The new five-star Merrion Hotel in Dublin combines luxury with the latest technology. It was created by transforming four large 18th-century houses, a project that took nearly two years and involved extensive research into what customers want. This approach allowed for the installation of advanced technology that benefits both staff and guests.

General Manager Peter MacCann expects his staff to know guests by name, but he uses a computer system to track guests' preferences. This system helps the hotel provide a special experience for returning guests. Although it cost £250,000 to set up, MacCann believes it will be worth it over time due to its efficiency. For instance, if a guest requests specific music CDs during their first stay, those same CDs will be ready for them on their next visit, thanks to the guest-history feature.

Room temperature is another common concern for hotel guests. The Merrion has a high-tech system that allows guests to adjust the temperature within three degrees of the standard 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can change the temperature in each room between 14°C and 25°C.

Business travelers will particularly appreciate the technology in their rooms. MacCann estimates that about 65% of the hotel's business will come from this market. To cater to their needs, the hotel has equipped each room with three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and video-conferencing capabilities. 

As technology evolves quickly, the hotel has prepared for future upgrades by installing extra cables. They rent televisions instead of buying them, allowing for easy replacement with newer models. DVD recorders can also be updated as needed. Despite all this technology, MacCann emphasizes that they want guests to feel comfortable, not overwhelmed. The hotel has 145 spacious and well-furnished rooms that are inviting and cozy.

In addition to the rooms, the Merrion features a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a lovely garden. The food is also a highlight, with Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, running the restaurant. Moving his restaurant to the Merrion has allowed him to create a modern kitchen and improve parking facilities. For the hotel, having a renowned restaurant adds value without financial risk.

With its combination of advanced technology and skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is poised for success.

**Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women who live life fully to share how they find their energy.

A. **Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author:** "I get my energy from excitement. I need challenges and learning new things to feel energized. Right now, I'm learning flamenco dancing, which is very expressive and uplifting. If I'm bored, I feel drained and life seems pointless. Being effective, even in small ways, gives me energy."

B. **Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor:** "I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it, so it doesn't feel like a burden. Enjoying what I do helps me feel good, even when I'm tired. I need enough sleep to feel my best. Exercise also boosts my energy, but I sometimes struggle to find the motivation. I do yoga once a week and try to work out at home. After exercising, my mood improves a lot. I often feel low in the afternoon, so I think it's good to have a snack then."

C. **Annie Nightingale, Disc Jockey:** "I don't rely on healthy eating for energy; I think it's about having natural enthusiasm and a positive attitude. I dislike negativity. I believe we should enjoy life and set goals. I love my job, and the past two years have been exciting. Being around lively young people energizes me. I enjoy taking photos, even if I'm not great at it, and I like writing lyrics for fun, which helps me relax while traveling."

D. **Floella Benjamin, Author and Children's TV Presenter:** "My energy comes from doing things I love. I believe in my work and being positive in life. Working with kids is energizing because they are resilient and full of energy. Communicating with others boosts my energy—just smiling at someone can create a wonderful feeling. I try to eat healthily and avoid smoking and drinking, but I don't have a strict exercise routine. I get my energy from playing with kids."

E. **Deborah Moggach, Author and Playwright:** "What I love most is transforming a wasteland into a garden. I once turned a concrete area into a beautiful garden, which was more energizing than any workout. Knowing that someone wants to read my writing also motivates me. I enjoy sneaking into nature, and if caught, I playfully act surprised, which feels fun and childlike."

F. **Katherine Monblot, Therapist:** "It's important to have an interest in what you do. I like taking risks and get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things I don't enjoy drains my energy. I used to be part of many committees, but I found their demands exhausting. You have limited energy, so focus it on what matters most to you."

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones, which were used until iron skates appeared in Scandinavia around 200 AD. For the wealthy in Scandinavia, skating was an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was seen as elegant, but everything changed at the 1924 Winter Olympics when 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style, making skating very popular.

Today, skating combines art and athleticism, making it both beautiful and physically challenging. For beginners, balance and control are crucial, and speed comes with practice. The way you position your body is key to maintaining balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and your knees relaxed, leaning a bit forward. Relaxation is essential in skating, more than in many other sports.

To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outward. As you push off with your back foot, make a small movement with the other foot. It’s not too hard! If you can keep this up, you can gradually make your movements longer as you gain skill. Learning how to fall safely is one of the first things a skater should master. Even professional skaters fall sometimes. To fall without getting hurt, stay relaxed to reduce the impact with the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel and then stand.

Once you feel confident on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance skating, speed skating, and pair skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks offer guidance, so you can quickly learn the basic moves, and soon you’ll be able to do turns, jumps, and spins in freestyle.

If you watch skilled skaters, you’ll notice how relaxed and fluid their movements are. To achieve this, it’s important to follow a regular exercise routine. Skating with a tense body can be risky, so warm-up exercises should focus on your legs, back, shoulders, and especially your ankles and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness.

Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also boosts heart and lung health and strengthens the body. When combined with swimming or jogging, it creates an excellent fitness program for overall health.

**Trills and Bills**

Seeing a talented child receive a medal can bring tears of joy. Julia Gregson spoke with three young achievers and their mothers about the joys and challenges they face.

A. **Annika Reeder**, 15, won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She dreams of becoming a physiotherapist and competing in the next Olympics. "Training is very demanding right now. I don’t have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I take it one day at a time. When I’m extremely tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can’t take too many days off, or your body gets stiff."

B. **Annika's mother**: "From a young age, Annika showed great talent. I’ve seen parents try to push their kids, but it doesn’t work. Competing at Annika’s level requires a lot of time and energy, so she has to want it herself. People often say we, as parents, have sacrificed a lot, but they don’t see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it has done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who hid behind me, but now she has met people from around the world and gained confidence through her success."

C. **Sarah Stokes** started show-jumping at age ten and has since won the British National Championship. "It’s great that my parents enjoy show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. The shows can last from one to five days. I never get tired of it; I love the excitement and fun of show-jumping. Even without my parents, I would still do it because I’m determined. I’m happy they celebrate my wins, but I’m not doing it for them. This year, I want to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team, and my big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."

D. **Sarah's mother**: "From the moment Sarah first sat on a horse at age one, it was clear she had found her passion. When she was five, she would wake up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for major shows, we travel all over England. To save money, we sleep in the living quarters of our horse box. Sarah is very organized and feels completely at home on a horse. Watching your child succeed in something they love is incredibly rewarding."

E. **Jane McShane**, 10, is Britain’s Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are really friendly. I know everyone, and it’s fun. When I play, I don’t focus as much as I should; I just look around and don’t think too much. I’m not worried about becoming arrogant, and I don’t talk about my success at school because I dislike feeling embarrassed."

F. **Jane's mother**: "Jane played her first game at age five. My father suggested we see if she liked it. He had tried to teach me when I was young, but I found it boring. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she had memorized all the moves, and by age six, she was beating adults. I’m proud when she wins, but if she decided to quit tomorrow, I wouldn’t stop her. I also don’t want to discourage her because she is exceptional. If she has this talent, I want her to reach her full potential."

Text: 

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher jokingly asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. 

Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about one centimeter. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a new super race. Instead, we are returning to how our ancestors were. We are starting to recover from the effects of poor diets over many generations. Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist, says, "We are becoming like Cro-Magnons again, the people who lived 40,000 years ago."

For most of human history, our ancestors had a varied diet. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate from 85 different wild plants. However, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture began, which changed everything. Farmers took over many natural areas, and now just three plants—wheat, rice, and maize—provide more than half of the calories we eat. This limited diet has harmed our health and growth. 

In Ohio, scientists found that when they started farming corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, which was thought to be a blessing, turned out to be a health problem, according to some experts. Despite this, agriculture spread because one piece of farmland could support many more people than hunting and gathering could.

Today, many people who rely on farming are still poorly nourished. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets starting to reflect the variety of our ancestors' diets again. As a result, the average height of men is now 179 cm in the US, 180 cm in Holland, and 177 cm in Japan. This is a positive trend, but it comes with challenges. 

Even though people are getting taller, standard bed lengths have stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Legroom in planes and trains seems to be getting smaller, and clothing companies have to keep changing their sizes. The question is: how tall can we get? 

Some experts, like Robert Fogel from the University, think we could reach a height of 193 cm this century. However, there is a twist. While individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate warmed, we became thinner and shorter, even with good food. If the planet continues to warm, we might shrink even more. In other words, our growth could be affected by global warming.

**Studio Audiences**

What is it like to be part of an audience when a television show is being filmed? Cosmo Landesman explored this topic. Like technical problems, studio audiences are a common part of television, yet many of us find them mysterious. When we see people getting excited on game shows, we often wonder: who are these people?

Among all types of live entertainment, studio audiences are often seen as the least important. Some people in the television industry even look down on them, comparing them to cattle. I used to think that studio audiences were made up of silly people wanting a moment of fame. However, there is no typical studio audience; they come from various backgrounds, jobs, and income levels. Television shows aim to attract different audiences for different programs.

Many of us who prefer watching television at home question why anyone would want to be in a studio audience. Why would someone apply for tickets, travel far, and endure hours of discomfort just to see what they can watch at home? One idea is that people hope to be seen on television, which I doubted until I spoke to Angela, who said she came for a chance to appear on TV. Another reason is curiosity about what happens behind the scenes. However, the most common reason I heard was simply, "a friend gave me a ticket."

Most of us have never been in a studio audience, yet we think we know what it’s like. We imagine sitting close to strangers while someone holds up signs that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and we respond accordingly. While this may be true for some shows, it is not the case for all. As one studio manager said, "We believe a show should be good enough not to need these signs."

But is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting," while Charlotte enjoyed the feeling of being part of live television. She mentioned seeing her favorite comedian live, saying that watching him on TV at home misses a lot of the experience. I, on the other hand, missed seeing the live actors because I could only see the back of someone’s head. The opening scenes were filmed far from my seat, so I ended up watching the show on a studio monitor.

Going to a studio may not be the best way to watch television, but that’s not what matters most. For many in the audience, it was simply a fun and free night of entertainment.

**Favorite Places**

**Bruce**  
I prefer landscapes that have some human presence. When I travel, I am drawn to charming villages with old temples rather than empty deserts. At the age of eight, I went to school in England, and on Saturdays, I would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham, located in a beautiful valley. Cycling was a way to escape school. I enjoyed exploring the rugged hilltops, sheltered valleys, and ancient villages. Coming from Scotland, I found the landscape both familiar and different, and I still visit it today. I used to write about my adventures in a private diary, which was my first attempt at travel writing, a field in which I later became well-known.

**Sophia**  
There is a small railway that runs from Hythe to Dungeness, operated by enthusiasts. I always choose first class because it costs only a little more than the regular ticket. The scenery is not breathtaking; the train travels across Romney Marsh with its sheep and alongside a canal. However, there is one part of the journey I always look forward to—when the train takes a detour through back gardens. For a few moments, we passengers get a glimpse into people's lives as they make tea, wash dishes, or set up deck chairs. I see myself reflected in their eyes, a woman in a tiny train carriage looking into their homes. It is the simplicity of the landscape that captivates me—just fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. This makes me pay closer attention and search for something that opens my eyes.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a beautiful and remote coastal area. The beaches are hard to access and filled with rocks, so there are not many people here. A few brave surfers come, but most visitors prefer to admire the power of the sea. This coast, facing the Atlantic, is known for shipwrecks. There are coastal walks that you can combine with trips into lovely damp valleys filled with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple self-catering accommodation with a family who owns property in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a vast moorland perfect for hiking. There are few residents and visitors, making it a quiet and remote area, which I enjoy. I discovered this place by chance when I was a student, and since then, I have visited every year, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It has changed little since my first visit. Having a child makes these trips even more special, and it saddens me that he is growing up in a city.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain, to find peace and reconnect with my English roots. I grew up in what is now Sri Lanka, but at twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. There was a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you would never return. That place was Glenthorne. It is my dream home—magical, secluded, and romantic. Here, you can only hear the sea, the wind, and the birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We are a family that loves animals of all kinds. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work to tell me she had found a beautiful pine snake. She asked, "Can we keep him?" I replied, "Yes, but only for one night." We had prepared a special tank for such visitors, allowing us to admire them and look them up in our natural history book.

I got home late and quickly started boiling water when I heard my sons screaming, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I rushed to their room. The chaos involved our cat, Domino, and a white mouse named Bianca, which I had received as a Mother's Day gift. Domino was running around with the mouse in his mouth, trying to escape while avoiding the flailing arms of the children.

In the midst of the confusion, I tripped and fell. As I considered how to stop Domino, I noticed the snake had escaped. It was slithering off the table and onto the floor. I crouched down as the snake moved closer, while the kids and the cat continued to jump around in a wild, noisy mess. The dog was barking, and the pot in the kitchen boiled over. I quickly turned off the gas and returned to the chaos with renewed energy. 

I managed to grab Domino by the tail and rescued the small, wet mouse from his jaws. Interestingly, this same mouse was caught by Domino three more times during its life but eventually died of old age. Feeling encouraged by my success, I examined the snake but found no weak points. 

I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer, rocking back and forth, but without music. Gradually, the snake relaxed and rested its head on its body, though its eyes still looked wary. Slowly, I lifted the snake and stood up, walking to the end of the garden. I pointed it towards a tree, hoping it would find a new home.

When I finally let go of the snake's head, expecting it to attack, it instead slid over my shoulders like a colorful shawl, seeming to settle in for the winter. We stood there in the fading light, with my four children, myself, and the snake. My eldest son, DJ, broke the silence with a scientific observation: "You know what it is, Mum? You're nice and warm, and the shed isn't."

I asked the children to gather at the snake's tail and gently encourage it to move on. Slowly, it did, climbing up the wall and disappearing over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished, my three-year-old son, Clay, sighed and said what we were all thinking: "Boy, that was one big snake!"

**Drop Me a Line!**

In our fast-paced world filled with phones, fax machines, and computers, the traditional practice of writing letters is in danger of disappearing. However, I believe that receiving a letter offers a unique joy that no other form of communication can provide. There is a thrill in its arrival, the delight in seeing who sent it, and the pleasure of reading its contents.

Letter writing has been a part of my life for as long as I can remember. It likely started with the small notes I wrote to my mother. She always encouraged me to write my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts, no matter how short or messy they were. When I moved away at 18 to study medicine in London, I wrote to my parents every week, and they wrote back. My father occasionally wrote, and his long, funny letters were always a treat. Most of the letters from home shared everyday happenings about my parents and their friends. While we also made phone calls, it is the letters that I cherish the most.

I also received letters from my boyfriends. During my youth, I often connected with people who had to work or study far away, and we kept in touch through letters. Surprisingly, this strengthened our relationships. I found it easier to express my thoughts in writing than in conversation. I especially love the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. While short notes are nice, receiving a full year’s worth of news is even better, especially when it arrives in an airmail envelope with lovely stamps.

I receive letters from friends around the world, including Mangala in Sri Lanka, a friend from my training over 20 years ago, and penfriends in Australia and Vancouver. There is also a woman in France who writes to me. If we hadn’t met by chance in a restaurant after a holiday, I would never have had her address to write to her. Thankfully, she replied, and now we have a regular exchange of letters. This helps me improve my French since she doesn’t speak English. We have visited her twice, and she has stayed with us as well.

My greatest letter-writing achievement happened this summer when my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met in person. Everyone was surprised that our correspondence lasted so long, and the local newspaper even featured our story on the front page.

I am happy that my children are continuing this tradition. Like my mother, I make sure they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just as I did for my mother. She and my son have their own penfriends in Texas, arranged by my penfriend. I strongly encourage everyone not to let letter writing become a lost art.

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art**

Many ancient pictures carved into rocks at a significant tourist site in France are being slowly destroyed. Scientists worry that the 36,000 drawings on the rocks in Mont Bego, located in the French Alps, are being harmed so quickly that they may not last for future generations. This mountain, thought to have been a place for prayer and worship, features drawings that are around 4,000 years old. These include images of horned cows, cultivated fields, and various gods and goddesses. However, as more people visit the site, the pictures are being damaged by careless graffiti.

Jean Clottes, the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, explains that many visitors believe these ancient images will always be there. He warns that if the damage continues at this pace, there will be nothing left in 50 years. He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings, which wears away the rock and blurs the artwork. Some visitors even break off pieces to take home as souvenirs. Clottes notes that when people cannot take a good photograph, they rub the drawings to make them clearer. The weather naturally polishes the drawings, but if the sun is shining and visitors cannot see them well, they often rub and scrape them to make them appear fresher.

Other researchers have observed that some people arrive with long sticks that have sharp ends to scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks. Experts disagree on the best way to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, believes the only way to save the site is to make the entire mountain a restricted area, allowing public access only through guided tours. He argues that without such measures, the site will be completely destroyed, and important research will suffer.

Clottes disagrees with de Lumley's strict proposal, stating that while it may be effective, it will likely lead to protests from local residents. He emphasizes that the site has been recognized as a historic monument by the Ministry of Culture, and efforts must be made to preserve it. David Lavergne, a regional architect, also prefers not to close the site. He believes that while it is important for people to see the area, the large size of the site makes it hard to prevent damage. He suggests that financial issues are a major concern, as there are not enough funds to hire the necessary security. Charging an entrance fee may need to be considered, but government funding seems unlikely.

In Nice, Annie Echassoux, who has also researched the site, is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to access—tourists can now avoid a long walk by using vehicles—the damage will increase quickly. She believes the best solution is to cordon off the area and provide guides. She insists that the lack of funds should not stop the plan from moving forward, stating, "Money must be provided because the Ministry of Culture has classified this area as a historic site. If we do not take action, we will be responsible for losing these drawings for future generations."

**Young Shoppers**

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother describes it as "absolute murder." Her children want everything they see, whether it's the newest sugary cereal, a Disney video, or a comic book—often all three. She feels guilty when she buys them these things, but she also hates saying no all the time. This makes her feel frustrated before they even leave home. She tries to avoid taking them shopping, but worries that she is not letting them learn how to make their own choices. It feels like a no-win situation.

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they are in a supermarket. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on television. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often do not understand why their parents say they cannot afford certain items, and arguments about the health risks of sugar are not convincing when faced with appealing advertisements.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance states that most parents care about what their children eat and have their own ideas about healthy food, even if those ideas are not always correct. It is important for parents and children to talk about food, as children who only hear about products from advertisements get a very limited view. Parents feel frustrated because they are competing with the advertising industry and often have to disappoint their children.

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV advertising, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy products. However, as Dibb notes, the goal of advertising is to persuade viewers to make purchases, even if they do not directly say, "Tell your mom to buy this."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother mentions that she tries to discuss food with her children, and while her son is aware of advertisements, he is critical of them. They talk a lot about different products and read labels together. Because of this, her children rarely ask for things she does not want to buy.

Parents also recognize that they can be inconsistent in how they respond to their children's requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, explains that they refuse to buy sweets for their son because they believe they are unhealthy, yet they buy rich foods for themselves. He finds it reasonable for children to want nice things, but he still feels annoyed by their requests. His willingness to say yes often depends on his mood and how well things are going in his life.

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. While parents might spend less if their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without constant demands from their kids could attract more customers, making up for any lost sales.

**Going Up the Wall**

In the past, climbers would go to mountains to climb. Now, people can enjoy climbing in many places, both indoors and outdoors. The audience watches closely as French climber Francois Lombard hangs upside down by just two fingers on a climbing wall. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at Birmingham's National Indoor Arena. This arena is better known for hosting the TV show Gladiators, but both events have one thing in common: The Wall. The ability to hold such events is thanks to new and rapidly advancing technology.

Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on natural cliffs where there were good climbing spots. In winter, they had to deal with cold weather, go for walks, or climb on snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing became more popular, it became essential for top climbers to stay fit. Since they couldn't use cliffs for much of the year, they started to train on brick edges or stone buildings. This helped them strengthen their fingers and avoid boredom from not being able to climb.

Soon, many sports centers began to build climbing walls specifically for training, using bricks designed for climbing. One of the pioneers was Don Robinson, a physical education teacher who built a climbing wall in a corridor at Leeds University in the mid-1960s. He came up with the idea of embedding natural rock into concrete blocks to create climbing walls. Throughout the 1970s, many similar walls were built in sports halls across the country, but they had clear design issues. These walls could only be vertical, while real cliffs have features like overhangs and slanted rocks. Additionally, once the walls were built, they couldn't be changed, and climbers would eventually get bored with the same routes.

In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny created a new material that could be shaped like the holds found on cliffs. These holds could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted a change. French manufacturers also started to experiment with panels on steel frames. Unlike concrete, which was too heavy for overhanging walls, steel frames could be built anywhere as free-standing structures. This system of interchangeable holds provided climbers with endless new challenges.

So, you want to be an actor? If you tell someone about your desire to pursue acting, they will likely mention how risky it is. Acting is indeed a risky career. There are many more actors than there are roles available. When you decide to become an actor, some people you thought were close friends may think you are making a mistake, while others might support you. Everyone will have different opinions, but this is a personal choice, and you alone are responsible for your journey and achieving your goals.

There are no shortcuts to becoming an actor. There are no exams to pass, and even after training, there is no guarantee of success in the industry. Success often depends on a mix of luck and talent. However, there is always a need for new actors and fresh talent, along with the excitement and potential rewards that come with the profession.

Many people ask what talent really is. I believe talent is a combination of natural ability and imagination, with imagination being the hardest to measure. It also involves courage and confidence in what you are doing and how you present it. 

Where does the desire to act come from? It can be hard to explain why you want to act. In theater, the key moment is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is what motivates actors to perform, no matter where they are.

When you ask successful actors how they achieved their success, they often don’t have a clear answer. They understand their own skills and techniques, but they don’t take anything for granted. They know that their success depends on their current work, and fame can be fleeting. 

Disappointment is a major challenge for actors. One month, you might be unemployed, working in a store or as a waitress. Then, you might get a chance to audition for a role. However, no matter how much you want the job, it might not be yours. Because of this, actors often avoid discussing their chances of getting roles. They find ways to cope with the stress of competition and the fear of rejection, which is something no one enjoys. 

From the moment you start auditioning professionally, you are putting yourself out there, showing that you are available, willing, and hopefully talented enough for the role. Ultimately, it is up to you; if you don’t care enough about your career, others may not care about you either.

**Food for Everyone**

We are excited to share our carefully chosen selection of the best cookbooks available. 

A. When people think of a famous TV chef and author, they often think of Delia Smith. Her recipes come from many different cultures, reflecting her passion for delicious food and her understanding of what everyday cooks can achieve in their kitchens. The book that made her famous is "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course," which has become a key reference for modern cooks. It offers clear guidance on both basic and advanced cooking techniques, along with hundreds of exciting recipes. This recently updated book answers the question: "If I could only have one cookbook, which would it be?"

B. Raymond Blanc went from being an untrained amateur chef to the owner of the most famous French restaurant in Britain in just 15 years. To accompany his first TV series, "Blanc Mange," he has released a book with the same title. Raymond aims to help everyone become better cooks by explaining how and why certain ingredients behave in specific ways. He believes that cooking is easy when you understand what happens in the pan. The book includes over 80 fantastic recipes that illustrate his points. It serves as a practical guide, explaining why some dishes may fail and introducing basic food science to clarify these concepts. Monsieur Blanc enjoys cooking for others, and this book shows that he is very skilled at it.

C. Le Cordon Bleu is a name that represents the best in traditional French cooking. For the past 100 years, the expert chefs at this renowned cooking school have trained students of all levels to achieve excellence. To celebrate its centenary, they have published the "Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook," featuring 100 of the school's most respected recipes. While these recipes are classic, they remain fresh and relevant. Le Cordon Bleu has always championed traditional French cuisine but has also adapted its recipes to reduce rich, creamy sauces and lower calorie counts. The book starts with essential kitchen techniques and includes sections on Appetizers, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe is accompanied by step-by-step illustrations and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from Cordon Bleu schools worldwide have contributed their famous recipes and shared their tips with readers.

D. Fast food? No way! It is commonly believed that good food requires a long time to prepare. However, Nigel Slater, the food editor of The Observer, disagrees. His new book, "The 30-Minute Cook," shows that fast food can be delicious. Nigel believes that when people come home tired and hungry, they want something good to eat quickly. He has always thought it is possible to make tasty meals in the same time it takes to order a pizza, and he has already published two successful books to prove it. In this new book, you will find many appealing recipes, each ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel shares over 200 recipes from around the world in his cheerful and engaging style. Just because he enjoys quick meals doesn't mean he doesn't value good food. If you doubt that fast food can be great, try his recipes—they are simply delicious.

Text: 

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher jokingly asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. 

Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about one centimeter. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a new super race. Instead, we are returning to how our ancestors looked. According to palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer, we are becoming like Cro-Magnons, the people who lived 40,000 years ago. 

For most of human history, our ancestors had a varied diet. Women gathered fruits and herbs, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate from 85 different wild plants. However, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture began, which changed everything. Farmers took over many natural areas, and now just three plants—wheat, rice, and maize—provide more than half of the calories we eat. This limited diet has harmed our health. 

Research in Ohio showed that when healthy hunter-gatherers started farming corn, they became sickly and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Although corn was thought to be beneficial, it turned out to be harmful to health, according to some experts. Despite this, agriculture spread because one piece of farmland could support many more people than hunting and gathering could. 

Today, many people who rely on farming are still poorly nourished. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets starting to resemble those of our ancestors again. As a result, the average height of men is now 179 cm in the US, 180 cm in Holland, and 177 cm in Japan. This is a positive trend, but it comes with challenges. 

Even though people are getting taller, standard bed lengths have not changed since 1860, remaining at 190 cm. Additionally, legroom in planes and trains seems to have decreased, and clothing companies must constantly adjust their sizes. The question is: how tall can we get? 

Some experts, like Robert Fogel, believe we could reach a height of 193 cm this century. However, there is a twist. While individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate has warmed, we have become thinner and shorter, even with good nutrition. If global warming continues, we might shrink even more. In other words, our growth could be affected by climate change.

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He explains, "After 14 years in the business, I found that working in the City became boring and no one was enjoying it anymore. I had planned to stay for another five or ten years, but then I lost my job unexpectedly. I didn’t receive a great severance package, but it was enough to start my farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a well-known hotel restaurant. By supplying them with meat, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat online. I’m happy to be out of the office, but surprisingly, my work hours are still long, around 80 to 90 hours a week, and I’m still selling a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Able White was a manager in advertising, but now he makes a living as an artist. He shares, "I started painting as a hobby and found it much more exciting than my job. It made sense to take redundancy and pursue art. The career counselor I spoke to was very supportive. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their forties need to find work quickly for financial reasons. My wife and I married young, and our children are now independent, so we took a risk and moved to northern England, where we didn’t know anyone. We left our friends behind, but luckily, our friendships have lasted, and many visit us now."

**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business from her flat in London. She says, "Being a lawyer was enjoyable and well-paid, but the hours were awful. I realized I didn’t want to become a senior partner and work even longer hours, so I decided to leave. Many people thought I would get bored, but that has never happened. The key is to set deadlines. In the fashion business, there are always collections and new designs to work on, so I keep a strict schedule. I feel happier and less stressed now, but I do miss the social interaction with colleagues. What I love about this job is that I am fully responsible for my work. If I do a poor job, I am the one to blame. When you work for a company, you care, but when your name is on the product, you care even more."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He explains, "I was in finance from the age of 22, making deals. I enjoyed the excitement, but I never found it fulfilling. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I chose to resign and travel for a year instead. During that year, I tried to figure out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited top gyms and spoke to their owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took various massage courses. Eventually, I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my life, which is the best part."

**A Winning Game**

Two brothers have discovered that their childhood game is great for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, bearded brothers in their forties, are at their simple home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, enjoying their past. In front of them is a wooden board with round plastic pieces. They are playing pichenotte, an ancient game they believe is unique. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, a grocer from Quebec, Canada, brought the game to the USA and shared it with his family. Soon, every weekend and holiday, the family played together, and as Dave recalls, "we had the best time ever." 

Later, the family moved to New Mexico, but they kept playing pichenotte using the board their grandfather made from old wooden crates. Visitors were often intrigued because the game was unknown in the southern USA. Three years ago, Dave noticed their old pichenotte board was damaged, so he decided to create a new one. It turned out beautifully. A relative wanted one, then a friend asked for another. Curious about the interest, the brothers took one of Dave's new boards to a sports bar in Santa Fe. "People watched and said, 'No way I'm playing that silly game.' But soon, they couldn't get up from the table!" Dave said.

When people began asking about the game's history, Dave researched it. He found that its origins might be in India, where a similar game called 'carroms' exists. This game evolved into 'squails' in British pubs, and British immigrants brought it to Canada. Pichenotte is the French-Canadian version that developed in Quebec. 

Pichenotte can be played by two to four players and is a game of skill. Each player has 12 pieces, or 'pucks,' which they flick across a wheel-like board using their fingers. Scoring 20 points is achieved by getting a puck into a small hole, while three rings around the hole are worth 15, 10, and 5 points. There are also eight small posts that act as obstacles. The game usually lasts about two minutes.

Seeing the game's popularity at the Santa Fe bar, the Lagasse brothers made more boards and took them to markets and craft fairs. Crowds gathered, money was exchanged, and the game's popularity soared. Championships began, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. As word spread, the boards sold quickly, leading the brothers to start a full-time pichenotte business. They set up a workshop in their garage and have produced over 450 boards. Made from birchwood and mahogany, each board weighs 12 kg and is 1 cm thick. Norm explains, "They're very durable and can handle a lot of use." 

Each board is sold for $595 on the brothers' website. Currently, there are no professional pichenotte players or TV coverage, but the brothers believe that one day their garage will be home to a luxury car instead of tools and wood. Until then, they enjoy playing the game they hope will bring them success.

WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE

When you enter the Model Village, it is hard to believe that just a few years ago, this area was an empty, overgrown piece of land. For a long time, it was seen as useless. However, through careful planning and hard work by one man, with the support of his wife, this land has been transformed into the beautiful village you see today. 

During the construction, many tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat land into the shaped landscape you now enjoy. While machines like bulldozers helped, a lot of manual labor was also involved. Once the land was shaped, about 1,000 tons of topsoil were added to create lawns, flower beds, and rockeries. Hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted, chosen specifically for this area. Only plants that could survive the salty air near the sea and withstand strong winter winds were used. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were imported from as far away as Canada and New Zealand.

The entire village was designed by Colin Sims, who spent nine years creating over 100 models since the village opened in 1972. These models are made from various materials like stone, concrete, specially treated wood, and plastics to endure different weather conditions. Initially, Colin needed help from experts to understand how materials would last over time, but he quickly became knowledgeable himself. 

You will notice that a consistent scale has been maintained, and great attention has been given to even the smallest details in the models. This was achieved through patience and the development of unique building techniques. The Model Village has become a popular attraction, known for its high-quality craftsmanship and upkeep. The methods used here have inspired other model villages in England and have even been included in college courses on modeling.

All the buildings in the village represent traditional British architectural styles and are not based on any specific location. One of the most impressive structures is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower, reflecting the style of manor houses found in the West Country. As you explore the village, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini-golf course, which is the latest addition.

We kindly ask you to stay on the paths during your visit and not to touch any of the models, as any damage can lead to hours of repair work for us. You are welcome to take photos from the pathways only. Dogs are allowed on a short lead.

To enhance your experience, you will find buttons in front of some working models. Pressing these will make the models operate. At the end of your visit, we would appreciate any feedback you have. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us create a more diverse and interesting display. We also want to know if any models did not meet your expectations, as we are constantly updating and replacing them.

We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Please tell your friends about us!

Every week, British tabloid newspapers publish photos that invade people's privacy and violate the editors' code of conduct. While some pop stars do pose for photographers, this is not the norm. More often, individuals in the public eye suffer when their private moments are displayed on the front page. However, very few people report these issues to the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was created to address such problems. These intrusive photos rarely serve the public interest. For example, how do intimate images of pop stars help solve crimes? How did a photo of a famous actress on a hotel balcony contribute to public safety? The actress has previously complained about long-lens photos, and since she was in a hotel—a place where privacy is expected—she had valid reasons to complain, but she did not take action. It is scandalous that the PCC did not investigate this matter. 

The PCC should also look into a recent scandal involving a pop star's private life. Like the actress, the pop star has not made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take the lead in addressing these shameful invasions? This seems like a good idea, as it could result in many rulings against newspapers. Such rulings would be reported by competing media, and the public would likely not support the tabloids, forcing editors to stop publishing such content. Photographers would also be affected, as they might no longer be able to afford to hide and take pictures of unsuspecting celebrities.

If the PCC took on the role of enforcing privacy, it would face several challenges. How would it decide when to investigate? Should it encourage victims to file complaints? If a victim chooses not to complain, should the PCC still act? Additionally, celebrities and royals might expect the PCC to address any story about them, and they could be upset if it does not. The task is too vast for the PCC to monitor all of the British press, including national and regional newspapers and magazines. 

There is also the issue of embarrassment. Even if someone's privacy is violated, would they want the added embarrassment of an investigation? Many might prefer to move on with their lives. Some may have other reasons for staying silent, such as fearing that a worse story about them could be revealed if they complain. In this way, the PCC could become seen as an enemy.

A British comedian faced similar issues when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon. He did not complain then, nor did he when a photographer took pictures of his family during a holiday. He feared that the newspaper would publish the photos again with a new story about his anger, claiming they thought it was just a joke and that, as a comedian, he would find it funny. This fear is understandable; many believe they will become targets again if they challenge the tabloids. Finding a simple solution to this serious issue is difficult.

Many college graduates receive advice about starting their first job. This article focuses on what to consider when moving to a second job. We will not discuss those looking for a temporary job while searching for a permanent one, or those who leave a job shortly after starting. Instead, we will talk about those who are ready to take a significant step in their careers. You have gained some experience and skills, and you have a clearer idea of your career goals.

When choosing your second job, think about your long-term goals. Do you want to specialize in a specific area, aim for higher responsibilities, or explore a broader field? It is important to choose this job carefully, as you should plan to stay in it for two to three years. Future employers will look closely at this job when you apply for your next position. It should demonstrate that you have thought seriously about your career. Most importantly, this job should help you grow, develop new skills, and take on more responsibilities.

If you feel the urge to travel, now might be a good time to do so. You can work temporarily when you return and then find your second job. Employers will appreciate that you have satisfied your desire to travel and are less likely to leave again soon.

Juliette Davidson spent her first year after graduating from St. Aldate's College working for three solicitors. It was a good first job because they were supportive, and she learned how to navigate an office and improve her word processing skills. However, there was no opportunity for advancement. Eventually, she decided to leave, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.

Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says, "In two and a half years, I have become more capable, and my job has really evolved. From the start, my boss was eager to help me grow. My job title is the same as when I began, but my responsibilities have changed. I now handle most of the correspondence and budgets, and I deal with various inquiries, from company chairmen to people wanting to start their own businesses. Brenda includes me in all her work and also assigns me specific projects and events to organize."

**Text: The Secret of Confident People**

What is the secret of confident people? They may seem naturally confident, but many will say it is a skill they learned over time. Nina Hathway interviews five individuals to share their experiences.

**A. Jenny**  
When I finished school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. At about twenty-five, I was asked to help at my daughter’s school. I was nervous but surprised myself by doing well. Someone suggested I take a university course. On my first day, I felt very anxious, but my confidence grew over time, and I became more outgoing. Looking back, working at the school was a turning point that helped me in many areas of my life.

**B. Michaela**  
My journey began four years ago when my father got sick, and I had to take over the family business. I was scared and became overly aggressive and impatient, thinking that was how confident people acted. Eventually, I learned that true confidence comes from believing in yourself. If work becomes too overwhelming, I don’t feel guilty about postponing some tasks. When facing challenges, I remind myself that I have nothing to lose. Fear can undermine confidence, so I often have quiet conversations with myself to overcome those fears.

**C. Lisa**  
People see me as confident, but the calmer I appear, the more nervous I actually feel. I had to learn to look confident because it is crucial in my job in TV. Interviewing people made me realize that everyone gets tense in important situations, but we feel better when talking to someone friendly. My mother once told me, “Who’s looking at you? Everyone is too busy worrying about their own appearance.” I find this advice very helpful. I also believe that facing your fears builds confidence. I was very nervous during my driving test, but after passing, I felt I could handle anything.

**D. Barbara**  
My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but I have built it over the years. If you keep working and learn from your mistakes, you will feel more confident next time. I work hard and am well-liked in the restaurant, but I know that not everyone will like me. I focus on liking myself for who I am, rather than trying to meet others' expectations. My company offers many training courses, which have boosted my self-esteem. Setting achievable goals helps a lot; it’s better to reach small goals than to aim too high and achieve nothing.

**E. Kim**  
After college, I worked as a secretary and often sat in meetings without speaking up, even when I disagreed. Eventually, I found the confidence to share my thoughts. When I started working in politics, I had never spoken in public and would shake with nerves. I told myself, “Don’t be silly. People do this every day, so you can too.” I also found it helpful to write down points to refer to, like a comfort blanket. I believe everyone feels a bit nervous when speaking publicly. The real secret to confidence is reminding yourself repeatedly, “Nothing is impossible.”

**Visit to Malaysia**

Paul Forster attends a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled widely when I gave him his torn kite. "You should keep it," he said, "it's a tradition—if the line breaks, the finders keep it... and I have many more." He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All were exactly 120 cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and split bamboo. We sat in the shade of the whispering conifer trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, looking out at Malaysia's largest kite festival. 

In the center of the beach, there were 10 platforms where helpers held up the kites, and a line of tense competitors waited for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites shot into the sky like rockets. More than 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts five days each year. Each participant entered four different designs, judged on decoration, stability in the air, and flying ability. "Flying kites isn't too hard," Adnan said, "but making them requires real skill. Come visit me at home, and I'll show you how." I received five invitations that day and decided to accept his.

At his house, I enjoyed cold milky tea and fish crackers in a large, polished room. As night fell, he invited me to return the next day to help rebuild his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, through granite mountains covered in lush rainforest. I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road ended at a river. A narrow boat was waiting to take people across. Nearby, a small sign caught my attention. It pointed up a footpath into the forest and read: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." It would have been helpful to know that most of this distance was steep and slippery uphill.

When I reached the track, I found a man named Baba waiting with a flask of tea. He managed a tented kitchen and several bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about the insects crawling under my thin foam mattress. The night was completely dark, filled with various sounds. A nearby waterfall roared, and thousands of creatures moved and squeaked. In the morning, I enjoyed a stunning view of five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First came the wind, then lightning struck the treetops. Moments later, I was soaked. As I slid downhill, I wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the heavy raindrops. I also worried about my car being washed away (which can happen) and the risk of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, my car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the track.

In Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, everyone asked me questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" But their curiosity was friendly. While Kelantan is famous for its kites, I will always remember it for the kindness of its people.

What kind of shopper are you? Shopping is something we all do, whether we enjoy it or not. There are various types of shoppers. Do you know which type you are? Abby Edwards asked several people about their shopping habits:

A. Melanie, 22, dancer: I love shopping! I can't resist spending money. When I have cash, I go shopping and it makes me happy. I find it hard to walk past sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often shop together. We are both addicted!

B. Brenda, 40, office manager: I don’t like shopping much. My husband does most of the grocery shopping because he cooks and knows what he likes. I don’t spend much time shopping for clothes either. I take my son and daughter shopping, but we all have different tastes, which makes it hard. I rarely buy things for myself, and when I do, I feel guilty and often tell my husband I spent less than I actually did.

C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager: I only shop for what I need. I dislike shopping and only go when necessary. When I do shop, I know exactly what I want and won’t settle for anything else. Shopping exhausts me, and I’d rather be doing something else.

D. Anita, 35, TV producer: I enjoy browsing occasionally, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don’t waste time and prefer to shop quickly. However, I sometimes make mistakes with my purchases, so I guess I’m a careful shopper who occasionally buys the wrong things.

E. Lizzie, 41, secretary: I really don’t like shopping. I find it hard to find clothes I want, and the shops are too noisy and messy. Luckily, I don’t have to shop for clothes often since I receive many of them as gifts. For groceries, I go to the supermarket once a week and get it done quickly.

F. Lisa, 22, actress: I would say I’m a happy shopper. Sometimes I go shopping with my friends, and we often end up buying things. I don’t usually have a specific item in mind, but if something catches my eye, I’ll buy it.

G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant: I’m a careful shopper. I enjoy shopping, but I don’t buy much. I usually know what I want and don’t go overboard. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but then I often regret spending too much.

H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker: I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it’s too crowded. I consider myself a careful shopper. I have a good idea of what I want before I go, and I take my time to find the best deals.

I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager: I don’t enjoy shopping, maybe because I work in the city and the shops don’t excite me anymore. When I have to shop, I go reluctantly and don’t bother trying things on because it’s too much effort. The clothes I buy don’t always fit, but I prefer to make a few mistakes rather than spend too much time shopping.

NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE

The Open University offers degrees just like any other university, but you can study without leaving your job. This experience can introduce you to many new interests. If you have never studied before, you will find joy in gaining knowledge. You will also meet a diverse group of people. Additionally, your degree may lead to new job opportunities.

At the Open University, you do not attend traditional lectures. Instead, you study from home using television, radio, and computer programs. If you want, you can go to one class a month at an Open University center. Like any university, there are exams to complete.

If you want to learn more, simply fill out the form below. This could be the beginning of an exciting new chapter in your life.

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**  
During the Easter holidays, young visitors can join a quiz about surprises. Free quiz sheets are available at the desk by the Orange Street entrance. Children will explore 14 surprising paintings and answer various questions about them. The quiz sheets can be picked up from 25 March to 9 April during regular gallery hours.

**New Artwork**  
The Gallery now features a beautiful still life by the Dutch painter Jan van Os from the 18th century. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) depicts flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first of its kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778. It is common for artists to date their work in two years, as they wait for specific flowers to bloom in different seasons. This artwork was generously donated to the Gallery by Miss Violet Churchman in memory of her sister, Ida Nancy. It is currently displayed in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**  
The exhibition titled "Painting in Spain during the Late 18th Century" opened in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery has recently acquired works by three Spanish painters from this period: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu, who are the main focus of the exhibition. They are joined by Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italian artists who worked in Spain during this time: Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition will be open until 31 May.

**Lecture Series**  
The series of lectures related to the special exhibition continues every Wednesday. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will discuss Melendez's work. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will talk about Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will focus on Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists often tell stories through their paintings.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**  
The Gallery is pleased to announce that the restaurant has improved and expanded its services. With new kitchens, the restaurant now offers a wide variety of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

**Visitor Information**  
Free guided tours of the Gallery are available every day at 11:00 am and 3:00 pm (except Sundays). These tours highlight some of the Gallery's most famous paintings and showcase its collection of important European art from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

**Little Chefs**

A group of children aged ten to fifteen spends their Saturdays learning how to cook. Their small classes are very popular, and there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where children can have fun and learn to make delicious food. 

Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it even better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down to enjoy the food we've made together." 

Flora, who is twelve, has some trouble with onions. She shares, "I love cooking. I prepared a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. My mum suggested I find a hobby instead of just staying home on weekends. At first, I wasn't very interested, but I'm really glad I decided to come." 

Their teacher, Philippe, explains, "It's a lot of fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, even if the kitchen isn't always tidy when they cook! As adults, we keep learning more about food. If parents encourage their children to cook when they are young, they will have the skills to prepare meals for themselves when they grow up."

The Outdoor Centre Fees apply to a car with four people. Each additional person costs 50p. Payments should be made at the main office. The centre is not a private club; it is an organization that aims to provide outdoor sports and recreation facilities for everyone. Groups planning to visit are asked to inform the centre in advance.

**Windsurfing - One-day Course**  
Beginner windsurfing courses are available on Saturdays and Sundays, weather permitting. Learning to windsurf is very enjoyable, and the thrill of sailing across the water for the first time is unforgettable. Boards with small sails are provided for beginners. The course fee is £32.50, which includes all necessary equipment.

**One-day Adventure Course**  
This is a great chance to try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. This course is designed to introduce outdoor activities to adults in a fun and relaxed way. You do not need to be very fit or have prior experience; just bring your interest. The course fee is £22.50.

**Play Park**  
The Play Park is suitable for children aged two to ten years. It is one of the best parks of its kind in the country, featuring sand and water play, slides, a large ball pool, a play castle, and much more. Next year, the centre will open a new Play Palace and Play Ship.

**Group Day and Residential Courses**  
We also offer day and weekend courses for groups. Schools, colleges, and youth groups frequently visit us. There are three large rooms, each with twelve beds, available for groups of up to 36 people (minimum of 12).

**Summer Adventure Holidays (for ages 8-14)**  
Activities include sailing, climbing, windsurfing, and fun games. Safety is our top priority at the Outdoor Centre. All staff are fully trained in First Aid and qualified to teach the activities. We ensure that all children participate in activities that are appropriate for their age and physical abilities. For this program, children must be able to swim 25 meters and be in good health.

**STAMP COLLECTING - A HOBBY THAT CAN GROW**

Many people of all ages find joy in stamp collecting, a hobby that is both enjoyable and engaging. Each year, more individuals begin their own stamp collections, discovering a passion that can last a lifetime. 

Starting a collection is simple because stamps are easily accessible. You can find stamps on holiday postcards from friends, birthday cards from family, and letters from pen pals. Once you become serious about collecting, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club, which helps collectors obtain new British stamps. 

As a member of the Club, you can order special sets of new stamps for your collection. There are three ways to receive them: 
1. A complete set can be mailed to you in an envelope.
2. You can receive the same stamps in a colorful information pack filled with interesting facts.
3. Alternatively, you can get individual stamps to arrange in your own special book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has around 70,000 members, and you can join for just £5 for a two-year membership. If you join with a group, you may even get a discount. This is a great deal! When you join, you will receive a Starter Pack at no extra cost, which includes 100 stamps to kick off your collection and a nice box to store them in. You will also get a helpful 4-page guide with tips on how to expand your collection and a list of shops that sell stamps.

Every two months, you will receive the Club magazine, filled with competitions, quizzes, and opportunities to exchange stamps with members worldwide. 

Why not embark on this exciting adventure that can bring you years of enjoyment? You will spend countless happy hours admiring the diverse stamps in your collection or searching for rare ones that are waiting to be discovered. 

Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and experience the fun of stamp collecting. To become a member, simply fill out the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will arrive within 28 days of your application.

**MONEY**

What is money? The pound, the dollar, and the franc are similar to a gram or a kilometre. The key difference is that you can trade money for goods or services. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a large bag of sweets, or a few cinema tickets. However, the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs very little to produce.

Thousands of years ago, people did not have money like we do today. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, a farmer, would trade the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a direct exchange between two people, each having something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own forms of money, known as 'currencies', to facilitate more exchanges. Eventually, these different currencies began to connect, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.

**Write a Winning Story!**

2. **Get Your Facts Right**: If you describe a place or explain something technical, make sure your information is accurate. Only write about things you are sure of.

3. **Hold the Reader's Attention**: Start your story in an engaging way and end it with a surprise. A weak ending can ruin a good story. Develop your plot carefully and think of something unexpected for the conclusion.

4. **Think About the Characters**: Make your characters feel real by using descriptive language. Help the reader connect with them.

**THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST**

Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many centuries, she was the only woman scientist recognized in history. Her father was the director of Alexandria University, and he ensured that she received the best education possible. This was rare, as most women at that time had limited chances to study.

After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria and began teaching mathematics. She quickly gained fame for her understanding of new ideas. Although we do not have copies of her books, we know she wrote several important works on mathematics. Hypatia was also interested in technology and created various scientific tools to assist her in her work.

During her time, many rulers feared science, and those involved in it were often in danger. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.

**Grass**

Grass is one of the most successful plants on Earth. There are more than 9,000 types of grass, and they can be found in every part of the world. Grass is unique because it can grow in very cold places like the Arctic and Antarctic. Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All these animals rely on grass for food in some way.

One of the remarkable features of grass is its ability to recover quickly after being cut or damaged. Unlike many other plants, grass grows new leaves from below the ground rather than from the top. This allows many animals to live together in the same area. When they eat all the grass, new grass starts to grow again, providing a fresh food source.

Kal Kaur Rai, the Young Achiever of the Year, has always loved fashion and recently won this title at the Asian Business Awards. Since childhood, she has enjoyed drawing clothes and creating designs. However, she never shared her dream of making fashion her career with her parents, who run a supermarket. She believed they wanted her to pursue a more traditional job, so she studied management at university.

After finishing her studies, Kal moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. Although she attended many industry events, she could not afford the designer clothes she admired. To solve this, she began making skirts and tops for herself. When her friends noticed her creations, they asked her to make clothes for them too. This led her to find a small shop in London that agreed to sell her designs on a sale-or-return basis. The clothes were very popular, and nothing was returned, which motivated her to leave her advertising job. She took out a £20,000 loan to start her own womenswear brand.

Kal's parents were supportive of her decision to change careers, which made her very happy. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns more than £500,000. Her designs are featured in fashion magazines, she creates outfits for pop stars, and she gained public recognition by winning this award. Kal feels grateful for her success, saying, "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this."

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has provided excellent service to guests from around the world, welcoming people of all ages and nationalities. Over the past 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed at Sunningdale.

The hotel is located on a main road that leads to the town center. It is about a 20-minute bus ride from the center, and many buses stop outside the hotel. Guests should avoid buses with a blue "Express" sign, as they do not stop near the hotel. An underground station is less than 100 meters away.
