Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in the history of cinema. However, his life has not always been easy. As a child, Tom was shy and struggled to make friends, but he loved participating in school plays. After finishing high school, he moved to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter while also taking drama classes. In 1980, the film director Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he had become so successful that he was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, earning millions for each film. Today, Tom continues to act in films and remains very popular with his many fans around the world.

Text: 'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? When Bo the cat decided to explore a furniture van, she had a bigger adventure than she expected. The driver found her after a long trip of over 500 kilometers. Both the driver and Bo were hungry at the end of the day. He gave her some milk and started to ask questions. He called his last customers, but they had not lost a cat. As it was getting late, he took Bo home for the night and the next morning took her to an animal hospital. Meanwhile, Bo's owner had also been searching for her. After looking everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had delivered to a neighbor. Luckily, he recalled the name of the company. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely returned to him.'

**The Ghan Train**

Mark Ottaway took a train journey from Darwin, in northern Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train travels across the Australian continent, moving from the warm northern coast through vast deserts to the cooler Southern Ocean. It is often called the "famous Ghan," but this name is somewhat misleading because the train is known for being late.

The idea of a train link between Darwin and Adelaide began in the 1920s, with a line built from Adelaide to Alice Springs. However, this line often faced serious flooding, which made it hard for trains to operate. A new line was finished just a few months before my trip. The railway was designed for speeds of up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a high-speed train. It has few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. Unlike luxury trains like the Orient Express, the Ghan does not focus on providing luxury, although the food on board is very good.

Originally, the railway was built to transport goods, not passengers. It was believed that sending goods from Europe to Australia’s southern cities via Darwin and the train would save time and money compared to shipping around the continent. Completing a transcontinental railway is a rare achievement, and the Ghan claims to be the world's first north-south railway.

As I waited to board the Ghan, I noticed that everyone was excited about the journey. Many of my fellow travelers were Australian retirees who were particularly eager to get on the train. Our first stop was Katherine, where the Ghan stayed for four hours. Some passengers got off to take a boat trip in the gorge. I stayed on the train until Alice Springs, where I joined a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Nowadays, climbing the rock is discouraged, and few people do it. Our group simply walked around the rock and enjoyed the beautiful sunset.

From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week heading south, so many passengers choose to stop there. The scenery from the train after Alice Springs is not very exciting; it mostly consists of flat land with cattle. However, on the third day at dawn, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was coming to an end, and although the train did not meet all the expectations set by advertisements, it had taken me to some of the most incredible sights in Australia.

**Climbing to the Top of Britain**

Every year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is located in the north, the weather can be extremely cold. Climber Keith Hewitt shares his experience of climbing Ben Nevis for the first time.

It was February, and it was my first major winter climb. We chose a route up the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. This climb is six hundred meters high, making it the longest climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries,' which are large bowl-like areas cut into the mountain halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. These spikes are essential on Ben Nevis because the snow can be so hard that it feels like walking on ice. 

Even though some members of our group were very experienced, we packed a lot of safety equipment, including lights to signal for help, hard hats, and extra clothing. Although the weather forecast was perfect with no strong winds, there was still a sense of nervousness as we began our climb. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always challenging.

As we climbed, the path became steeper, and my legs felt heavy. Being the least fit member of the group, I needed to take more breaks. The others sometimes paused to let me catch up, but as soon as I arrived, they would start climbing again. I promised myself that I would train better before my next climb.

After climbing 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path that would take us to the summit of Ben Nevis. This path is only a meter and a half wide, and the mountain drops steeply on both sides. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on each step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we finally reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, which is 48 kilometers away. Unfortunately, we were not so lucky, as a mist had rolled in.

Getting back down to our camp can be just as difficult as climbing up. It is important to read a map correctly because a wrong turn could lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was glad we decided to take turns navigating. It was only when I was safely inside the tent that I could truly say I enjoyed the experience. But at least I made it to the top.

**Anna's New School**

This week has been very exciting because we have moved into our new school building! It is a wonderful place. The builders used wood for the entire structure, similar to our old school, but this one is also designed to be environmentally friendly. The construction took several months, and we watched it all happen. It was thrilling to see the builders clear the land, even though it meant some beautiful open space was lost. The noise from the construction machines was quite loud, and the builders often had to stop working because of heavy rain. At times, we worried that the building would never be completed.

Now, we have five large classrooms, much bigger than those in our old school next door, which was very old. We also share one room with people from the town for meetings. There is a nursery, a lovely dining room, and spacious changing rooms that we are eager to use once our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, the first thing you notice is that there are no heaters! Instead, the warmth comes from everyone inside—the students, teachers, and the computers we use. The building is designed so well that it keeps all the heat inside. It also holds sound very well, so when we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we are in a concert hall!

Another interesting feature is that the school roof has a tree on top! The builders placed it there after finishing the roof, as it is a tradition in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for our lights and computers comes from a wind turbine located on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday, and it spins very quickly. It is so large that it can be seen from far away! We took some pictures that we plan to share on our website.

Even though we are already using the new building, some parts are still being completed. For example, we are currently preparing a play for our parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall to perform it. However, the new hall will be ready by next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster now that we are here!

A month ago, I never imagined that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be 30 meters above the ground and enjoying it. Now, as I looked down at the river far below, I understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The accommodation was basic, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be away from the city and in the fresh air.

On Saturday morning, we met the other ten members of our group. Cameron came with his friends Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn were with Amanda. We all came from different places and none of us knew the area well. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we weren’t sure how.

Half of us went caving in the morning, while the others went rock climbing. We switched activities at lunchtime. Matt and I went caving first. Climbing out was more difficult than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally made it out—covered in mud but happy and excited about our adventure.

Letter to the Newport Evening News

On Saturday afternoon, I accidentally left my handbag on the bus. Inside were my cheque book, address book, and my purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized my mistake, it was too late to do anything. I felt lost and worried because I am 72 years old and far from home. I stood by the road and cried.

A young man saw me and asked what was wrong. I told him what had happened, and he kindly gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I explained the situation to the bus driver, he told me I could keep the fare. I made it home safely, and soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that operated the bus where I left my handbag. He informed me that they had found it and offered to bring it back to me.

I was amazed to get my handbag back with everything inside still there. I want to express my gratitude to everyone who helped me that day. Their kindness and honesty meant a lot to me.

Mrs. B. James, Newport

**Sharks**

Sharks are among the most intimidating animals in our oceans. They are well adapted for hunting underwater because they have excellent vision and can sense movement through special lines on the sides of their bodies. This makes them very dangerous to smaller sea animals that they prey on. 

While sharks share some similarities with other fish, their bodies are quite different. For instance, most sharks must keep swimming constantly to breathe and survive, which means they hardly ever sleep. Additionally, if sharks are flipped onto their backs, they can become completely still. This is a useful method for researchers who need to study sharks, as it helps them learn more about these intriguing creatures.

Joining the Kirov Ballet

My name is Nathalie. Last year, I became one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. On my first day of ballet class, I felt nervous because I didn’t know anyone. Everyone came over to ask me questions in Russian. I tried to respond in Russian, and then they switched to English, so we were able to communicate. Now, six months later, everyone is very friendly, my Russian has improved a lot, and I can understand my teachers.

For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mother stayed with me. When she left, I felt a bit sad. I even called home late one night to talk to her because I was feeling lonely. Compared to my ballet school in England, the classes here in Russia are much tougher, and I eat a lot to keep my energy up. This gives me confidence to meet the school’s high standards.

In the evenings, I like to watch my favorite movies on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before they finish. Now that I have settled in, I feel really at home here. I enjoy walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when it was incredibly cold. I decided to buy a fur hat because it was minus 10 degrees Celsius, but the locals said that was mild for that time of year! At least my room is warm and cozy.

Currently, we are preparing for a new production, and there is also a competition for young dancers that I plan to enter. I feel very fortunate to be here.

**THE ICEHOTEL**

For many years, the Arctic was a popular summer destination to experience the land of the midnight sun. However, in winter, the few people living there enjoyed the snow and ice alone. By the late 1980s, it was decided that the long, dark winter could be seen as a positive thing. In the winter of 1990, French artist Jannot Derit was invited to open an exhibition in a specially built igloo (a structure made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi, located on the frozen Torne River. This building, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors.

One night, a group of foreign guests thought it would be fun to sleep in Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel was created. Today, it is famous worldwide. When winter arrives, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from around the globe come to Jukkasjarvi to construct the hotel for that year. As each section is finished, it opens to visitors and overnight guests, while other parts are still being built. The first section is completed in December, and each week a new section opens until January 7th, when the hotel is fully finished.

Since the ICEHOTEL is built outdoors using natural winter materials, the completion date depends on the weather, which can lead to changes in the schedule. In spring, as temperatures rise, the hotel melts away. Inside the hotel, the temperature stays between -5°C and -8°C, no matter how cold it is outside. Guests receive winter clothing, such as warm overalls, hats, and gloves, as part of their stay. It is also wise for guests to bring sweaters, scarves, and plenty of woollen socks, and to choose shoes that are slightly larger than usual to fit thick socks.

If you plan to visit the hotel, you can purchase warm sweaters, woollen socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items along with your booking, and they will be delivered to your room when you check in. The hotel is located in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. Bus transport can be arranged from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

**Shopping for Furniture**

A report by Dave Worthington

Homestyle, a new furniture store, had to close shortly after it opened at midnight last Thursday. Up to 6,000 people rushed to the store. There were many special deals, like a leather sofa for £45 (available only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only from 3 am to 8 am). The store's regular hours will be from 9 am to 9 pm every day, but Homestyle had planned to stay open for the first 24 hours. Unfortunately, it had to close just half an hour after opening.

A police officer who was called to the store said, "We knew a large crowd was expected, but people were not patient. The store quickly became full, and the managers wisely decided to close the doors. The people outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold out before they could get in, and they refused to wait quietly for their turn. Another issue was that there was a long line of cars trying to reach the parking lot. I was shocked that many people left their cars in the middle of the road and walked the last few meters to the store, which blocked the road completely."

One customer, Jenny Smith, who got into the store, said, "I waited in line for three hours, but I didn't have time to buy what I wanted. The staff were very calm and explained the situation. They had no choice; it wasn't safe. I will return when they reopen, but I don't want to wait in line again."

**Free-diving in the Caribbean**

Tanya Streeter holds four world records in free-diving, a sport where competitors dive to great depths on just one breath of air. In 2003, she made history by becoming the first person to dive 120 meters into the ocean and return to the surface without assistance. Although she had previously dived deeper using a balloon, this time she held her breath for over three and a half minutes, making her the first woman to break a world record previously held by a man.

A team of fourteen safety divers monitored her dive at various depths. Despite concerns about the dangers of free-diving due to several serious accidents, Tanya believes that safety is the most important factor, followed by proper training. While most free-divers focus on one or two events, Tanya maintains a consistent training schedule. Two-thirds of her training occurs in the gym, with the remainder split between the pool and the ocean. She uses an exercise bike to improve her cardiovascular fitness but avoids running to protect her knees, opting instead for fast walking.

When preparing for dives, Tanya usually travels away from home, aiming to complete fourteen dives over four weeks, with a rest day between each dive. It is crucial for her to avoid fatigue, as it could jeopardize her preparation. When not training, she often makes public appearances to promote sports products and supports environmental organizations through research and film projects.

Growing up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman, Tanya spent her childhood swimming and exploring rock pools to observe sea life. She feels that her current life reflects her childhood dreams. Being well-known in some countries, she believes people are willing to listen to her views on environmental issues. Looking ahead, Tanya, now in her thirties, plans to continue breaking her own world records. Since she began free-diving at the age of twenty-five, she is eager to emphasize that she does not plan to retire from the sport anytime soon.

**CARTOON FILMS**

Cartoon films have very few restrictions. If you can draw something, you can animate it for the cinema. New ideas and advanced computer programs are making cartoons exciting for audiences of all ages. By the late 1970s, the film industry believed that cartoons were only for children. However, soon after, a few directors introduced original concepts. They showed that it was possible to create films that both adults and children could enjoy together. Not every cartoon film was a hit, though. For instance, *The Black Cauldron* did not succeed because it was too scary for children and too silly for adults. Directors learned from this experience, and film companies started to earn significant profits again.

New TV Star Caroline Benson discusses her first role on television. "I never thought I would spend part of my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I had only acted in school plays, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother used to say I was just like Polly Finnegan, and I always dreamed of playing her. Before starting university, I took a year off to travel. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me about plans to adapt the book into a TV drama. I knew I had to audition for the role. At first, my mother was surprised, but she sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the role. Filming started a week after the term began, so I asked the university for permission to be away for three weeks. When I returned, I woke up at 6:00 am to catch up on the essays I had missed. I didn’t tell my university friends, but they found out and thought it was exciting. It was an incredible experience, and I feel very lucky. After university, I definitely want to pursue acting as a career. I don’t come from an acting family, although my grandfather was an opera singer. I have auditioned for other TV roles but haven’t received any offers yet. I’m not sure how I managed everything because I also had a busy social life. When filming ended, I felt a bit lost. Since then, I have acted in two college plays. Unfortunately, I haven’t been home much, and now that my first year at university is over, I’m going to Greece for the summer with friends."

When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my main goal was to earn enough money to feed my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is a fast-growing international company. Over the years, I have learned a lot, and much of this knowledge is shared in this book. I believe our company has valuable insights on how to run a successful business while staying true to our beliefs. This is not just a typical business book or a memoir; it conveys the idea that to succeed, you must be different. Business can be enjoyable, run with love, and contribute positively to society. In both business and life, I want to feel joy, a sense of family, and excitement from unexpected events. I have always hoped that the people working at 'The Body Shop' share these feelings. This book aims to share my ideas with the world. I believe there are no limits to our 'family' or to what we can achieve. I find this thought exciting, and I hope you do too.

**A Journey Along the Beautiful Douro River**

Jules Verne operates a 'hotel ship' on the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can accommodate 160 guests in double cabins, all with outside views and private bathrooms. Onboard, you will find air-conditioning, a sun-deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

**Itinerary**

**Day 1:** Depart in the early evening from London Heathrow to Oporto. A guide will meet you upon arrival and take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will spend the night.

**Day 2:** After a morning of sightseeing in Oporto, you will return to the ship and set off for Entre-os-Rios. This part of the journey takes four hours.

**Day 3:** You will continue your journey up the river. In the early evening, the ship will stop at Peso da Regua, known for its port wine production. At dinner, you can enjoy delicious local food and drinks.

**Day 4:** After breakfast, you will travel south by bus to the ancient town of Lamego, where you will visit the cathedral, several churches, and a museum that was once a palace. The museum has a great collection of paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. You will then return to the ship and sail on to Tua.

**Day 5:** The Douro River becomes very narrow here. Depending on the river's depth, you may take a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. The return journey to Tua will be by coach, with many sights to see along the way.

**Day 6:** In the morning, you will drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for one of the best views in the Douro Valley. After lunch on the ship, you will take the Douro Valley railway for a scenic ride to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting for you.

**Day 7:** There will be a trip to Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch and then heading down the river to Oporto. You will spend the night on board the Lady Ivy May.

**Day 8:** You will arrive in Oporto with plenty of time for sightseeing and last-minute shopping before your flight back to London Heathrow.

**HONEY**

Honey is a sweet liquid created by bees. It is made up of water and sugars. To make just half a kilogram of honey, bees can travel up to seventy-five thousand kilometers and visit over two million flowers. The color and taste of honey vary depending on the type of flower the bees visit. There are more than three hundred different types of honey. Generally, lighter-colored honey has a milder flavor compared to darker honey.

In ancient times, honey was the primary sweetener because sugar was very rare. The ancient Egyptians valued honey highly and even used it as a form of payment. Today, honey is produced and consumed all over the world. Research indicates that honey can help reduce tiredness and enhance athletic performance. Additionally, honey is not only a food; it can also be used to soothe sore throats and is included in many skin and hair care products.

**Norwich**

Norwich is the capital of East Anglia, a region in Britain, and has been inhabited for over two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By the time of the Norman invasion in 1066, it had become one of England's largest towns. Norwich has two cathedrals and a mosque, making it a significant center for various religions. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated the 800th anniversary of receiving a Royal Charter, which allowed it to be recognized as a city and to govern itself.

Today, Norwich is smaller than cities like London or Manchester, with a population of about 150,000. However, in the 16th century, it was the second city in England. For the next 300 years, it continued to grow and prosper, becoming known for having as many churches as there are weeks in a year and as many pubs as there are days.

Currently, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was established in Norwich. The city has a growing student population and is a modern commercial center, being the largest hub for insurance services outside London. Today, Norwich offers a variety of entertainment options, including theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, busy cafes, excellent restaurants, and several arts and leisure centers. The local football team, known as 'The Canaries', wears green and yellow, though the reason for the name is unclear.

One of the city's recent developments is a modern shopping center called 'The Castle Mall'. For over two years, residents dealt with a large construction site in the city center as builders worked on the main car park. They moved nearly a million tons of earth to create a park on the roof of the Mall, complete with water features and many trees. Fortunately, the old open market remains in the city center, next to the new development. Both areas continue to thrive, showing that Norwich successfully blends its historical charm with modern advancements.

**The Albuquerque Balloon Festival**

Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the southwestern United States, fills with bright colors. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event that happens every year. The first festival took place in 1972 to celebrate the 50th anniversary of a local radio station. It started with about twelve hot-air balloons taking off from a parking lot in the city. Since then, the festival has grown significantly. This year, at least a thousand balloons from over a third of the countries in the world are expected to participate at its current location outside the city.

**What to See**

The balloon pilots communicate with each other via radio and light up their burners at the same time, creating a beautiful display known as "balloon glows." These glows are great for taking amazing photographs, but you need to arrive just after sunset or before 5:30 AM to see them as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and talk to the pilots as they prepare for take-off. The balloons come in various sizes and colors, some shaped like animals or cartoon characters, and even popular products like soft drinks and fast food. Children will especially enjoy this.

In the afternoon, you can experience a balloon flight over the desert by booking a ride with one of the many companies that offer this service. Another option is to take the cable car from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains, which is the longest ride of its kind, and enjoy a stunning view of the festival.

There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the opening night and the last three nights of the festival.

**The Albuquerque Box**

This is a local wind pattern that creates ideal conditions for ballooning. The Sandia Mountains shield the balloons from strong winds and create gentler wind currents at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by rising or descending.

**Practical Advice**

Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long waits at the festival entrance. Dress in several layers of light clothing, as it can be cool at night and in the early morning, but you will need sunglasses and sunscreen during the day. Bring a flashlight for nighttime events and, of course, your camera. If you use film instead of digital photography, make sure to bring high-speed film for evening and nighttime photos.

The Eden Project, located in the south-west of England, has become one of the UK's most popular tourist destinations since it opened. The large 'biospheres' on this former industrial site resemble something from a science-fiction film. Each biosphere represents a different climate zone, highlighting the important connection between people and plants. It is fascinating to realize how many everyday products come from plants, such as wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate. The project cultivates over 135,000 different plant species. Regardless of the outside weather, computer-controlled heaters maintain the ideal temperature for the plants. In the Rainforest Zone, the environment is consistently humid due to a large waterfall. Another zone mimics the climates of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to create a desert zone soon.

Some people have expressed dissatisfaction with this year's collection, New Writing 3, but I find it hard to understand why. After all, 500 pages of high-quality original writing for just £6.99 is quite impressive. The majority of the book consists of fiction, including both excerpts from novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable contributions from well-known authors like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, many lesser-known writers have focused on food in their pieces. I recommend being cautious with Jane Harris's story, Those Nails—it is best not to read it right after eating, as it contains some very disturbing scenes. The collection also features excellent work from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. Additionally, there are excerpts from works in progress by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, the collection includes a bit of non-fiction, such as a humorous article by Alan Rusbridger about certain newspapers and a remarkable personal piece by Ursula Owen. Overall, this is an outstanding collection, and I am eager to see what next year's edition will bring.

**No Title**

Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher, believes that the best age to start learning the violin is between three and six years old. She explains that this is when children are discovering the world around them. Living in London, Margaret usually accepts students who are three or four years old, but she has made exceptions for enthusiastic five-year-olds.

When she began teaching the violin in 1972, her first class included her children’s five-year-old friends. Margaret teaches her students in groups of about twelve, with each lesson lasting one hour and occurring every two weeks. Additionally, each student has a weekly individual lesson with her. It is also necessary for parents to attend these classes, as their involvement is crucial for the students' learning.

From the very first lessons, students learn to play music by ear. They do not start reading music until they have been playing for several years, and there is often a noticeable difference between their playing skills and their ability to read music. Margaret emphasizes that her teaching method is not designed to create expert violinists. She often advises students who excel to leave and pursue more traditional violin training.

**Moonshine**

The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. "Here Again" follows their previous album, "The Waves." There have been some changes since the last CD: Tom Wilcott has joined as the new bass guitarist, replacing Simon McVee, who left the band last year. Additionally, Tom Simpson is now playing the drums.

From the first song, which is a dance track, it is clear that the band is shifting away from slow songs. The second song is also a dance track and is even louder and more energetic. Most of the later songs return to the band's usual slower style. These two dance tracks may surprise many fans, but either could easily become a hit single because they are excellent. 

Singer Rob Letchford showcases his talent by hitting every note perfectly. Fans should appreciate that he recorded these songs before experiencing throat issues, which led to the cancellation of their upcoming tour. However, anyone who has purchased tickets need not worry, as all concerts will be rescheduled once Rob has recovered.

In this CD, Moonshine demonstrates their ability to create great music in various styles, from the slow songs we know to upbeat tracks that make you want to dance. I did feel that they placed their best songs at the beginning, and the last few tracks were not quite as strong. Nevertheless, "Here Again" is sure to be a big success and will bring more recognition to the band.

San Francisco is located on the northern California coast. The first Europeans to find this area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola, who saw it for the first time in 1769. Interestingly, San Francisco Bay, which is a beautiful natural harbor, was discovered by land instead of by sea. In 1849, many people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. However, it was not the gold seekers who became wealthy. The richest individuals were those who owned banks and law firms, and they built large homes on a hill known as Nob Hill. Today, tourists visit San Francisco to see famous attractions like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to visit the old prison.

**SAMUEL PEPYS**

The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It provides a detailed and engaging account of daily life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys discusses significant events of the time, such as diseases, an enemy navy sailing up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also shares personal stories, including his own flaws—like often falling asleep in church or admiring pretty girls. He talks about his home life, including arguments with his wife and how they reconciled, as well as his concerns about her health. In addition to reading, he enjoyed music, theatre, card games, and lively parties with good food. Pepys was a busy man with many important roles; he served as a Member of Parliament and was the President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his contributions to the British Navy.

**The History of Shoes**

In the past, people did not focus on making shoes comfortable or stylish. Early shoes were likely made from animal skins, which people wrapped around their ankles to keep warm. Today, we still use leather, but other materials like silk, plastic, and cotton are also common, depending on current trends. It was only about 150 years ago that people started wearing different shoes for each foot. Before that, shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. 

Originally, all shoes were handmade. While some shoemakers still use traditional methods, most shoes are now produced by machines in large factories. The invention of sewing machines allowed the shoe industry to create many more shoes at lower prices, making them available to a larger number of people.

Title: My Journey to Encourage Women to Run

After injuring my back, I had to pause my running career. I wanted to help more women discover the joy of running and build their confidence to participate in the sport. Frustrated by the attitudes of many race organizers, who often complain about the low number of women in running while failing to provide proper facilities for them, I decided to start a running club for women in my community.

I created posters, and soon, 40 women of all ages and fitness levels joined. Most were interested in losing weight, but I don't think many had considered running before. If they did, they imagined it as painful training. They didn't realize that running could be enjoyable, filled with conversations and smiles in beautiful locations, like along a river.

Initially, the women could only run for a minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes. They have also learned about nutrition and fitness from each other. I wanted to make a positive impact on women's running, and it has been incredibly rewarding to witness their progress—almost as much joy as they have experienced themselves.

**THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH**

In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the northernmost state in the USA. Many people moved there hoping to become rich. New towns quickly developed, including one called Iditarod, which means 'far, distant place'. In 1909, Iditarod grew so fast that it briefly became the largest city in Alaska.

During the summer, supplies could be brought to these towns by boat. However, in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, making it impossible to reach them. To solve this, a winter trail was built in 1910 for dog sled teams to deliver mail, food, and clothing to gold miners. This trail became known as the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a team of dogs to travel across Alaska, stopping at 'roadhouses' where drivers could find a warm bed and food for themselves and their dogs.

The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced dog teams and steam boats as the main transport. However, in 1925, dogs gained fame again when a disease called diphtheria struck the city of Nome. The medicine needed to treat the disease was located in Anchorage, on the other side of Alaska. At that time, airplanes were new, and it was uncertain if they could fly in the cold. The only skilled pilot, Carl Eielson, was away on a trip. Therefore, it was decided to transport the medicine using dog teams.

The journey covered over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail, and took twenty teams just six days to complete. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who had come to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He relied on his dog Togo to navigate through the heavy snow, and Togo proved to be an excellent guide. The final part of the journey was completed by Gunnar Kaasen, who had been driving dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Saito. At one point, Balto, another lead dog, refused to go further, preventing the team from falling into icy water. Thanks to this effort, the diphtheria outbreak was controlled, and Balto became a hero.

Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the route of that famous 1925 journey. This race is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.

**Sweden's Ice Hotel**

The village of Jukkasjarvi is located in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can drop to -40°C. Despite the cold, around 6,000 tourists visit each year to experience one of Europe’s most unique hotels. In this hotel, everything—eating, drinking, and sleeping—takes place in rooms made entirely of ice. You can even have a wedding there. The bar is also made of ice, so it is not advisable to place hot drinks on it! The bedrooms are kept at about -4°C, but guests receive special sleeping bags designed to keep them warm in extreme cold. If needed, suitable outdoor clothing can also be provided. The hotel lasts no longer than six months because it melts in the summer, and it is rebuilt each winter. Constructing the hotel requires 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.

**Maria Mutola**

In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl playing football on an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained." This story was published in a local newspaper, and Jose Craveirinha, who supported other African athletes, learned about Maria. He went to meet her and saw her kicking a ball outside the football club. He quickly realized she was very fast. 

"He talked to me about athletics. I didn’t understand at first because I only knew about football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was very hard work, and my legs hurt a lot." Jose spoke to her parents and convinced them that she could be successful, which would help improve their financial situation. They agreed to let him take her away for training.

In 1991, she finally accepted an invitation to train in the United States. She had previously refused because she was worried about missing her family. Her background was different from the girls she met in the US. She said, "They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew very little about me and even less about my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were excellent, and I learned a lot."

Today, Maria still runs and spends most of the year happily living in South Africa with her mother.

The Skywalk

The Grand Canyon in the United States was formed by the Colorado River. Many people visit Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and especially to enjoy the stunning views. The view is enhanced by the Skywalk, a glass platform that extends over the canyon. The Skywalk is 1,219 meters above the canyon floor, allowing visitors to see the beautiful rock formations below. It can hold up to 120 people at once. Since its opening in 2007, thousands have experienced it. To protect the glass surface, visitors must wear special shoe covers. Walking on the Skywalk gives you the sensation of soaring like a bird high in the sky.

**THE ROCKIES**

The Rocky Mountains stretch nearly the entire length of North America. They begin in the Northwest but are also found a few hundred miles from the center in the southern regions. While the Rockies are not as tall as the Alps, they are equally impressive. There are many roads that cross the Rockies, but the best way to experience them is by train. 

You can start your journey in Vancouver, which is one of Canada's most beautiful cities. This city is unique because it is close to both the ocean and the mountains, allowing people to ski just 15 minutes away from the city center. 

In the past, thirty passenger trains left Vancouver daily for the cross-continent railway. Now, there are only three trains each week, but the journey remains an exciting adventure. You can sleep on the train, which is enjoyable, but you will see some of the most stunning landscapes at night.

**Zoos**

People have kept animals in zoos for over 3,000 years, starting with a large zoo in China called the Gardens of Intelligence. In the past, animals were trained to perform for visitors, but this practice has stopped. Now, the main goal of zoos is to allow people to observe animals in their natural behaviors. Most cities today have a zoo or wildlife park.

However, opinions about zoos vary. Supporters argue that zoos help us learn about nature and allow us to see wild animals up close, which would be difficult without them. Conversely, critics believe it is wrong to confine animals in cages. They argue that poorly managed zoos can lead to animals living in unsanitary conditions and being fed inappropriate diets.

**JAZZ**  
By Katie Atkins, aged 14  

I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes, from black school uniforms like ours to bright T-shirts. We may not have looked like professional adult bands, but we were all experienced performers, so the quality of our playing was impressive, especially considering our young age. Musicians from each band even made up new songs right on stage. It was thrilling to watch, but even more exciting when my band performed!  

Our school has a fantastic jazz band, but not everyone who wants to join gets in—only about half of the applicants. However, anyone eager to play can attend jazz practice before school, and we often hang out after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. We also go on trips to jazz summer camps around the country; I’ve attended a few and learned a lot.  

Adults are often surprised that young people are interested in jazz. My music teacher believes it’s because pop music isn’t challenging enough for serious musicians like me. I find jazz exciting because it feels both new and old at the same time—you can create your own music while also connecting with its rich history, just like the great jazz musicians before us. Our school is fortunate to have excellent teachers and supportive parents. Without their help, we wouldn’t make progress in our music!

**Watering the Desert**

In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain anytime from November to March. However, rain is rare, and when it does occur, the city's water pipes often cannot handle the sudden floods, causing the streets to become like rivers. Despite the lack of rain in many recent winters, when it finally rains, the local people appreciate it. 

The parks and gardens in Marrakesh do not rely on rain; instead, they are sustained by a system of underground channels created in the 11th century. These channels bring water from the mountains throughout the year. Areas that are mostly dry but receive water this way are called oases.

Traveling further south from Marrakesh, one reaches Skoura. In Skoura, every piece of land is divided into small sections by water channels, which are used to grow food. The snow-covered Atlas Mountains in winter provide a beautiful backdrop to this landscape.

Gareth Ellis, who is 13 years old, is the youngest son of Alan, an engineer, and Kath, a nursery teacher. His older brothers work in banking and computers, but Gareth has always dreamed of being a clown. Three years ago, the family joined a circus. Kath explains, "People laugh when we tell them, but it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three." 

When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to look for full-time work in the circus. They both found jobs with a well-known circus, and Gareth started training to become a clown, calling himself Bippo. They travel with the circus in the summer and return home in the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away. 

Kath admits, "I can't say it was easy. There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a small caravan to sleep in, and we were leaving our nice house behind. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths." 

Gareth shares, "People ask about my education, but from the start, someone has always come to teach me wherever we go. I use the same books as my classmates and I have a computer. I've never fallen behind." 

As for the future, Kath says, "It was a tough decision, but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it." Gareth adds, "One day, I'm going to be the main clown in a circus, maybe Bippo's circus."

**Eight-eighteen News**

Eight-eighteen News is a news agency designed for young people aged 8 to 18. We gather news and write reports, stories, and articles. These are sent to major national and local newspapers, magazines, television, radio, and websites for publication. You can read or listen to the news stories and articles created by our members on the Eight-eighteen website.

We have three centers across the country where young people can meet others and participate in projects, and we plan to open more centers soon. Since our agency began in 1994, originally called 'Young News', over 2,500 young people have joined. One of them is Sophie. She shared, "I first learned about Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article about young people's views on hip hop music. I was in a room with young journalists and was impressed by the opportunities they had. Age didn’t matter; they were trusted to handle stories independently. I started attending the Eight-eighteen center in my city, received training, and remained a member until I turned 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I ever expected. With the skills I gained, I got a job at 19 and am now the youngest employee at a major news website, where I check articles written by journalists before they are published."

**Get Involved at Every Level**

When you join Eight-eighteen, you will receive training and participate in monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen promotes skill-sharing among members. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members aged 12 and older who train new members in basic journalism skills. As they gain more experience, some members present sessions to audiences of young people and adults outside of Eight-eighteen, often at youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are always supported by older staff who accompany them on these outings.

Eight-eighteen News offers training sessions for new members three times a year. The next training for new members will be in February. If you or someone you know is interested in joining, please call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with reading and writing skills at all levels. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website! Here, you will find all the information you need before booking a flight. During the short summer in Antarctica, we offer sightseeing flights from Sydney, Australia, on a Boeing 747. These flights take you over Antarctica and back. The exact dates for next year are not confirmed yet, but if you book now, your deposit can be transferred if we need to change the date.

**Frequently Asked Questions**

**How long is the flight?**  
The average flight lasts 12 hours. About four hours into the journey, we usually start seeing sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica and the rest of the time returning home. During the flight, experts who have worked in Antarctica will give talks about the environment and history, and they will answer your questions. There is also a camera near the pilot that shows a view from the cockpit throughout the flight.

**Will I get a seat next to a window?**  
All passengers receive two boarding passes. At the halfway point of the flight, you will be asked to move to the seat indicated on your second boarding pass. Business and first-class passengers will have a window seat for half of the flight and a seat next to a window for the other half. Economy passengers will have either a window seat or a seat next to a window for half of the flight and an aisle seat for the other half. While we are over Antarctica, we encourage passengers to move around the plane to enjoy the views. The pilot will fly in long 'figure 8' patterns over interesting sights so that everyone can see well from both sides of the plane.

**What happens if the weather is bad?**  
We have 17 different approved flight plans. On the morning of the flight, our captain will check the satellite images of the clouds and choose the route that offers the best views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**  
Most wildlife in Antarctica lives at sea level, which is over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we cannot see them clearly. We do not land in Antarctica for environmental reasons. If you want to see wildlife, you would need to join a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**  
Absolutely! You are welcome to bring all types of cameras. We even offer some fun photo opportunities on board where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothing.

**Little Chefs**

A group of children aged ten to fifteen spends their Saturdays learning how to cook. Their small classes are very popular, and there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where children can have fun and learn to make delicious food. 

Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it even better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down to enjoy the food we've made together." 

Flora, who is twelve, has some trouble with onions. She shares, "I love cooking. I prepared a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. My mum suggested I find a hobby instead of just staying home on weekends. At first, I wasn't very interested, but I'm really glad I decided to come." 

Their teacher, Philippe, explains, "It's a lot of fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, even if the kitchen isn't always tidy when they cook! As adults, we keep learning more about food. If parents encourage their children to cook when they are young, they will have the skills to prepare meals for themselves when they grow up."

**Winter Driving**

Driving in winter can be dangerous because conditions can change quickly, leading to accidents. Fog can appear suddenly over a hill, and ice may be hidden under melting snow, which can cause you to lose control of your vehicle. A car coming towards you might unexpectedly slide across the road.

**Rule Number One** for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Sudden movements can make it hard to control your car. When you turn the wheel, brake, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. You can think of it like driving with a full cup of hot coffee next to you—drive carefully so you don’t spill it.

**Rule Number Two** is to stay alert to potential dangers. The more ice there is, the further ahead you should look. Practice how long it takes to stop by braking gently. Be aware that you might be driving faster than you realize. Generally, you should allow double your normal stopping distance on wet roads, three times that on snow, and even more on ice. Always try to keep control of your car to avoid accidents.

Craigie Aitchison

Craigie Aitchison was a painter from Scotland. He moved to London with the plan to study law, but instead, he chose to attend art school. He found the traditional drawing classes challenging, but he continued to paint. In his late twenties, the Italian government supported him financially to study art, which sparked his interest in early Italian artists. This influence can be seen in some of his artwork. He was inspired by the greens and browns of the Italian countryside and the bright light there, and he aimed to capture this light in his paintings. 

To achieve this, he painted colors in thin layers, from light to dark, but he admits he never knows how the final result will turn out. He explains, "It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start with yellow, knowing what I will add on top." Like many skilled artists, Aitchison makes it seem simple. He believes anyone can use colors since they can be bought, but he focuses on how colors interact with each other.

Unlike some artists, Aitchison does not create sketches before starting a painting. He feels that making sketches might make him lose interest in the actual painting. Instead, he often changes his paintings multiple times before they are complete. This is why he prefers to work with models who do not ask to see their portraits while he is painting. He says, "If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it."

Since moving to London, Aitchison has not felt connected to the Scottish art scene. He claims he is not interested in following any artistic tradition; he simply paints in his own way. Nevertheless, his work continues to inspire young British artists.

**Rock Band**

Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked for a drum set for his birthday. At first, we were against it because of the noise. Ben argued, "It's better than watching TV or playing video games in my free time, and it will keep me out of trouble." Eventually, we agreed. We said, "Okay, but you need to think about the rest of the family and the neighbors when you play."

That was just the start. Since drums are hard to move, Ben's band members began coming to our house with their guitars and other equipment. Now, for several hours each week, our house shakes with their music and singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever they practice, my husband and I go for a long walk. 

I must admit that, even though their music can sound a bit unusual, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I can't judge their musical talent—after all, I didn't expect my parents to enjoy the same music I liked as a teenager—but they do perform regularly in local clubs for young people. 

Our main concern is that they might not spend enough time on their schoolwork because of their music, but that hasn't happened yet. I always remind Ben how important his studies are. One thing is clear: Ben was right; playing music has kept him out of trouble and he is never bored.

**Atlantic College**

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a great private college in Wales. This college offers students valuable experiences outside the classroom, along with the chance to prepare for their exams. The students, aged 16 to 18 and from various countries, study in the mornings. In the afternoons, they participate in meaningful activities, such as helping on a farm, caring for individuals with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One of the remarkable aspects of Atlantic College is its diverse student body, which includes individuals from different social backgrounds and countries. Since the tuition fees are £20,000 for two years, many students rely on grants to afford it. About 25% of the students are British, and many of them can only attend because of government support.

Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands, expressed her admiration for the college's efforts to promote international understanding among young people. She said, "You learn to live with and respect others, even those you may not like. During the summer holidays, my mother noticed I argued much less with my sister."

In conclusion, Atlantic College provides an excellent education through effective methods that truly benefit its students.

**Being an Older Student**

At 32, I have just completed my first year at university. Along with attending lectures regularly, I have had to learn to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to return to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, I earned a decent salary, but I felt bored because my job required little thought. This made me increasingly unhappy, as I felt trapped in my position. I envied the local university students, who seemed happy, carefree, and full of hope, and I wanted to be part of that experience.

Now that I am a student, I find it challenging to connect with younger classmates. They often mistake me for a lecturer and ask me questions I cannot answer. I also feel distant from the lecturers, as we are the same age, but I know much less than they do. However, I appreciate this chance to study because I understand that having a qualification is essential for getting a fulfilling job, which is very important to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer spending my weekends with my books rather than going out to parties. 

Additionally, I enjoy the typical student benefits, such as long holidays and discounts for theaters and cinemas. I often worry about what I will do after university, but I hope that continuing my education at this stage in my life has been a wise decision.

**Henry Ford**

Henry Ford was born in 1863 on a farm in Michigan, but he did not enjoy farming. At the age of fifteen, he started working as a mechanic. In 1893, he created his first car. After driving it for 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and then made two larger cars. In 1903, he founded the Ford Motor Company. By using strong yet lightweight steel, he produced affordable cars for regular people. In 1908, he introduced the first Ford Model 'T', which cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars every day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was valued at $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and inexpensive, but this simplicity sometimes meant fewer options. Henry Ford famously said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

**Rebecca Stevens**

Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to successfully climb Mount Everest. Before this achievement, she worked as a journalist and lived in a small apartment in south London. In 1993, Rebecca decided to leave her job and family to travel to Asia with a group of climbers. She quickly learned that life on Everest is very challenging. 

"You have to carry everything on your back," she said. "This means you can only bring what you really need. There is no way to wash on the mountain, and in the end, I didn’t even take a toothbrush. I usually like to stay clean, but there is no water, just snow. Water is very heavy, so you only take enough to drink!"

When Rebecca reached the summit of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the happiest moment of her life. This accomplishment made her famous. She has since written a book about her experience, and people often invite her to speak about it. She also has a new job on a science television program. 

Today, Rebecca is well-known and has more money, but she still lives in her small apartment in south London, surrounded by her pictures and books about mountains.

**Canada Geese**

Canada Geese are large birds with blue and white feathers. When autumn comes, they need to fly south to find warmer weather. The winters in Canada are very cold, and the birds would not survive if they stayed there. 

Last spring, Bill Lishman discovered sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. They had lost their parents and would not know how to migrate in the autumn. Bill owned a small plane and decided to help the birds learn to follow him. Throughout the summer, he took short flights in his plane, and the young geese followed him.

When autumn arrived and the weather turned cold, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, which is 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him all the way to Virginia. After reaching Virginia, Bill left the geese there and returned home.

This spring, Bill waited for the geese to come back, but they did not arrive. Concerned, he flew back to Virginia to find them. He searched for two weeks but could not locate them. When he returned home, he was surprised to find the geese waiting for him. They had managed to find their way back home on their own!

**ESTHER'S STORY**

When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. While most of Esther's friends chose to go to college, Esther decided to use her aunt's money to start her own business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make jam. She sold the jam for £1 per jar to her friends and quickly earned back her aunt's £500.

At first, Esther's parents were not supportive of her jam-making. They believed she should focus on her studies and hoped she would become a teacher or a doctor. However, Esther ignored their advice and continued making jam. After a few months, she began selling her jam at the local market. She also started making orange juice, which she sold to a school where a friend worked.

After two years, her business had grown significantly, and her parents were proud of her. She produced various types of food and sold them to shops and supermarkets. She became so busy that she needed to hire some employees to help her.

**Corryvale Farm**

Corryvale Farm is located in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler raise cows and chickens, selling milk and eggs. However, most of their income comes from Jenny's sheep. She has 50 sheep, and each sheep produces enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen shears the sheep to keep them comfortable.

Five years ago, Jenny tried to sell sweaters made from the wool at country markets, but it was summer and too hot for people to buy sweaters. Instead, she made socks, which became very popular because they were affordable, durable, and easy to clean. This is how Jenny's business began.

Initially, she made the socks at home, but soon she gained thousands of customers. As a result, she started sending the wool to a factory where machines now produce all the socks. There are six colors, five sizes for all ages, and various types of socks for walkers, athletes, and skiers. 

Jenny is especially busy during Christmas because Corryvale socks are a popular gift. Her office walls are filled with letters from satisfied customers from around the world.

He noted that 67% of these burglaries happen when people leave their homes and forget to lock doors or windows. 

Inspector Saunders mentioned that burglaries at night are rare because families are usually at home during that time. However, winter afternoons are particularly favorable for burglars since it gets dark, making it easier for them to go unnoticed. Many houses are also empty during this time because people are still at work.

To help prevent burglaries, Inspector Saunders suggested leaving lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when going on holiday. This can deter burglars. He also encouraged neighbors to keep an eye on each other's homes when someone is away and to contact the police if they notice anything suspicious. 

"We can also provide advice on how to secure your home," Inspector Saunders added. "This assistance is free of charge."

Before farming began, people searched forests for plants and fruits to eat. This meant they had to move constantly to find food. Farming allowed people to settle in one place, leading to the growth of villages. As a result, some villagers could focus on other jobs, like making clothes, because farmers provided food for everyone. Unfortunately, farming could be challenging, especially during bad weather, which sometimes left people without enough food. Today, farmers can produce more food, which can travel thousands of kilometers to reach our homes.

Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from a small town in Canada. They have been friends and classmates for a long time. Like their other friends, they usually enjoy fishing or swimming on weekends. However, for the past few months, they have spent every weekend in Peter's room working on his laptop. This is not because they have a lot of homework; instead, they have created a new computer word game.

The idea for the game came from Frazer's younger brother, Kevin, who struggles with reading. Kevin finds it easier to learn words by seeing pictures and hearing sounds rather than by reading text. Frazer wanted to help his brother, so he and Peter worked together for over 200 hours to develop the game, which is now ready to use.

The game combines speaking and pictures. For instance, when you see the word "hat," there is a drawing of a hat next to it, and you can hear Peter saying "Hat! Hat!" at the same time. The boys have received many awards for their game, and it will soon be available for sale worldwide. Many schools are interested in purchasing it.

**How Does the Irish Pop Group 'Boyzone' Live a Healthy Life?**

Getting enough sleep is very important. When I return to my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. However, after a concert, I find it hard to sleep because my mind is filled with music. 

Staying active is also essential. Before my car accident, I spent two and a half hours at the sports center five days a week. Now, I can't do that, so I do about 150 sit-ups daily. I do not drink alcohol or smoke, and I try to eat healthily. I also drink a lot of water because it is good for my health. I should drink about eight glasses a day, but I don’t always manage that.

It is important not to work all the time. I love my job, but I enjoy other activities too. In my free time, I like to listen to music or watch TV. Sometimes, it is good to relax and do nothing. **Bollywood**

Bollywood is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India, and it produces nearly 1,000 films each year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has created over 29,000 films, making it the largest film industry in the world, far surpassing the USA. Watching films is the most popular leisure activity for many Indians, with around ten million people going to the cinema daily. 

Bollywood films often focus on romantic love stories, and they include a lot of singing and dancing. These films are also popular outside of India. Last year, Bollywood earned over $500 million by selling its films to other countries. 

Indian actors produce more films each year than American actors in Hollywood, but they earn less money. This is why most Bollywood films have a production cost of about $2 million, while Hollywood films typically cost at least $5 million. Most Bollywood actors are young and work hard, but their careers are often short. Amitabh Bachchan, who is considered by some to be India's greatest actor, is an exception. He has starred in more than 140 films over a career that has lasted nearly 40 years.

Parrots

You may have seen these beautiful birds, known for their vibrant colors and long tails, in forests or zoos. Parrots are native to countries such as Brazil, Australia, and India. They are quite loud, but they are intelligent and can easily be taught to speak. Some zoos feature parrot shows, where you can watch these birds perform learned behaviors.

The Rhino

There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos are found in the open fields of Africa, while the other types live in forests in Asia. All rhinos have large, heavy bodies. Their skin is tough, and they have very little hair. A rhino's body rests on four short legs, and each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but can run at speeds of up to 50 kilometers per hour. Rhinos are generally quiet and calm animals, primarily eating grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs about 40 kilograms at birth and stays in its mother for around fifteen months. An adult rhino can weigh over 200 kilograms and may live for up to 50 years.

**THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE**

Today, we see police officers everywhere, but in 1700, London had no police force. A few elderly men tried to protect the streets at night, but they were not paid much. Around 300 years ago, London was growing larger. The city was very dirty, and many people lived in poverty. There were many thieves who stole money in the streets, causing people to stay home as much as possible.

In 1750, Henry Fielding began to pay a group of individuals to catch thieves. They were similar to police officers and were called the 'Bow Street Runners' because they operated near Bow Street. By 1800, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had expanded significantly and needed more police.

In 1829, the first Metropolitan Police Force was established, consisting of 3,000 officers. Most of these men patrolled on foot, while a few rode horses. Until 1920, all police officers in London were men. Today, London police officers are well compensated, and those who still ride horses earn even higher salaries than their colleagues.

**ICE FISHING**

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes, and many Canadian fishermen visit every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Inside these houses, they fish for the fish swimming beneath the ice.

Bob Marvisch has been coming here for twenty-five years during this season. He says, "You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks, gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top. Catching fish is easy." 

To fish, you first break the ice to create a small round hole. Then, you take a fishing line, put some bread on it, and lower it through the hole into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. The fish are usually between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people enjoy eating them, but after I catch three or four, I prefer to have chocolate or another snack! Today, I caught twenty-five! It's a fun sport, and you can meet nice people here!

Madame Tussaud's

One well-known tourist attraction in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. Visitors can see wax figures of famous individuals here. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle, who was a doctor, created wax figures and opened a museum in Paris. Marie assisted him with this work. In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was imprisoned. While in prison, she had to create wax models of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud, and in 1802, she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her figures are still on display today.

BICYCLES

Bicycles are an affordable and environmentally friendly mode of transportation. The first bicycle was created around 150 years ago. Initially, bicycles were quite costly, making them accessible only to wealthy individuals. These early models looked very different from modern bicycles. Over time, as prices decreased, more people began to purchase bicycles. Many started using them for commuting and leisure activities. 

Today, cars are more commonly used than bicycles because they are faster and keep you dry in the rain. However, some individuals still choose to cycle to work. They argue that there are too many cars in city centers, making parking difficult to find.

The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14

Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. The park had beautiful flower gardens, but we were mainly interested in the elephant show. We went directly to a large area with seats on three sides. Three elephants entered with their keepers and stood in front of a big piece of white card. Each elephant was given a paintbrush and began to paint on its own card. Occasionally, the keepers would give each elephant a new brush filled with paint and take away the old one. Slowly, following their keepers' guidance, the elephants created pictures on the cards. I was amazed by what I saw! One picture depicted a river, another a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the keepers displayed the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We also gave the elephants the bananas we had brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they no longer do that, but the smartest elephants live in special centers where visitors can watch them.

**Big Cats**

There are many types of cats, each varying in size, appearance, and behavior. Tigers are the largest cats, measuring up to 3.7 meters from head to tail. While most cats avoid water, tigers often enjoy lying in pools when it is hot. Lions are unique among cats because they live in large family groups. These groups often work together to hunt for food. Lions typically inhabit flat, open areas where they can see far and track other animals easily. All cats require excellent eyesight to hunt smaller animals for food. Additionally, they need to be fast and strong.

THE OSTRICH

The ostrich is the largest bird in the world, with adults weighing over 90 kilograms. Most wild ostriches are found in southern Africa, but their numbers are declining. Although ostriches have wings like all birds, they cannot fly. Instead, they use their wings to help them change direction while running. Ostriches are incredibly fast runners, reaching speeds of 65 to 90 kilometers per hour, making it hard for predators to catch them. Baby ostriches are about the same size as chickens and take around three years to grow into adults. They primarily eat plants and can survive for many days without water.

Victoria Jamieson, a 23-year-old snowboarder from Britain, began snowboarding at the age of 20. She has achieved success in many competitions. Recently, we interviewed her at a snowboarding event in Switzerland and asked why she chose this sport. She explained, "I have always enjoyed various sports, especially skiing, so snowboarding felt like a natural choice. It’s easy to learn, and you can become quite skilled in just a few months."

When we inquired about her practice routine, she shared, "During winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also enjoy running and biking. I truly love all of it! Competing and being in the mountains is wonderful, but free-riding—doing what you want outside of competitions—is the best part for me."

We also asked her about the key factors for learning to snowboard. She replied, "You can learn quickly, but taking lessons is essential. Having the right clothing is also important to stay dry, especially since beginners often fall a lot!"

**Mount Kilimanjaro**

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people, ranging from a seven-year-old boy to an 87-year-old man, have successfully climbed it. There are several routes to reach the summit, with the Marangu path, which is five kilometers long, considered the easiest. This route typically takes about five days to complete and is very popular among tourists. However, only half of those who attempt to climb Kilimanjaro actually reach the top. This is often due to the unpredictable weather. At the start of the climb, conditions can be hot and rainy, but as climbers ascend, they encounter ice and snow, with temperatures possibly dropping below 20 degrees Celsius. Therefore, climbers should prepare by bringing both sunglasses and warm clothing!

**Otters**

Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes using small pieces of wood. They usually come out at night. Otters are excellent swimmers and can swim faster than 10 kilometers per hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, allowing it to stay underwater for several minutes. 

Twenty years ago, there were very few otters in Great Britain. The rivers were so polluted that many fish and insects died, leaving otters without food. However, today the rivers are clean again, and there is plenty of food for them.

**Buildings**

People have always constructed buildings. We need houses to stay warm and dry, and we build stadiums to enjoy football matches and concerts. Other buildings, like museums, are used to display beautiful items. Many individuals collaborate on a building project. The architect determines the building's appearance and creates drawings to share their vision. Engineers ensure the building is strong and safe. Finally, workers carefully construct it.

The Sydney Opera House is a well-known modern building with a stunning roof. However, it is beautiful from all angles, not just the top. Another notable structure is the Olympic Stadium in Munich, which resembles a glass tent.
