The Cerne Giant

Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in southern England that are close to each other. Between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a large image of a man. This man is called the Cerne Giant because the nearby village is named Cerne. The exact time when the Cerne Giant was created is unknown, but it is believed to be very ancient. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the image. If you visit on May 1st at sunrise, you will see the villagers dancing around the giant on the hill.

Gail Rollins is one of the top runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she plans to compete in the 10,000 metres and possibly the 5,000 metres at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was known for finishing second in major competitions, but she always remained cheerful, which made her popular in her hometown. Everything changed in 2004 when she participated in her first half-marathon, a long road race, and won with the fastest time of the year for any British woman runner.

Gail's husband and manager, Mike Rollins, used to race as well, but he had to stop competing due to an injury to his right leg. He can still run a little and sometimes trains with Gail, but it can be frustrating for him when she runs ahead and he can't keep up. Gail trains diligently, doing long runs in the morning and faster runs in the afternoon, but she always takes Sundays off from running. Mike says, "I am with her all the time. Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' Usually, it's cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

**Piano Players - Their Early Years**

**Ivan Petrov**  
Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From the age of twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher could not play the piano but taught him and his sister songs from operas. His mother started teaching him the piano when he was six years old. By the age of ten, he wanted to write music and began working on his first song.

**Oleg Gagarin**  
Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him some traditional Russian songs. At six, he began taking lessons from a piano teacher in his city. Oleg quickly started winning prizes for his piano skills. At fourteen, he attended a music college in Austria for two years before returning to Russia.

**Josef Heptmann**  
Josef's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two, and he began playing the piano a year later. He had his first concert at six years old. By the age of ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England! Josef loved music but was also interested in physics and languages. Although he is very busy now, he hopes to write his own music one day.

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, teacher, and dentist before he became a children's book writer at the age of 60. Now, thirteen years later, he has written over 80 books. Every day, he works in his office and writes. In the evening, he shares his work with his wife, who tells him what she thinks. "She lets me know when she doesn't like something," Bill explains. His ten grandchildren, who live far away, also read his stories and give their opinions.

Through this feedback, Bill has learned what young children enjoy reading. He often writes about life in his village and the nearby farms. His favorite book is his fifth one, titled "The Sheepdog," which tells the story of a farmer and his helpful dog. "I have always loved animals," Bill says, "and dogs are very smart; they learn quickly." 

Last year, this book was turned into a film featuring real animals and actors. The filmmakers used advanced computer technology to make it seem like the animals were talking. Bill was very happy with the film. "Sometimes filmmakers change the stories, but they didn't change mine, and I love the film."

**POSTCARDS**

Today, many people enjoy sending postcards to their friends and family. These postcards usually feature images of beaches, mountains, or castles, and you can write a message on the back. Many individuals send postcards while on holiday because they are inexpensive, and the images are often more appealing than personal photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the nineteenth century, and it displayed a picture of a seaside town. Over time, postcards began to show images related to current events, such as accidents or visits from important figures. People appreciated these postcards because newspapers at that time did not include pictures.

Dinosaurs

No one has ever seen a dinosaur because the last one died around 60 million years ago, long before humans existed. The exact reason for their extinction is still unknown. Birds are the closest living relatives of dinosaurs. Dinosaurs were not all the same; there were over 5,000 different types. Some were very small, while others were enormous. The largest dinosaurs were bigger than any land animals that have ever lived. For instance, the Brontosaurus was about twenty meters long and primarily ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was smaller but much stronger, with sharp teeth for eating meat and long back legs that allowed it to run quickly.

**Bears**

Bears can be dangerous animals. An adult bear is very strong and can potentially harm a person. They are skilled climbers and can run quickly. However, bears have poor eyesight and, like many animals, rely on their sense of smell to find food. 

There are seven species of bears. The largest is the polar bear, which can grow to nearly three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: one inhabits the forests of North America, while the other is found in Southeast Asia. Interestingly, not all black bears are actually black; some can be dark brown or reddish-brown. 

The black and white panda bear, native to China, is beloved by many. Unfortunately, the number of pandas in the wild is decreasing because they struggle to find enough food in their forest habitats.

CROCODILES

Crocodiles are found in tropical regions around the world, such as Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They primarily inhabit slow-moving waters but can swim quickly and move fast on land. It is common to see crocodiles in large groups. Their diet includes a variety of prey, such as fish, birds, and small animals, and they can also attack larger animals or even humans. There are over ten different species of crocodiles, all equipped with very sharp teeth. Although they frequently lose teeth, they quickly grow new ones. Typically, crocodiles measure about 3.5 meters in length, although some can be much larger. They have a long lifespan, with the oldest recorded crocodile in a zoo living to be 66 years old.

A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL

In 1783, two French brothers created the first balloon that could carry people into the sky. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers invented the first powered airplane and successfully flew it in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office launched the first airmail service. Over the next thirty years, airplanes underwent significant changes. By the 1950s, they became much faster due to the introduction of jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was developed in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger airplane in the world, capable of flying at 2,500 kilometers per hour, which allows a journey from London to New York to take only four hours. Today, millions of people travel by airplane, making it hard to imagine a world without them.

The Globe Theatre

Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was quite different from today. The building was round and had no roof, so people would get cold and wet if it rained. The queen enjoyed attending performances at the Globe Theatre, located by the River Thames, to watch the plays of William Shakespeare. At that time, all the actors were men. The audience would eat, chat with friends, and walk around during the performance, and some even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre has been built in the same location by the river. You can watch a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.
